review_content:
The Baklava sweet has uncertain origins. The fact is that it is an ancient sweet, claimed by many peoples, each with their own variant.
A dessert that has honey as its main element, in addition to dried fruit.
In Aurum you will feel one of the most real representations of honey there is, honey in honeycomb, made gourmand by dried fruit and a light touch of praline on the base.
It really feels like eating a Baklava, a dessert I love so much.
Realistic, deep, I am not a gourmand lover, but I really liked this fragrance.
Ideal for the cooler seasons.
‘Yuansu Series I, Geometric Series I #01 World, 2007’ represented by contemporary artist Ren Ri.

Zaharoff Signature Aurum is the second-to-most recent release of the house, a captivating honey-rich scent that captures the baklava dish with lots of nuance, including notes of honeycomb, cinnamon, mixed nuts, vanilla, and tonka. It’s sweet and rich while not being overly sweet, with a vaguely floral brightness that makes it feel more honeyed that perhaps a baked good, at least to me, and a lot more wearable for those that find gourmands challenging or overbearing. This is a great answer for those, and takes for the form of a unisex fragrance that has great density without being at all overdone in any one aspect, its balance demonstrating the care and patience that went into it. I guess it’s the first gourmand of the Signature line, but I hope it’s not the last, as it’s yet another outstanding expansion of the line into new territory, a further challenge met and exceeded against. I really love this creation, definitely among my favorite honey scents with Zoologist Bee and Hiram Green Slowdive, albeit not as syrupy as Bee and not as spicy as Slowdive, nor as floral as either, fitting for a gourmand. To my nose, it does not evolve a ton, a little sharper at first spray and a little smoother and creamier in the dry down, but that’s to be expected, frankly.

The line’s pricing remains very reasonable for a high-quality, high-performance product, especially at the greater size, at $195/155 for 120/60ml, sold through the house website exclusively in the US, I believe.

8 out of 10

I find this fragrance interesting in that in the very beginning as the scent hits my skin I can barely detect it at all. It develops though, into a wonderfully pure floral where I definitely smell lilac, and the lilac seems to be a dominant note for a while. Lilacs are probably my most favorite spring flower so this is a bonus! It transforms into what my mind envisions, a white bouquet, with a good abundance of dainty little lily of the valley interspersed throughout, (I happen to grow Lily of the Valley in the depths of the cool shade, and their smell is amazing). Elle 25 is not heady or headachy, but a pure uncomplicated scent that smells to me like the cool, crisp spring air that carries the scent of new fresh blossoms. A beautiful change of pace for me and very, very enjoyable.

This is a nice floral bouquet under toned by notes of cedar and musk.
It's so simple but yet so wonderful.I can't separate the floral notes because they are blended all together without one being stronger from the other.
It opens and stays with the floral notes from the beginning to the end.It's not heady or loud but intimate and you feel its sensation.Inoffensive and feminine ,wearable to all occasion and seasons.

Essence Rare opens with a green, vegetal smell of freshly cut, wet flower stems, as if you are inside a flower shop. In the background the flowers start to appear on the stage, jasmine, roses, and lilies of the valley. The evolution is pretty linear, a little boring and unpleasant for me, as the lily of the valleys with the oakmoss beginning to take center and dominate. If you like lily of the valley, you might enjoy this. It's just a note that I don't particularly care for.

Essence Rare se deschide cu un miros verde-vegetal de tulpini de flori ude, proaspăt tăiate, ca și cum ai intrat într-o florărie. Pe fundal, apar și florile, iasomia, trandafirii, și lăcrimioarele. Evoluția este foarte liniară, cam plictisitoare și neplăcută pentru că lăcrimioarele încep să domine împreună cu lichenul. Dacă îți plac lăcrimioarele, poate că o să te încânte. Siaj și persistență moderate. 6/10

Hello, you sniffers, and good evening :)
Tonight, I’m introducing a new, old fragrance. Huh, how can that be, you might be asking?! Well, the fragrance Essence Rare is already a classic, first released in 1928, reissued in 1976, and finally revised and re-released in 2018. I know that many of you think that reformulated fragrances always lose quality. That may indeed be true, but I can’t say much about it yet, as I haven’t experienced fragrances over multiple generations, since I’m not as old as all of you (… so much for my New Year’s resolution to be a bit nicer to you ladies here… :DD), but I also think that not all reformulations have to be bad.

Anyway, it seems that the perfumer of this fragrance doesn’t mind reformulations either, especially when given the honor of re-composing a classic fragrance. It’s then about combining tried-and-true elements from the past with something new, at least according to the perfumer.

Well, since I don’t know the 1976 fragrance and especially the 1928 fragrance of this one, as I said, I’m not nearly as old as you (… I really should, REALLY stop referring to you ladies as older… :DD), I can’t write a comparison test, but as always, I’ll share my opinion on this fragrance and try to describe it as accurately as possible :)

The Fragrance:
The fragrance actually starts with quite classic notes, or it smells like a classic French fragrance. At first sniff, it reminds me a lot of Guerlain’s wonderful Habit Rouge, only a bit more floral and feminine. You can smell lily of the valley and jasmine, as well as a creamy-powdery note that could come from notes like violet or even more so, iris. A hint of the stated mandarin is also present, but you have to sniff very closely to detect it. When you sniff directly at the sprayed spot, you can briefly perceive a mandarin, or better said, a mandarin peel, as it comes off slightly bitter.
The classic impression of the fragrance remains later on, which is not surprising due to notes like oak moss. Additionally, the fragrance also appears slightly soapy or clean.
Towards the end, the fragrance continues to smell classic with oak moss and remains creamy-soft due to powdery notes. Of course, the fragrance is also beautifully floral. And this is exactly the kind of floral notes that I like in a ladies' fragrance, as they don’t smell cloying or stuffy, but simply come across as beautifully feminine. I still lean towards lily of the valley and jasmine, although the roses are now also more noticeable. Along with the floral sweetness, there’s another sweetness from the vanilla. Overall, a truly lovely fragrance.

The Sillage and Longevity:
Although the fragrance seems soft, it has a strong sillage, so it can be perceived from a distance for a while. It’s pleasant to smell without being overwhelming. The longevity is also very good, as you can still smell the fragrance well on the skin after ten hours.

The Bottle:
The bottle is round and plump, with thick lines running around the glass that look like veins and seem to divide the glass into many separate chambers. On the front, one of these “chambers” is gilded and represents the label. The neck of the bottle is pink, and a cap designed similarly to the bottle sits on top, only this one is hemispherical and transparent. A very beautiful bottle.

Conclusion:
So, this fragrance really has something about it that is very appealing. I’m not always a fan of old-fashioned fragrances, but there are quite a few that I really, really like, such as Habit Rouge by Guerlain, which I can even wear at my over 30, 32, 34 (… let’s stop here, shall we? :D) years. You see, you’re not the only ones who have gotten much older… I’m just probably a tad younger than all of you, mu ha ha ha. Alright, alright, don’t come at me with pitchforks. Maybe it helps if I say that you ladies can still look absolutely stunning even at an older age?! Well, is there peace again now? :D

Anyway, although I don’t know the previous Essence Rare fragrances by Houbigant, I find this one simply very successful and therefore highly recommendable. It may not be a fragrance for younger people or for those who don’t like that classic touch, but I think it smells very good. It comes across as very elegant, has a slightly soapy-clean component, and just smells nice.

It’s an all-rounder, so in my opinion, it’s a fragrance for every season (except maybe very hot summer days) and can be worn subtly both during the day and especially for the evening and going out. Definitely give it a try sometime; it could be worth it!

That brings me to the end. Please excuse my age jokes (hey, I still find you all very sexy… uh, I meant I love you all :DD) and have a great evening, until next time :)

Over the past decades, I have had to attend so many funerals and memorial services. In doing so, I experienced the most absurd scenes, involuntarily comical and bordering on cabaret-like expressions and actions from mourners, even from those most closely affected.
Not to mention the speeches and life lies presented by the speakers.
As well as boundless grief, behind which not infrequently other sorrows and foreign mourning were unleashed. Funerals where an "Ave Maria" was spoken up to 100 times by a female voice over loudspeakers, while the mourners melted away in the sun and heat in black clothing.
Until I landed in Parfumo, the scent of half-wilting or strongly fragrant flowers like lilies and other blooms often played a breathtaking role for me, quite literally. Since then, I have scented myself for such occasions in a way that I can perceive myself and push the others aside.
Because I have experienced and observed so much absurdity at funerals and memorial services, I have considered several times whether I should write a collection of funeral stories. Alone: The new engagement with scents has kept me from doing so.
This would thus be the first published short story about the memorial service I experienced today, where a perfume, namely "Essence Rare," at least played a role for me.
My friend Hildegard did not pass away unexpectedly, but peacefully at the age of 95.
My friend Hildegard had, until the end, bright gold-red dyed hair and always wore black clothing, as she said. And she loved perfume, preferably Jovan Musk Oil and woody scents. So I also dressed entirely in black, even though I did not belong to the close circle of mourners, in her memory. And now the perfume?
I didn't think long: "Essence Rare"! And after spraying and letting it develop, I immediately thought: That was the wrong choice.
This scent would have never pleased Hildegard. And she would have made that clear to me without beating around the bush, I thought amused.
I had only tested it on my wrists and clearly perceived it as a scent with finely balanced beautiful and subtle white flowers. Immediately, I also smelled and had the scent of dry-powdery iris, which is not listed. - Later, "Essence Rare" becomes creamy. Despite the latent opulence, it is a delicate scent. "Essence Rare" is, typical of Elléna, an almost minimalist, in a special way dry-sober scent, created this time with white flowers. There is no long progression; within a few minutes, the scent settles, becoming only more delicate, the initially pronounced indole of the white flowers recedes.
But today I also sprayed on my décolletage, and now I smelled "lilies" as the main flower.
My husband, meanwhile, thought I smelled very elegant. He likes such scents.
And he also said that I only smelled very subtly and finely.
I could and did not want to change that anymore. In the church, it would not be warm; who knows if anyone else would even notice. And after all, I primarily scented myself for myself.
The church, meanwhile, was not decorated with any typical, strongly scented, and huge floral arrangements. Hildegard loved tulips and cyclamen. She loved the simplicity of the archaic block of stone altar from the Middle Ages with the mysterious five consecration crosses. This stands in contrast to the opulent baldachin and the pyramid pulpit from the Baroque.
When Hildegard and I prepared this altar for services, we looked at the ancient stone slab with the crosses in reverence. I felt "Shekina" was there. We never spoke about what we felt and thought about it; we remained silent.
So her place with the urn was only decorated with a cream-white organza cloth, surrounded only by a few upright giant grasses, nothing else. On the altar stood white tulips.
So I sat there, smelling my scent and thought: Oh, now I am contributing just a little bit to the ambiance (Italian: smell, scent, environment) that otherwise prevails at funerals in small churches and mourning halls.
It was a sober and quiet memorial service; not much was said, I smelled "Essence Rare," and I liked it more and more. I remembered that Hildegard was the first person we encountered here in this church.
What coincidences and events made us friends with an immediate understanding. How I often helped her as she became smaller and weaker.
No, "Essence Rare" will not become for me the funeral and mourning service scent.
It is also not a scent for other "great events." "Essence Rare," so my conclusion, is a sober-quiet yet intimate scent. A scent for contemplative hours, to find peace.
It may be that "Essence Rare," through this farewell, radiates a latent melancholy for me despite the brightness. Perhaps also because the always light indolic hint suggests passing, transience, and decay.
"A Dio, ci verdiamo in paradiso, Hildegard"

Sleeping flowers, this image goes through my mind with every spray.
“Essence Rare” starts off so calmly, expressing such profound silence and tranquility that I almost want to switch into meditation mode myself.
In the opening, a whisper-thin, mild “chalky” iris powder is sprinkled over fresh and initially only moderately sweet flowers. Not the powdery impression I usually smell in powdery scents, no sugary sweetness and nothing lively “powdery,” but a dry, powdery white layer over still resting flower heads.
Nevertheless, nothing here feels tired or dull; beneath the powdery layer, you can sense the life and energy of the flowers, just waiting for the sunrise to rise up and bloom in all colors.

And that happens within the first hour. Lily of the valley, rose, and jasmine bloom harmoniously next to each other, spreading their enchanting fragrance. A mild citrus breeze from fresh, partly ripe and juicy, partly still green, aromatic mandarins occasionally drifts through the composition, keeping the warm flowers fresh.
As the wearing time increases, the iris develops a subtle lipstick creaminess alongside its powdery facet, making the powder feel a bit more viscous and delicately creamy.

After at most an hour, I finally wear a substantial, airy-creamy, and sunny bouquet of flowers. I stand on a late spring day in front of a flower bed in the garden and breathe in the scent of countless colorful blooms.
It is important for me to emphasize that these are garden flowers growing and blooming in fresh summer air, not cut flowers in a vase. The typically green-stemmed accompanying notes that I smell when entering a flower shop (and in some floral scents) are absent here.

Overall, a clean-floral, sunny, and colorful bouquet of flowers that slowly settles on a fine bed of sandalwood and a few micrograms of vanilla powder. A mix of cream powder, iris powder, and chypre-like fresh elements accompanying the friendly radiant floral symphony that dominates everything from start to finish.

“Essence Rare” feels calm and elegant … and grown-up. So far removed from some garish, loud, flashy girly floral scents, as a fragrance can be.
It is not a “typical,” minimalist Jean-Claude Ellena. I have the impression that he has returned to his roots here, as he created classics like “First” for Van Cleef&Arpels and fragrances for Sisley in the 1970s. This scent is for me classic perfume art. An elegant fragrance that, in contrast to his “First,” does not feel overloaded with flowers, but despite the sea of blooms comes across as carefree and fairy-like light.

To make the scent comparable: The floral mix itself has a striking resemblance to “Jardins de Bagatelle” by Guerlain for my nose, but here it feels fresher and thus “more modern.”
What makes "Essence Rare" special for me is the accompaniment of different facets of iris, from white-mealy to lipstick-creamy, which sometimes envelop the bouquet in fine gauze and sometimes gently underlay it with creaminess.

review_title: And the golden raspberry goes to....
review_content:
The raspberry has bright white teeth and smiles at me challengingly. Overall, she is very dressed up and presents herself as peppery-youthful. When I ask if I might speak to the oud, her smile widens, but nothing happens. I secretly sigh. I have never faced such a vain raspberry before. The fact that she tries to mask her vanity with a deliberately simple vanilla-colored outfit only makes things worse. I decide to wait. Time will tell, oud will come. Or am I mistaken? In any case, a hint of unrefined oud would do this berry good. After about 4 hours, I get fed up and make my exit. She waves goodbye with a vanilla-colored handkerchief, which, I must admit, emits a rather pleasant scent.

Postscript: In the middle of the night, the phone rings. It’s the Not-So-Bad Vanilla. She hurriedly whispers to me that the oud has finally appeared, but must leave again right away; if I hurry, I might have a chance... I growl and hang up. The next morning, I have no idea whether the call was real or just a silly dream. I lean towards the latter. Or has anyone else been called by a vanilla in the middle of the night?

I fell in love with this fragrance from the very first moment, even though I am not a fan of oud.
Right after the first spray, I am transported back to my childhood; I smell wonderfully ripe, juicy, and zesty berries, raspberries, and strawberries, just like in my parents' garden when I picked them fresh and ripe myself, and of course, more ended up in my mouth than in the bowl. Hmmm, it smells so delicious, and I am 7 years old again, when the world was carefree and unburdened. And that's exactly how it continues after the top note.
The heart note, or rather the base note, doesn't take long to appear; after a short time, I perceive a warm, protective, soothing balsamic scent. It must be the oud and musk, as the vanilla plays only a minor role here. This is the first oud I like, because it is not sweaty and dirty, but soft, protectively warm. You really feel secure and carefree. Nevertheless, it remains light and unburdened; it doesn't overwhelm you but gives you your own space.
For me, a fragrance for small Déjà-vu moments of childlike carefreeness and security. And for anyone who usually doesn't like oud.

review_title: A secret recipe for black tea flavored fudge
review_content: What an incredibly weird and wonderful fragrance! This is a thick, rich, gooey tea-flavored fudge spiked with citrus and which reveals some evocative earthy elements that emerge as it dries. It’s as if a pot of strong tea was boiled down with a teacup full of brown sugar, a goodly glug of molasses, and slivers of bright yellow lemon peel, and then the mixture was stirred together with an entire box of sweet, nutty, whole wheat graham crackers crumbs and left on a counter to cool and set overnight. Fast forward about twenty years, and rather than the treat itself, this fragrance smells of its dusty, stained magazine clipping recipe card and which was secretly buried in the back garden by your eccentric relative because they didn’t want anyone to have their recipe after they died. This is why we dig it up and make the hell out of it and shout the recipe from the rooftops– because we don’t believe in gatekeeping the good stuff.

I sampled this not expecting to be wowed… MJ isn’t my fave house. But holy cow… I love it. It’s got the balance of sweetness at top and woodiness in the base that I enjoy in Daisy Love but with more fruity zing. Banana flower is a new note for me, and I really enjoy it here. Sandalwood and vetiver in the base remind me of grass in a really fresh way.
I think the Daisy line are all generally inoffensive, sweet, pretty… and this one is actually a standout!

ETA: came back to say I smell this strongly for the first hour, then I go noseblind to it and get a ton of compliments. lol Around hour 5 I start smelling it on myself again, but more intimate projection. A big spring love

review_title: A Little Sour, Zesty, Breezy, Unforgettable!
review_content:
I have a lot of perfumes, but this one definitely makes the top 5. What I love most is that little sour twist it gives the scent such a fun, lively kick! It’s fresh, green, and just the right amount of tart to keep things interesting. It reminds me of picking wildflowers on a sunny summer morning, right after the rain, when everything smells clean, green, and a little bit tangy from the damp earth and crisp air. There’s also a playful edge to it, like biting into a green apple or sipping on sparkling lemonade in a garden.
I usually wear it in the summer when its bright, green vibe really comes alive. It lasts around 7 hours on my skin, and the sillage? So good. I always get compliments when I wear it—it leaves a fresh, happy trail that gets noticed in the best way!

Synthetic, playful, adorable. Banana-flavored chewing gum; rubbery smell of a bouncy castle; entrance to the beach level in Sonic Adventure DX – with low poly women in swimsuits and incredibly blue water in the pool that somehow feels more real than the real thing.

Artificial banana part took about ~2 hours to evaporate. And perhaps that's nostalgia's fault – but I loved every moment it lasted. Jasmine, while visible, never took centerstage, and faded away soon after.

I was left with what I can only describe as "sweet sneakers" scent. It's like your regular clean sneakers, but with powdered sugar on top. Not unpleasant, but not something I'm looking for in a perfume either. My partner said that I smelled "like freshly washed feet after a long day of walking", so take that as you will. That scent took ~1,5 hours to settle close to the skin, and in another ~3,5 hours it was gone.

I don't think I'll ever wear it again, but I will remember those first 2 hours fondly.

I really wanted to like this because I bought a miniature set from Sephora with this and the original Daisy EAU DE TOILETTE and it smelled intriguing in the bottle. On my skin the banana came out in a way that I didn't like. I don't like bananas or banana flavored things and I am SUPER picky about them in fragrance. I tend to dislike them in my perfumes; there are a VERY few exceptions and this is not one of them. This smells like sunscreen and not the kind of sunscreen that smells good. The set was only $21 and there's a mini Daisy so I'm excited about that so I'm not too torn up about this but I am sad that I didn't like it :(

review_title: not a stand out but wearable
review_content: Marc Jacobs as a fragrance brand never stood out to me - moderately priced, pleasant enough without pushing the limit, with eye-catching bottles that draw me. But as beautiful as Marc Jacobs' bottles always are - Daisy Wild being in my favorite colors, no less - the fragrances miss the mark. I'm a fruity floral lover, there's no denying that, and most lighter, fresher, designer fragrances are nice enough that I wouldn't be holding back negative emotion if someone handed me a bottle as a gift, but I probably wouldn't spend my hard earned cash on them, either. Daisy Wild is in that same boat - fresh, sweet, with a hint of fruitiness, the perfect amount of sillage and depth for everyday, and won't create a sneezefest on the subway/metro/T/tram/bus etc. I enjoyed wearing it and would definitely use the heck out of a bottle, since this is basically gone by hour six, but it's not unique. From the middle to end of wear time is really where the fruity tropical smells come out, and the base is soft, sweet, and subtle. Reminds me a lot of the effect of Donna Born in Roma Coral Fantasy, but I enjoy that one a bit more.

I was testing some new releases at Ulta and I decided to smell this one of course. I do love many of the scents in the Marc Jacobs line. I knew I would invest in this one at some point in time for nothing more then the bottle, which is their most creative and lovely presentation yet. I sprayed it on my skin and clothes. Wow! I’m in love It is a floral, which is...

It’s sweet, it’s fresh, citrusy and a little tangy, it’s a nice light floral blend. The silage is moderate. The longevity for me seems to be 8 plus hours. I enjoyed wearing it but the crispness of it reminds me of Dolce and Gabbana light blue which is also lovely. I feel like it does tend to maybe lean a little too sweet, but not too much that it’s sickening.

The original Daisy was my signature scent when I was a teen so when I got a sample of this I hoped that it’d be the same soft, fresh, floral scent, but greener.
Unfortunately, this one has such a basic mainstream DNA.
I mean, it’s nice, but it’s just a generic scent.

Good for a younger audience with not a lot of knowledge of perfumes

... and seek joy, in this beautiful summer time. .. This song goes through my mind as I wandered through the perfume department of Karstadt, where the various summer scents were beautifully displayed. My eyes naturally lingered on the lovely Daisies by Marc Jacobs, which bloomed colorfully at me. I not only like the scents, but the beautiful floral bottles also appeal to me....

With a dip into the sample pot, "Daisy Wild" has earned its ticket for vacation with me. And it has proven to be wearable, even though it doesn't completely fit my usual preferences: Right after spraying, this fragrance feels exotic-floral, fresh, and a bit sweet. Unfortunately, the combination comes across as artificial. "Daisy Wild" doesn't impose itself, remaining...

Colorful plastic flowers as a cap, I was skeptical during the test... But the jasmine works well for me, pushing all thoughts of dull, chaste daisies to the back. It has a green note plus a hint of clean sweat. And then something that reminds me of the smell of a cat's paws. The floral-fresh jasmine and a bit of rainwater aquatic keep everything on the clean side; I find it very wearable and I'm somewhat tempted by this creation.

edit.: Now I've bought it as a late summer scent; I perceive the banana blossom more as a green sweet fruit note in the heat, which I also like very much, I've never smelled anything like it before. In the dry down, a hint of aquatic remains with the other notes in the background, so it stays fresh.
Sillage is rather weak, so not intrusive. The bottle is refillable, which comforts me about the plastic flowers that, unlike green-floral-sweet scents, do not fit my usual preferences.

When I sprayed the fragrance, it smelled so fruity, juicy, and almost real, truly tempting enough to bite into a fruit. I just couldn't quite pinpoint which fruit it was, yet I felt like I was on the verge of figuring it out. Melon? Lychee?
But then, unfortunately, a note emerged that unpleasantly smelled like old floral water.
At home, I was very surprised to see that there is neither a zesty fruit nor a stinky flower in the notes. Banana blossom has never come across my path before, and I would really like to know if this is responsible for the described scent impressions. It must be so, as it is the top note; at the same time, the only flower in it - jasmine - is one I usually like very much.
The "stinky floral note" unfortunately lingers for a while, making the fragrance not suitable for me. After over an hour, it finally fades away, and it smells deliciously warm, floral, and sweet, almost reminding me of "Daisy Love Eau So Sweet".
From there, the fragrance is and remains pleasant, ending with very soft, almost chocolaty sandalwood and vetiver notes.

review_title: The association ruins the scent for me...
review_content: I am really into beautiful bottles, and those from Marc Jacobs have always appealed to me. Today I tested Daisy Wild, and I will first describe the scent itself: I find it really well "composed" and extraordinary. Unfortunately, I haven't been able to test much from MJ yet, but compared to most other designers, this one stands out. I like the banana blossom that smells...

I am disturbed, with a green bottle you expect ...something fresh... let’s be honest. I have already smelled/tested several fragrances with banana or green banana leaf and thought Banana Bliss was an artificial filler. This one is somehow buttery, creamy, like a Banana Split with double cream, and after 10 minutes it has a burnt plastic note, as if...

After one second it fulfilled my nose with spicy tobacco notes but i can also strongely smell the pepper and vanilla. This is something i really didnt expected from van cleef. All of there other perfumes are so heaven like standard good smelling scent for everyone but this one is the complete opposite. Strong notes, dirty smell, spicy and strong. The combination of the notes remind me of spicebomb fragrance without the cinnamon notes but i hate them, so i would 100 % choose this. The price is already down and almost reaches the 100$ limit. I think the price is fair for this type of perfumes.After a few minutes the vanilla more and more breaks through the other notes but is still in the backround because the pepper and tobacco are overwhelming. This reminds me of old men who smoke expensive cigars on the evenings and then, when they go back inside their house the smell of the cigar combines with the smell of their old wooden cabinets.

What a disappointment!
This was a blind purchase based solely on the fragrance notes provided by the site.
I'm going to be brutally honest, even if it might offend some!

Upon the first spray, I was hit with a very dense, powerful, and pungent amber note (it smells overwhelmingly of Ambroxan!). It was an assault on my senses! This note was so overpowering that it completely ruined the experience for me.
As for the rest of the scent's evolution? Ugh! Disappointing!
I detected a hyper-concentrated Myrrh resin, which gave off an olfactory impression somewhere between rubber and leather.

There was nothing syrupy or sweet about this fragrance.

There was no hint of Oud wood! But it felt as if it was there! It reminded me of the Oud found in poorly crafted fragrances - chemical and invasive!
The vanilla tobacco was overdone and lacked finesse!
I found it to be irritating and aggressive. It was like an olfactory punch... A bulldozer!

In the same vein, I would place:
Ameer Al Oudh Intense Oud by Lattafa Perfumes.

review_title: Holy Father Figure on the Motorcycle
review_content:
A tension-filled contradiction that simply works too well.

One takes:

- a hardened biker who has left his wild days behind
- a somewhat unconventional pastor
- a kind, caring father

These three types were best friends in childhood. Their lives have developed in completely different ways, and now, after many years, they are finally together again. Drinking, laughing, smoking, telling stories from yesterday, the day before yesterday, and today, and it is just like it is with really good friendships: as if not a day has passed. Sometimes the laughter quiets down, and there is also room for silence. Never uncomfortable. Eloquent silence.

In this circle of trust, closeness, and cozy friendship, one is simply welcomed by Encens Precieux and joins in as if it were the most natural thing in the world.

The opening: immediately strong peppery notes, with a sweet leatheriness. Warm, pleasant - with incense and tobacco as accompanying spicy notes in the background, and amber, myrrh, and vanilla for comfort. Not directly intrusive, but captivating.

Over time, the pepperiness diminishes somewhat, creating more space for the sweetness. The spiciness remains. Only towards the end does Encens Precieux softly exhale sweet-tobacco notes and bids farewell on quiet feet.

It can actually be worn all year round - except in summer. Then it’s better to wear it only late in the evening, otherwise it becomes too much.

Longevity and sillage are somewhat better than what is usually expected from Van Cleef & Arpels and quite decent. Not a bad powerhouse, but certainly not weak either. For me: just right.

The bottle: simple, elegant, timeless. Not an eye-catcher or a showcase of glassblowing.

Price-wise: the RRP is currently (end of 2024) €165, if I remember correctly. To be honest, that wouldn't be too expensive for a soul fragrance like this. Street price: €125. Still not a bargain - and worth every cent.
Conclusion: some fragrances hit you immediately upon spraying. Encens Precieux is not such a companion. Not a loudmouth, not a wallflower. It rests in itself and welcomes you with calm, cozy warmth, without lulling you to sleep. You feel at home right away and experience something better than happiness: contentment.

review_title: Van Cleef & Arpels typically high quality, but the DNA is not for every nose
review_content:
Encens Précieux is a fragrance that perfectly fits the niche theme, even though the brand Van Cleef & Arpels is strictly speaking a designer house.

Here you get a relatively strong leather, nicely spicy and especially peppery wrapped.
It also has a good portion of incense and myrrh.

Especially in the opening, it even comes across as quite animalistic, and that is not pleasant for every nose.
Presumably, classic designer noses will definitely not like this fragrance, just like people who always want something very pleasing. Encens Précieux certainly knows how to provoke.

The start is, as mentioned, quite animalistic, strong, spicy, peppery, and leathery. After a few minutes, the animalistic side recedes a bit, the leather is still very present, and the pepper becomes more intense.

As the fragrance settles more and more, it becomes gradually a bit "quieter." The leather does not seem as strong anymore, the peppery elements are still very present but more pleasing. Additionally, a bit of tobacco comes in, along with some vanilla. The incense also becomes quite pleasant in this phase.

The spicy impression continues, but with the vanilla and amber, it even becomes almost creamy.
In other words, towards the end, a really subtle sweetness comes into play.
Woody elements are also still present.

All in all, a well-made fragrance, as I expect from Van Cleef & Arpels.
Nevertheless, this scent is not for everyone, due to its slightly animalistic traits.
It simply has edges and corners, which also makes it stand out.

This is a well-mixed blend of jammy fruits that are richly blended to give a vintage feel to a perfume that's really not that old. If you didn't know the name or year of this perfume you would swear you were smelling a vintage perfume from decades ago. It's full-bodied, thick and lays on a bed of deep woods.
It's a sticky floral, almost narcotic with its sweetness. Decadence is sensual, old-school and more sophisticated than one would expect for its price. Some might call this a stuffy type of perfume, and that's ok. It's just not their style. It's not for everyone. That's what makes perfumes fun for all of us.
Decadence is long-lasting and strong, better-suited for nights. If you're looking for a strong perfume that brings you back to vintages, this might be one that's affordable. It's like walking down a lush garden path, inhaling every bouquet you can, with an outdoor kitchen not far away.
My bottle and box are marked "Parfums International" and look like the Prince Matchabelli bottle, so I'm actually not sure which one I own. I can post my review in both sections until someone can advise.

I already know two fragrances from the "Scent Prince" (and I have them too):
"Wind Song", a spicy-floral carnation scent, and...
"Cachet", a thick, heavy 80s oakmoss Chypre "board".
And now a third, wonderful fragrance:
"Decadence", also an 80s Chypre, but one of the spicy-floral kind.
With great longevity and equally impressive sillage.
The scent starts off quite harmlessly with citrus, peach, and a bit of "leaf green". Just as if it couldn't "cloud the waters" and drifts along completely insignificantly.
BUT THAT IS DECEPTIVE!!!
The little rascal (I have a mini) soon unexpectedly lets a floral garden bloom that truly has depth.
Garden carnations, very spicy, mingle with lily of the valley, where leaves and stems have been included in the distillation.
Roses, still armed with thorns on their branches, battle with ylang-ylang and jasmine for dominance, while iris, dark purple, sprinkles its powder over the squabblers and calls for harmony.
Which eventually does come....
Only much later in the foreground, but long before already latent and subtly present:
Woods, "earth", and moss. The "foundation" that makes a Chypre. Wonderful sandalwood contributes its own unique touch. Sweet and bitter at the same time, it could be a standalone perfume and enhances the EdP even further.
It's a shame that this "prince's jewel" is now almost impossible to find.
Quite different from "Cachet" and "Wind Song", but with the typical "Matchabelli" signature.
WUUUNNNSCHLIIISTEEEE!!!!

I already own and love the EDP of Chloe, but my obsession with roses had me at hello with CHLOE ROSES DE CHLOE. I had to see if there were enough differences between the two to warrant a purchase. The verdict:

CHLOE ROSES dries down to smell like a completely different fragrance than CHLOE. This flanker isn't trying to be her older sister. She's her own woman.

That said, while CHLOE dries down to smell of green melon and water (a la Issey Miyake), CHLOE ROSES dries down to a pale pink cone of cotton candy. So if you like HANAE MORI and the sweet dry down there, you'll also enjoy the light pink air of CHLOE ROSES (which is nothing like Bvlgari Essense of Roses).

I won't be purchasing because I don't need another sugar sand rimmed scent.

review_title: my first independent step into becoming a fraghead...
review_content:
my mom was into fragrances, but I would always borrow hers. I had never owned a fragrance myself or chosen it by trial and error. this perfume marks me developing a taste and getting it myself...

it's funny, the bottle I have will always be something special and nostalgic about it. I was rebellious and was trying out shoplifting for the first time, and this was the second thing I ever stole, from a Macy's I believe. so the bottle is a tester bottle that looks a little worse for the wear, but it was like 80% full.

the scent is slightly on the soapy side, but it's a really nice non-committal fragrance for me. great for layering with other fragrances as this is basically a lot of light, airy notes. I like to pair this with Dusita's Oudh Infini for added girlishness and sophistication.

it does tend to fade on skin super quick (almost immediately even), but on fabrics it can last a while.

Pure rose here. If you are looking for a true rose scent, this one is for you. It opens with tartness, perhaps a citrus, but after only minutes transforms into a blossoming rose. It’s quite lovely and not synthetic smelling.
It does soften over time, but the rose is always right there with you. Decent sillage and longevity.
It’s a far cry better than the Tom Ford Rose Prick I bought last month and a lot less expensive.
Again, if you want real rose, look no further than Roses de Chloe.

review_title: This is a date night in a bottle.
review_content:
It begins with a youthful excitement (the bergamot), as you put on your dress and makeup, getting ready for the date you've been looking forward to. The citrus perks you up as your date picks you up and takes you downtown.
And as the evening really begins, the roses bloom. You smell of love and romance. You raise your arms to touch your partner across the table, and roses breathe with your movement.
And finally, towards the end, everything settles down into a comforting rosy musk, and you feel, above all, like a woman in love.

This was one of the first perfumes I ever got myself (in travel spray format). I was big into fresh florals back then, and this one had just been released. Definitely a youthful take on rose, bright and fresh, not at all powdery. The lasting power wasn't great, and if I remember, that's why I never ended up buying a full bottle. Which turned out to be a good thing, because I outgrew this scent pretty quickly and never ended up finishing the travel spray I bought. Nevertheless, I still appreciate it to this day as my introduction to perfume.

The bergamot top note is very welcome, but quickly fades to leave behind a rather immature fragrance. I love simpler compositions, but I also want to be able to discern the notes. At least one in the top, middle and base. Once the bergamot goes you're left with a sweet, non-descript floral. It's very much like Dahlia & Vines , but perhaps just a tiny bit better in...

I love roses, especially the scent of a damask rose (my dad grows a bush in his garden). This scent is like the essence of that rose scent, soft and pleasant. I would even call it the Lacroix of rose scents. I'm actually not sure what those other notes are for, because this is just rose all the way for me. Unfortunately, it doesn't last very long at all. I wonder if it's because I have a travel-sized rollerball of it, but this is nice while it lasts.

I got to know Roses de Chloe as the third fragrance in the rose series from Chloe, after L`Eau de Chloe and Chloe EdP. In the last few months, I have worn it quite often, so I am now ready to share my thoughts. I tend to take a long time before I write a comment about a fragrance. I really like Roses de Chloe. It is an intensely rosy scent with the rose as the main actor, as...

The (always) cold winter is almost over. Okay, the next few days are supposed to be a bit colder according to the weather report, but these cool and somewhat gloomy days will soon be a thing of the past. But honestly, believe me :D Already, the first rays of sunshine are breaking through the cloud cover (occasionally), which even feel warming. Soon, you'll hear more little...

In my search for a rose fragrance, Stella and Chloe were my top contenders. Since the reformulated Stella has often been criticized here for its short longevity, I chose Chloe. A perfect hit.
Roses is a very authentic, slightly sweet rose. I imagine a rose garden full of pink roses, next to an open jar of rose jam. It is fresh, but not unpleasantly fabric softener fresh. That’s how I perceive the original Chloe. It is also very youthful. Not a dusty rose, but a lively, spirited rose.
Fresh, floral scents are not exactly known for their outstanding longevity. This one lasts exceptionally long on me. After 6 hours, I am still surrounded by a slightly sweet, authentic rose. And that’s considering my skin tends to absorb perfume. I don’t want to be without it anymore.
Unfortunately, it is no longer listed on the Chloe website. I fear the worst, quickly got a backup.

My elementary school teacher was married to a Bulgarian, and therefore she often distributed small wooden bottles of Bulgarian rose water instead of little bees. As far as I remember (and I remember quite well, because my sample ended up on the carpet in my childhood room and then filled the entire room for a very long time, regardless of my mother's draft ventilation), it was...

review_title: Roses, Roses, Roses, the little ones
review_content: Yes, it really has something. I sprayed it on today and at first I really missed the Chloé, which didn’t come back, but roses came, more and more roses, and somehow they are quite beautiful. This rosy scent has already lasted 6 hours on me. I can really almost only smell roses, but I already mentioned that. And again, a rose is never just a rose; it is always something...

review_title: From Turquoise to Saturn and Back Again...
review_content: takes about 5 minutes in Wiesbaden. But that was enough for me not to buy the fragrance... But let's start from the beginning: I was looking for a rose scent. Yes, there are many. The original Chloe is one of my signature scents. However, I was searching for a creamy-soft, slightly sweet rose fragrance. Something different. So off to the city to test various rose fragrances...

review_title: For the Sleeping Beauty in Me!
review_content: I love the scent of real roses; unfortunately, it is rare and often overshadowed by sweet or heavy counterparts. This is not the case here at all; this is a clear, fresh, initially green rose fragrance. After a while, it becomes creamy and lasts quite long on the skin for an EdT. I tested it once and I am truly in love; this could become my new everyday scent, one that stays...

I stumbled upon Roses de Chloe last year by chance while searching for a floral summer fragrance. I quite like the scent itself, but I feel it lacks a bit of spice and depth. Roses de Chloe is a fresh-sweet pink spring and summer fragrance. Chloe starts off with a zesty freshness from bergamot, shortly followed by magnolia, which gives the scent a "shower gel" feeling. The...

...this term immediately came to my mind after spraying it on my skin. I associate it with the finest rose softness, which could hardly be more accurate for this fragrance. I perceive the bergamot top note only very subtly on its own, but it contributes to the immediately noticeable brightness of this scent. The rose is present right away, a completely natural light pink...

What did the saleswoman put in my bag yesterday with my fragrance purchase? Roses de Chloe. She showed a sure hand, because I love rose scents! And this one is wonderfully done. A clear, unadulterated rose scent, accompanied by delicate magnolia. And the rose is captured in its entirety - with its leaves and stems. It’s more of a rose bush than a single...

review_title: Rose is a rose is a rose is a rose
review_content:
This was already recognized over 100 years ago by the American poet Gertrude Stein.

And it describes exactly what this fragrance evokes in me:
I lose myself in roses, red-radiant, pink-floating, yellow-vibrating, white-glowing, orange-warming, and they all scent in harmony in this perfume.
A rose intoxication, enchanting, tender, intense. Like entranced, I get caught up in the fragrance, wanting to sing with Knef in the rain of roses, lie in a bed full of roses as sung by Bon Jovi, compose poetry with Hölderlin “To the Rose”...

And above all, the Damask rose scents, gently supported by the magnolia. A minimalist touch of bergamot brings a bit of freshness to the abundance of floral fragrance, but without minimizing, restricting, or dominating the rose. The rose remains, radiantly central, fragrant.
Amber and musk bring depth and softness, but only to carry the rose within.
All the ingredients of the fragrance pyramid serve only to honor the rose, to roll out the rose-red carpet for her, to place the little crown upon her head.

And I fully agree with Gertrude Stein:
Rose is a rose is a rose is a rose.

review_title: Is it sad that there are no men's fragrances from Chloe?
review_content: Today was Chloe day. A brand that I have unfortunately hardly had the chance to engage with, which is certainly also due to the fact that there is not a single men's fragrance among the similarly presented bottles. Sure, the Eau de... scents are quite unisex, but officially the hairy gender seems olfactorily neglected here. Is that bad? Do I want a Chloettus? Today I...

On my balcony, the fragrant roses have bloomed. I have pink, white, and yellow roses, but I particularly like the red ones. Their scent is elegantly cool and soft, the petals velvety, and the green leaves give it a freshness. A perfect fragrance that I would love to wear! So I set out on a search - and found Roses de Chloé! The typical Chloé signature note is caressed by...

First of all, those who like roses will definitely be well served by this fragrance. I believe that if someone else wore it, I would like it more than on myself. The rose completely overwhelms you. I also smell something biting, scratchy in the opening. When that fades, the scent - who would have thought - smells like rose ;)
The longevity is very good. I can still smell it after a night’s sleep. Then the bedspread also smells of it, and I even noticed a bit of the scent after showering. A great fragrance for rose lovers, but unfortunately, it's too much for me!

~ Inspiration ~ After I really liked "Chloé" but didn't care for "Love, Chloé," today it was time for "Roses de Chloé." I received a sample of it during my last souk, otherwise I probably wouldn't have tested it, as I don't usually like rose fragrances that much. Bottle ~ Very charming. What immediately catches the eye is the large pink bow. The bottle is also ribbed,...

review_title: For You, It Shall Rain Pink Roses
review_content: Roses, pink, a pink rose shower.. Help.. everywhere is PINK.....The roses are pink, the meadow is dotted in pinkish-green.. even the bees are striped pink and black.....pink raindrops fall on the pink little dress of the rosy-cheeked princesses with pink ribbons in their hair, who dance the rose suite in their rosy ballet slippers.....Pink rose thorns do not accept even a hint...

I already have Chloe-Chloe EDP, but I absolutely had to test Roses de Chloe, just to test it, because rose scents are currently my target. About the scent: delicate pink petals and the fragrance of a large, full, sweet garden rose. I perceive this scent as a pure rose scent. Unfortunately, I can’t make out anything other than sweet roses. Neither the freshness of bergamot...

As a Chloé fan, I had to take a closer look at this new variant - I already own the EdP and L'Eau, both of which are very beautiful fragrances. L'Eau is an optimal summer scent, lightly soapy and citrusy; the EdP is suitable for all seasons, a unique, elegant, delicate, fresh-floral fragrance with a high recognition value. The bottles are all top-notch, and I was recently...

It glows, shimmers in the deepest dark red, sweeping all thoughts away. Close to the horizon, the red embers spread out and creep ever closer. Shimmering Inferno in the style of Labdanum Symphony. In the background, Mozart's Requiem plays softly. One could sink into this fragrance with head and soul.

No hellish aspects. No, rather it is a hot, smoky roll, sprinkled with a dense sweetness. Resinous contrasts spread here, with an immense sweet force that burrows deep into the skin. On the edge, a shallow, spicy scent, at the heart a tonka bean that packs a punch. Cognac and honey lubricate, like oil, the engine of the red sky. Emerging dark clouds bring a bit of smoke, spice with them. The scent is incredibly dense and made for lovers of resinous fragrances. Labdanum Symphony is undisturbed by anything or anyone. It has a calm demeanor. It wants to embrace everyone with its initially wild, yet undeniably passionate nature. Resinous sweetness meets something luscious here. Paired with smoky and spicy aspects. There’s no fussing around, no rushing. The scent is just as it presents itself from the beginning, only it becomes warmer. There are no unpleasant surprises here.

And so the inferno rolls on, like the setting sun on the vast horizon, with an immensely long breath and presents itself in an extremely intimate way.

Many thanks to the dear @Kokusai, who not only generously gifted me this but has also enriched my experience.

A hit, right on target!

I received this fragrance for the first time in a generous sample size from my friend, and when I found out that it was being discontinued, I was overwhelmed with concern and bought another 50ml bottle:
Labdanum Symphonie impresses me as a scent for cold days with an incredible richness of heavy resins, although I must admit that I don't detect the cannabis scent as I remember it from my student days. The honey-like sweetness of the labdanum, frankincense, and others is all the more convincing. I have a weakness for this type of resinous, incense-like fragrances. What stands out about this one is its incredible longevity. I know few fragrances in this category that surpass the longevity of, for example, Ambra Aurea by Profumum Roma, but this one belongs to that group: sprayed on in the morning and slipping into bed in the evening, you are still enveloped by the warmth of this scent. It is not something I would wear on warm summer days, but from autumn to spring, it is excellent as a feel-good and cozy fragrance.

In my exploration of incense and resinous scents, it has found a place as one of the fragrances that is less challenging; it doesn’t have that green note like Interlude Man or the slightly smoky quality of Ambra Aurea - and it is not sacred either. And this is my justification for why I had to indulge my FOMO (fear of missing out) once again and am glad to wear this scent symphony on cold days for the next few years.

Labdanum Symphony - for me, a great love at first sight. It started with a small fragrance sample (before that, I knew nothing of my passion for labdanum), which I sprayed on and was immediately captivated by the sweet darkness of this scent. I had to breathe it in deeply again and again, almost inhaling it, because I found it incredibly fascinating. I would like to illustrate my olfactory impression more vividly with passages from this song by ASP, which reflects the driving, bittersweet melancholy in my perception very well:

From the depths it rose
The flow of melodies
A song like I had never heard before
The music a gentle pull
And I wanted to kneel down

In the depths, in the depths they sang

Listening, I stood at the abyss
And it drew me to the edge
I didn’t know what gave them such great power
This song that commanded me
And left me no choice

In the depths, in the depths they sang

And now I am almost at the goal
A high feeling overtakes me
A strong, never-before-known euphoria
Oh, melody, I am almost there
So close to your origin

In the depths, in the depths they sing

Whoever heard them sing
Knows how
Longing sounds
And I will never forget this melody
I don’t know what is happening to me
Tell me, where are you drawing me
Into the depths, into the depths they sing

Now, away from the emotional level and on to: What is the scent like?

First of all, it is STRONG, right from the first moment. You spray it on, and it captures you with strong resinous arms and wrestles you to the ground with sweet waves of vanilla and tonka. You have to like it, and you can almost only "surrender." So caught and held by honey-sweet magic, in your now amber-colored shackles, you experience how the scent reveals its dark, animalistic side in the form of amber and cannabis after about 10 minutes - but just enough of it that you still find this "dark wickedness" fascinating and alluring. And then you remain trapped in this wonderful dark amber depth - for this scent takes complete possession of you, for many hours (at least 10), and it is always very present by your side (my surroundings perceive it as an extremely pleasant fragrance - in other words, you stand out with it)

For me, one of the scents to which I would like to give a 10 in every respect - it has completely enchanted me. With it, I love to dive again and again into a dark, warm bittersweet world that fascinates but also triggers tingling shivers of fear.

review_title: Score for Amber, Boat, and Echo Sounder
review_content:
Bass clef. A lake of balsamic amber, deeper than the Toplitz and arcane as well. Perhaps like a fjord. In slow motion, the waves of bitter honey wander, with driftwood inside, dry as tobacco, the old dark kind that only whales can possess. Lento.
A boat. Transparent and submersible. I can see the dirt swimming beneath the dark brown balsam surface through the wall, it glimmers sweetly and herbaceous. Cannabis leaves might fit in. They glow green with the copal grains, reflecting the waves of the echo sounder back into higher, brighter clouds, while the remaining tones resonate deeper.
Diving. Warm flickering of smoking myrrh in medically brown glowing layers of benzoin. Some earth flows by. Echo sounder deceives with tonka beans and wave-like vanilla surfaces. With the red roasting pearls of swirling incense, the colors dissolve into a wistful harmony. Friction. Tom Waits sings Jesus Blood at the bottom of the lake. It is dark there. Warm. Wonderful. For many, many hours.

(With thanks to Shaking)

review_title: A Summer Day's Idyl with the Sound of the Sea in the Background
review_content:
Warm summer rain showers and cool sea mist wash away the sunscreen, the skin smells like freshly showered. The sun brightens the sky again, clear raindrops glisten on the lush peony blossoms in the garden, the laundry on the line takes on its lovely-sensual aroma. The lady picks a few blackberries from the hedge, then puts on her simple white linen dress and hops on her bike to ride to the beach. Or maybe to the little town? Her good mood is contagious, she beams with the sun in a competition, and the warm wind plays in her long, flowing hair. Despite the many fruits and flowers, the gently rustling sea behind the dunes accompanies her the whole time.
For me, this scent is like an invitation to go to the idyllic holiday home with blue shutters
and a large romantic garden (but somewhere in the south, not in the north), where one has already spent some relaxed and sunlit holiday days and to which one always likes to return.
Not a scent to wear daily. But gladly, when the longing for the sea, for light, and for a flower garden in the south grips you and you just can't get away.

review_title: short visit to the North Sea
review_content:
sprayed on the skin, the perfume unfolds the direct feeling of being by the sea. Unfortunately, the aquatic notes fade after about an hour, and what remains of Eau de Luxe smells very similar to the fragrances Mustang - Sport, Bogner men classic.
.............................................................................................................................................................................

I bought Eau de Luxe in a set with a deodorant blind, as I generally like Vanderbilt.
And I was not disappointed here either.
It is light like a refreshing breeze, but not thin and watery.
The pear and jasmine harmonize wonderfully with each other.
It also has an aquatic note that reminds me of afternoons in a beach chair, where you just sit there, listening to the surf and the seagulls, and feeling content.
The deodorant complements the Eau beautifully as well. And it doesn't sting on the skin.
I have already gifted the set multiple times, and all recipients were very pleased with it.
A fragrance for every day - and not just for summer temperatures.

A scent like a whisper.

This perfume has been with me for a very long time. At one point, it was hard to find and somehow disappeared from the scene and my memory,
until I rediscovered it in an inconspicuous shop. It was even a special offer, a real bargain.

Now to the scent.
I don't know why, but every time I wear this fragrance, I feel light and buoyant. In my opinion, it is an absolute spring/summer scent for warm days.

It is not too fresh, slightly floral, not sweet. Like a gentle breeze in summer when you feel too warm.
It is not loud, but also not silent; it sings rather than speaks.

The longevity is good despite the lightness, and the bottle is kept beautifully simple. I would say the perfume is suitable for all age groups; it always fits.

With the musk in the base and jasmine and lily of the valley in the heart, the scent has a certain latent depth, which also makes it suitable for evening wear. Otherwise, it is more suitable for daytime.

A wonderful scent for dreaming.

review_title: I Don't Want That Much Power
review_content:
Lignum Vitae (life wood) is the Latin (botanical) term for guaiac wood, and Forte means strong. I don't find the guaiac in Lignum Vitae Forte that strong at all. But it's definitely there. Woody is Lignum Vitae Forte, without a doubt. It also feels natural. I couldn't detect leather, and since I don't like leather, I don't miss it either. At the point of application, the scent was simply too strong for my olfactory senses (that's where the Forte comes in). It started to shimmer, and I quickly pulled my nose away. In the aura, however, it was okay. The aura reached several meters. In times of Corona, this is ideal, as you can be perceived from meters away against the wind. Even at the far end of the ballroom, where people now stand two meters apart, or if only two people are allowed per ballroom unless they live together, then they have to dance two meters apart.

The scent itself didn't strike me as particularly special, meaning that it is a woody oriental, and there seem to be as many of those as there is sand on the beach (Parfumo spoils me). There is no oud in this one! That's a plus point.

One of the fragrance notes unfortunately remains almost forever on the clothing wherever it has been touched with a homeopathic amount of Lignum Vitae Forte. Without seeing the pyramid, the base (and the clothing scent) smelled fruity and somewhat like clove oil. I don't know if it's spikenard oil or nagarmotha or both. I had to wash everything today. Not because it smells bad, but because it smells at all. My wrist still smells of Lignum Vitae Forte in the evening because my arm was briefly in the sleeve of the dress I wore yesterday. For other people, the strong sillage and long-lastingness would probably be a reason to rate the perfume higher. The price-performance ratio does increase, but I don't want that much power.

In my opinion, Lignum Vitae Forte is more suitable for the colder season. The scent is rather, but not exclusively, masculine. It is obvious when you can wear Lignum Vitae Forte: when you are in quarantine. In times of plague, cholera, Corona. You can drip it into your pestilential beak, and then you definitely won't smell the terrible odors of the world anymore. Thus, it is also suitable for pathologists. I've already mentioned the lonely ballroom above. You can use it to mark a trail that others are supposed to sniff out. So, for example, in a scavenger hunt (which has nothing to do with schnitzels). If you want to scent a room with it, you can simply rub against the walls or quickly run through the room. Lignum Vitae Forte is definitely useful if you are looking for the exit of a labyrinth or have gotten lost in the woods; where it smells of Lignum Vitae Forte, you must have been there. Maybe the day before or two days ago, but at some point, you were there.

I met the sympathetic perfumer Sven Pritzkoleit, who taught himself the art of fragrance as an experienced pharmacist, a few years ago at a perfume fair in Düsseldorf. He presented his current creations under his own label SP-Parfums and kindly gave me some samples of his work.

Among them was Lignum Vitae Forte, which I would loosely translate as "Random Life in Wood" or "Chance in the Wood of Life," thanks to Google, as a non-Latin speaker. Feel free to correct me on that.

What cannot be corrected is the first impression upon spraying, as Lignum Vitae Forte comes across as extremely animalistic to woody, as if a civet and a beaver had marked their territory on a tree together. This might also be due to the nagarmotha - an essential oil derived from the roots of the Indian nut grass, a type of cypress, which bears a resemblance to agarwood.

A few minutes later, the scent becomes a bit calmer, but it still remains relatively unwieldy or somewhat unrefined and raw. Accordingly, it takes about 30 minutes for it to feel softer and more relaxed. Then you perceive this slightly animalistic leather note, a lot of spikenard oil, and woody to musky notes, overshadowed by a hefty dose of earthy patchouli. And this lasts for a really long time...

Deep within, there are delicate green and soapy hints that seemingly give the creation a kind of corset. Only after a few hours do you get the feeling that the scent has found some semblance of calm and feels more or less somewhat smooth. But even this phase will still be too rough for many - but it won't get any softer.

In Lignum Vitae Forte, there is indeed life in the wood, although it reminds more of woodlice, beetles, and other critters, and less of bees, butterflies, or unicorns. Personally, I find it too rough and too rustic to feel comfortable with it. It has something of: I’m experimenting now, and this is the most wearable attempt.

So, for those who enjoy something provocative and bold that goes against the grain, this life wood is a good fit. Unfortunately, I personally miss a bit of the refined polish or the interesting twist.

Touché… The name evokes a nasty pressure in my stomach. Is it something about the scent? No!! I wasn’t outsmarted during fencing or a discussion, and I’m not sitting here - after a direct hit (Touché) - sulking in the corner.
What makes me feel queasy is the thought of a boy band of the same name that wreaked havoc in the early 2000s. Not only did the "pop titan" himself produce this musical disaster… but these "musicians" are more aptly described as a "quirk of nature." Just take a look at the pictures on Google…. or listen to one of their "songs."
Due to this association, I obviously don’t agree with the naming. Whether the people at LPDO have ever heard of this group is questionable. However, what this group definitely would have known is a little fragrance from Tiziana Terenzi.
Kirkè EXTRAIT DE PARFUM surely served as a godparent for this creation. But that doesn’t make the scent any worse…. and some even claim that TOUCHÉ is the better Kirke; but I won’t go that far…
The opening is sweet-fruity. A colorful tropical cocktail with all sorts of goodies from the fruit department. I can perceive berries and peach… the rest of the ingredients, however, vanish in a fragrant cloud of sugary vacation vibes. Touché is not a freshie, as it performs too sticky for me. Already in the top note, I notice the biggest difference from Kirke, which continues to linger for a long 8 hours until the finale. Most call it "synthetic"… I call it "positively piercing." OK… Kirke already experiences something like "hate" and is often labeled as "chemical club" or "hairspray scent." Now I could say: "Just look up the word synthetic on Wikipedia… then you’ll find something about 'Touché' too"… but I won’t say that…. And why not? Because I like "the thing." Do you know those plastic twist-and-drink bottles? As a child, I loved that stuff. On every school trip or even on a trip to Hagenbeck, those sugary fruit juices with a delightful formaldehyde aftertaste were always there! And that’s exactly what TOUCHE reminds me of; and that’s POSITIVE! The sillage is also good and gives the surroundings the childish impression of a visit to the Bäderland-Hamburg. I don’t feel this connection with Kirke.
Price: Here the equation applies: 10x Touché = 1x Kirke; and you can certainly notice the extreme price difference as the TT hit feels softer and more mature (WHAT!!!! …the Kirke bashers will now exclaim… “That’s just not possible”).
Conclusion: An inexpensive alternative from Italy with a gummy bear flair. Not for everyone… Still: I LIKE!

review_title: Morning Walk in the Dew-Drenched City Park
review_content:
Opening with a refined accord of greenish spicy notes (greenish bitter orange note; musk sage, slightly bitter galbanum, rose geranium) appearing somewhat herbaceous. A kind of mossy note, but without the familiar note of oakmoss, feels like it is drenched in dew, rounding it off.
Soon a greenish aromatic, woody accord (softly aromatic cedarwood and Douglas fir?) joins in, adding weight to the aforementioned "green." A warming amber accord serves as the base, corrected with a slight aromatic leathery, slightly herbaceous sharpness (leathery note?).

EdP longevity is good at 7-8 hours, after about 2 hours the good sillage retreats to a strong skin proximity and ends with the base after about 9-10 hours rather mild. Unisex as it is not too rough, not too spicy, not too heavy or darkly woody, and also no moss inferno.

I highly recommend testing it on the skin, as it takes a few minutes of the body's warmth to animate the scent and create the overall fragrance impression.

review_title: A secret recipe for black tea flavored fudge
review_content: What an incredibly weird and wonderful fragrance! This is a thick, rich, gooey tea-flavored fudge spiked with citrus and which reveals some evocative earthy elements that emerge as it dries. It’s as if a pot of strong tea was boiled down with a teacup full of brown sugar, a goodly glug of molasses, and slivers of bright yellow lemon peel, and then the mixture was stirred together with an entire box of sweet, nutty, whole wheat graham crackers crumbs and left on a counter to cool and set overnight. Fast forward about twenty years, and rather than the treat itself, this fragrance smells of its dusty, stained magazine clipping recipe card and which was secretly buried in the back garden by your eccentric relative because they didn’t want anyone to have their recipe after they died. This is why we dig it up and make the hell out of it and shout the recipe from the rooftops– because we don’t believe in gatekeeping the good stuff.

...it's not that bad after all! This scent has a distinctly berry-like quality to it, reminiscent of Armani's City Glam, somewhat herbal and perhaps a bit of an acquired taste for some noses. In the case of Sex and the City, however, there’s also a gourmand touch of caramel that starts off sugary and then spreads deliciously and slightly creamy, especially in the base. And a dose of almost overripe oranges/tangerines. I have nothing against herbal notes and I prefer the berry aspect much more than the orange one, but the combination of both isn’t really my thing, especially when both elements are so strongly present. I can't perceive ambroxan, and the woods could definitely stand out more for my taste, which would give the scent more edges and character. As it is, it remains quite agreeable.
Sex and the City is not a milestone in the art of perfumery, but it can easily compete with all the Katzenbergers, Playboys, Essences, and whatever else is available in the drugstore, and it makes for a nice companion on moderately warm days.

~ Inspiration ~
I received the perfume in a swap. I know the series "Sex and the City," but I was previously unaware of the perfume.

~ Bottle ~
The square shape with rounded edges is in transparent khaki. The name is printed in gold lettering on the front.

~ Scent ~
Sour-fruity.
Upon spraying, it is initially quite zesty with blood oranges, mandarins, passion fruit, and berries. After a few minutes, floral accords emerge in the form of gardenias, orange blossoms, and jasmine. With sandalwood, musk, amber, and a gentle caramel note, it finishes somewhat warm and woody.

~ Longevity ~
Unfortunately, it only lasts about 2-3 hours on my skin (a bit longer on clothing and hair). You can confidently spray it on.

~ Occasion ~
A 0815 everyday scent that can be worn anytime and anywhere.

~ Conclusion ~
Not so bad at all - I just expected a different scent direction based on the name. Additionally, it is a bit too synthetic and sour for me.

If anyone expects me to elaborate on the topic of sex: no way! I certainly won’t reveal anything about myself! I will never do that, even with the most sensual fragrances.
This scent is conveniently found in the "Sample on Tour" travel package, and I randomly fished it out of the collection because the label was so faint that I had to use a magnifying glass and LED light to decipher the name. So I quickly applied it, called it up, and before the scent evaporates again, I’ll describe it quickly.
"Sex sells" - that is the unmistakable intention behind this perfume name.
Because such an inexpensive little bottle can be afforded by any teenager, allowing them to gain recognition in their peer group, and perhaps provoke a few prudish adults.
But otherwise, this is a perfectly normal boring cheap scent. Harmless!
"SatC" starts fruity, but not too sweet, quite zesty. Not even with a "red berry note" does it provoke me.
Flowers, if they are even perceptible, are muddled by synthetic sandalwood. Unfortunately, there are no animalistic, carrion-like O-flowers or even jasmine clusters that evoke any associations or feelings of desire, of any kind, e.g., the desire to get worked up over such stinky odors. Not happening! No chance.
Gardenia? Pah! You have to knit that yourself if you want to have at least a visual idea of it - or something like that.
For a little while, "SatC" is somewhat sharp and spicy, but before it could become interesting, it has already evaporated again. Ambroxan, which contributes to the longevity of fragrances, is already present, though not too strong. There are also fleeting moments with delicious caramel notes. It disappears faster than I can type. And I can type quickly.
Then, in the imagined dull wide city escapes, there remains a stale smell of relatively sour synthetic gummy candy, which, thanks to Ambroxan, will hardly be removable in the shower, according to my experience.
And with that, everything has been said about "Sex and the City."

This fragrance is nicely fresh and spicy, with sage and cedarwood - really clear and invigorating, but not in an annoying way. I think it suits both women and men, a true all-rounder.

It doesn't last forever, just a few hours, then it's gone. But for the price, that's totally acceptable. The bottle looks modern and feels good in the hand. Overall, I think you really get your money's worth here if you're looking for something fresh and lively.

Like A Virgin Limited Edition starts off fresh - floral, but also slightly sweet - creamy.

Our dear perfumer "Elbchen" provided me with her sample to test this fragrance, for which I would like to express my sincere thanks.

At first, one can detect a very intense, slightly sweet Moroccan orange blossom with its fresh - floral scent facet.

It is also the case that the orange blossom has slightly creamy attributes and reminds one of a pleasant summer body lotion.

At the same time, the orange blossom has something very refreshing - clear, subtly green, and it reminds me a little of neroli.

Like A Virgin Limited Edition does not have a real progression - it simply evolves over time.

As it develops, a lovely full Bourbon vanilla joins in and blends very pleasantly with the orange blossom, responsible for the beautifully balanced creamy nuance.

In the background, one can perceive something "matte," which I personally would not describe as milky; rather, it intensifies the creamy accent a bit without pushing the orange blossom too far into the background.

Like A Virgin Limited Edition is a fragrance that can be applied at any time of day without hesitation, as it will not disturb anyone, but it also does not stand out, as the scent feels very innocent to me personally.

And that can sometimes be quite pleasant :-)

Overall, the scent can be detected on my skin for 7 hours.

The sillage is designed from the beginning to be perceived at about half an arm's length, and this is maintained for 3 hours before it gradually diminishes until the scent finally fades away completely.

Masterpiece from my favourite perfumer – that is ESSENCES INSENSÉES.

Icing sugar peach lilac – the first breath, as your olfactory would be bombarded with shining, happy notes. If you take a deeper breath, it is easy to detect some biting spice, most probably the pepper (what else could be?). The fragrance is strong, confidently fresh, and 100% natural. The best face of niche – written here just to annoy GothicHeart :D

On the ground that I do not know all of the notes for sure, my nose makes easily mistakes, e.g. I feel chamomille. The scent of health. Bravo! This flower withers so fast... Dry and dead chamomille - The scent of sadness and too early farewell from life. If that was the intention, then bravo. If not, then: why the hell do I have to feel such grief at this stage???
...Especially after and before the beautiful springtime of head and base?

Till the end of heart ESSENCES INSENSÉES is the same with different body chemistries. The scent revives on lucky skin, and shows petals floating on clean water. Another drydown path is paved with herbs (mate?), is a bit sour, and shows in the last few hours a pretty, feminine and a bit boring mimosa. Where is the beeswax? In the head. Where is the vanille? In the head. Where is the violet? Mimosa kidnapped her to accompany her in the base.

As you can see, this fragrance involves me emotically very fast and deep, it is wonderful, and I can not keep myself away from the feelings that it makes arise. ESSENCES INSENSÉES is enough possessive to engage my thoughts for hours, nonetheless it is easy to wear. I like it. I love it. I hopelessly want to grab the volatile fineness of it.

Translating the name 1:1 from French raises the question of why?

Why are fragrances referred to as nonsensical essences... Has the manufacturer already supposedly enough sensible essences on the market and wants to market their formulations that have been languishing in storage under a slightly misleading name? No idea.

In any case, all 3 fragrances launched under this name so far are anything but nonsensical; each one is something special with a specific target audience. In 2014, mimosas were highlighted, in 2015 jasmine, and this year the rose has been put in a special light. The two fragrances from 2015 and 2016 are successful, but not to my taste.

The first formula from 2014 is different. However, one must have a certain preference for the quirky, tingling mimosa scent that runs like a red thread throughout the entire fragrance progression.

The fragrance starts green and slightly metallic; the violet blooms here only very briefly, as it does in nature, most of the time the small violet spring messengers are gone after a sunny day. The pink pepper also listed in the top note may be somewhere present, but is hardly noticeable.

The mimosa is already present in the top note and intensifies in the heart note. Anyone who has ever stood under a blooming mimosa tree in spring by the Mediterranean will immediately have this image in their mind.
The mimosa scent personally always reminds me a bit of blooming linden trees, which is why I would like to compare the fragrance a bit with Tilleul by D'Orsay. The beeswax note in the base further emphasizes this association. Farnesiana by Caron also caters to the same fragrance direction.

For me, the fragrance is the most successful of the "Nonsensical Essences"; it is subtle and not overwhelming, yet it has good longevity and a pleasant sillage. Essences Insensées 2014 is unisex, which I cannot attribute to the other two fragrances from 2015 and 2016, as they are more suited for women.

Anyone who likes green floral scents, especially mimosas, should definitely test this fragrance; I am not sure, but I believe it is no longer being produced, as it is very rarely found.

To start on a positive note, this fragrance smells like summer. Just like in the last few days, very very hot, many people at the outdoor pool lying on the grass and using plenty of sunscreen.
