It initially starts very green, like freshly cut grass, the lawn in the morning, still dewy and freshly mowed. I seem to miss the violet and pepper.

But after just a few minutes, the sun rises mercilessly hot, and something sweet joins in, gaining more and more dominance, very sweet-almondy, almost like baking aroma, while being powdery vanilla-like. Spicy not in the classical sense, rather radiating the spicy sweetness of acacia honey. Here I really wondered why I perceive no flowers at all, and did some research. Heliotropin, which is used in perfumery, is described as powdery, vanilla-like, and almond-like; it is said to have a relaxing and comforting effect. That describes it very well, as it is the scent profile that absolutely defines and dominates this fragrance for me. Heliotrope also means: turning towards the sun. I don't know how mimosa smells, but the scent essence from it is derived from a type of acacia, which is said to have honey-like facets. I am a little reconciled with my nose again.

And then...? Unfortunately, nothing more comes. Grass and marzipan continue hand in hand in the height of summer and eventually make themselves comfortable on a blanket. There they stay, turned towards the sun and very relaxed.

I hope more comments will come, as I cannot assess the longevity; as you all know, fragrances that you don't like are very hard to wash off, so I find it quite long-lasting... Anyone who loves sweet gourmand fragrances, vanilla crescents, and especially marzipan should definitely come and sniff this! It is not my scent at all; I am not a heliotrope lover, and the aroma seems a bit overdosed-artificial to me.
I will trade the remaining sample for a second comment! :-)

I heard how much this smelled like TDH and I found it for a great price so why not. It indeed does have some close resemblance to TDH, no grapefruit in the opening but a generic citrus blast with some decent pepper to wake you up. This settles into a woody dry down with a very light hint of leather to me.

Truthfully this is a quintessential English Baber Shop scent. If you enjoy shaving, or want to up your game and possibly learnt to enjoy shaving, D.R. Harris has a whole line in the Windsor collection including some of the best shave soap on the market. Great company that goes over looked outside of the wet shaving circles.

The man is a repeat offender.
As a fan of English Scents, it was only a matter of time before creations from D.R. Harris expanded my collection.

The fragrances and the predominantly "barber-related" grooming products from D.R. Harris originate from the apothecary house of Daniel Roteley Harris, who opened his business over 200 years ago in one of the most prestigious areas of London on St. James Street.

This unmistakable subtly English style of his high-quality products, combined with an affinity for tradition and his closeness to the English aristocracy, must have been the reason why this family business became the royal supplier to the English royal house just before World War II.

Windsor arrived with DHL in the morning post.
The perfect opportunity to test a new perfume fresh out of the shower.
In great anticipation, and because the first spray completely met my expectations - I did not expect such a strong sillage (lasting until after work at 9 PM) with this fragrance.
On my way to work, I was kindly approached by the baker, then the woman who locked her bike next to mine at the train station, my secretary, and several business contacts could not help but inform me how good and refreshingly clean I smelled.

Windsor begins, as expected, with a distinctly fresh citrus top note featuring sweet orange, lemon, and lime, which appears interwoven with neroli, evoking an incredible Mediterranean freshness for me.
In this opening, the otherwise often omnipresent bergamot is completely omitted, which certainly sets the fragrance apart from many déjà vu experiences.
After this harmonious citrus accord, warming and spicy notes join in, which must be due to the presence of nutmeg, clove, and black pepper, and subsequently complemented by vetiver, geranium, and very subtly leathery notes, which in their entirety are responsible for the already described sillage and long-lastingness, making Windsor not remain as close to the body as I initially experienced subjectively.

This fragrance is wonderfully traditionally English and, despite its age, is anything but a representative of the old man scent genre.
Like with Eau de Colognes, this perfume is conceptually another interpretation of an already known theme.
I simply cannot imagine my repertoire without Windsor anymore.

As a newcomer, I can't yet delve into the olfactory details of scents with precision, so I would like to share the impressions that come to mind as a user of the Windsor series.
I use the shaving soap, the aftershave splash, and the EdT discussed here.
The scent is slightly different in each case, which can certainly be attributed to the various concentrations and base ingredients.

Regarding the shaving soap:
Clean, warm, a bit leathery, a bit woody, slightly citrusy, powdery. It smells exactly like I imagine the scent of an old barbershop. It makes it unmistakably clear that you need to take your time now. It would also be a waste to scrape such rich, fragrant lather off your face just like that.

After the most thorough shave possible comes the moment of truth. Did you handle the razor or safety razor properly, or are you about to go through hell?

The aftershave:
Pepper. A bit of leather. But the pepper. That’s the main event here. You literally pepper your face. It calls out: “Let’s go! Saddle the horse! We want to achieve something great today!”
It’s dry, spicy, invigorating, wonderful.

Now comes the finish with 2 spritzes of the EdT, which presents itself unobtrusively and close to the body like a classic cologne, but is much more long-lasting.
Here, the clean barbershop freshness of the soap merges with the pepper and leather spice of the aftershave, resulting in an urban, herb-fresh scent for men who know what they want. You don’t find this on every corner. Even the base without musk feels wonderfully fresh and outstanding. It pairs perfectly with a dark blue suit, but with black shoes.
If I had to describe this scent in one word, I would say: new car.

review_title: The Rise of a Better World
review_content:
Delightfully fresh at the beginning, it's tempting to immerse oneself in this scent. I want to bathe in this fragrance and splash around in the bygone times that Windsor evokes.
Zionist has already described the perceptible nuances precisely, and I can only add: On the Titanic, I would have noticed this scent on every fourth passenger, which is enormous, considering the fragrance was released into reality in the 2000s. This is how the year 1912 smelled beyond the blast furnaces and backyards. In this lies the impetus for the creation of Windsor, which overwhelms my olfactory system. The distance of catastrophic events, the rich, warm distinction, the maiden voyage of a Titanic from a port, in whose hinterland extensive, soot-covered workers' settlements remain, from whose hard labor the massive metal coffin fades into time.
Windsor does not smell of the absent sweat of the workers. Windsor smells soft and beautiful. The dream of a world that rises above misery and drifts in the ether between times.

Thanks to a lovely and generous sample of Yatagan, I had the pleasure of experiencing this fragrance. I hadn't read about the scent character beforehand and let myself be surprised.

Scent Development:
My first surprise was the opening: A very fresh, almost piercing citrus start. This aligned perfectly with my preference for fresh, hesperidic scents. Very quickly, a minty, penetratingly fresh note emerged, beautifully balanced with a slightly herbaceous-spicy touch, which I would describe as green/gray, creating a connection that lasted until the end of the fragrance. In between, the spicy notes were occasionally a bit more intense, but never dominant. Throughout the entire, very enduring development, I perceived a fresh-minty, slightly herbaceous-spicy scent.
I was surprised for the second time when I later found no mint in the scent description. I was firmly convinced and had already been pleased that there could be a more subdued version than in what I consider the overly minty “Guerlain homme l’eau.” I see - in a hopefully not too misleading memory of the Guerlain - a similarity between both fragrances and would say that one should try Windsor if the Guerlain is too strictly fresh. This minty impression surely comes from the vetiver-pepper combination. It vaguely reminds me in the fresh and light vetiver note of Tom Ford's “Grey Vetiver” EdT vetiver note, although the one in Windsor is even brighter and lighter. I can't say much about the comparison drawn by some of my predecessors to Terre d'Hermes, as I only remember it very vaguely. However, I believe that Terre seemed significantly sweeter-spicier to me. Before I make any further comparisons that would leave the experts shaking their heads, I better stop here :)

Longevity and Sillage:
Here I was surprised for the third time. I didn't expect it to last so long. I could still perceive it clearly and continuously after 13 hours. It clearly has EdP power for me. As for longevity! Thank goodness (for me personally), the sillage is more restrained. At first, it is slightly perceptible at a distance and gradually draws closer to the body, but is still noticeable to others in the immediate vicinity with movement.

Conclusion:
I was surprised three times, with the first two surprises resulting from previous, intentional lack of information, which naturally makes it not particularly difficult to be surprised :). However, the longevity was truly unexpected.
This fresh-minty, well-measured herbaceous-green-spicy English scent is classically British, straightforward, without frills, natural, and of high quality, leaving no wishes unfulfilled. From my perspective, despite its young year of creation, it feels slightly old-fashioned - I often have this association with vetiver scents - elegant and truly uplifting. Throughout the day, I had this pleasant and finely tuned, entirely unartificial feeling of freshness. Therefore, it is particularly well-suited for summer and also for transitional months. Personally, it is a tad too cold for me, still too strictly fresh to be a purchase option. But it is very close!

Great new scent from D. R. Harris, launched in 2012 along with the entire relevant line. Initially a bit flashy due to the citrus notes, Windsor quickly transitions into a lush coniferous forest that comes across as very fresh and very clear. The bestselling lines Arlington and Marlborough now have serious competition: I bet Windsor will stay in the lineup just as long (and that’s a long time)!
Admittedly, I don’t wear it in the evening or at the office, for those occasions there are of course other fragrances. But for an uncomplicated country outing, checking on things quickly in the stable, clay pigeon shooting, hunting, etc., Windsor has become a reliable companion for me. I honestly can’t think of an alternative for these occasions!

review_title: Elegance and Freshness in Everyday Life
review_content: My wife gifted me the fragrance Windsor by D.R. Harris because I already appreciate the aftershave very much. The scent begins with a refreshing, citrusy opening that immediately evokes Mediterranean freshness. This vibrant introduction seamlessly transitions into a minty, slightly spicy blend dominated by vetiver and pepper. This combination gives the fragrance a pleasant,...

Chocolate, cheese and precision watches… then I say Switzerland, the home of Toblerone, Emmental and Rolex. With this reputation one should think, that if the Swiss ever started making perfumes it would have to be a success.
On oLiente’s website you can read that the perfumes “are made with Swiss precision and passion”. And I admit that this first encounter with the Swiss brand is quite promising, actually. Vida is sweet and floral, to the gourmand side. Freshness comes from the lemon which keeps it from getting too cloying. In this, coconut works so well with the praliné. It lasts some five to eight hours which is quite good. Sillage is an arm’s length.
I must say, though, that I find it rather expensive. Almost €200 on the official website… I am not sure if that is worth it. Mostly because it has so many similarities with Juicy Couture’s Viva La Juicy! and I can get 30ml for around €25. I guess I will spend my money on some other fragrances instead. But keep going, Switzerland!
Year 2, 59/365

For me citrus/vanilla scents are my favourite scent profile, along with gourmands. I have tested so many! (You can see all my comparisons under my review of Unknown Pleasures) and have just purchased Dulcis in Fundo for summer (which I absolutely love!) Il Colore del Vento might just be the better option for high heat and the summer citrus vanilla I’ve been searching for! I also love the inspiration behind the scent, which made it instantly more appealing.

Il Colore del Vento (the colours of the wind) is a light gourmand. It opens with an airy mix of vanilla, bright citrus, a nice balance of sweetness, and a touch of coriander which gives the scent a cool, slightly limey freshness. As it dries down I get a light, sweet, candied fruit smell with hints of zingy ginger and a little spiciness. It isn’t overpowering or heavy in any way. I get zero coffee and no cardamom (thank god!) but there is a slight effervescent quality to the scent in the mid, which I guess is due to the champagne note. This would work all year round and in high heat. Very well done, very high quality, no nasty base notes and at quite a cheap price. Beautiful 10/10

In my opinion this isn’t similar to Lira, which is cakey, very sugary and a bit heavy. I also don’t find it similar to Akro Bake either, which I find has quite an ambroxan smelling dry down. To me this is closest to Chilli Candy Crush, but still very different and unique. The more I smell this, the more I love it.

Young rays of sunshine wake me up. Softly nestled on white linens, I remember the here and now in the hotel and the breakfast booked the day before. With hurried steps, I set off, out the door, press the elevator button, wait, traverse several floors and - Bing - the aluminum doors open and I enter the lobby.

Here begins my fragrance journey with Il Colore del Vento.

I cannot yet see the doors to the restaurant area, but at first, I notice the homemade refined water carafes, which are adorned with ginger and lemon. The impression lasts only briefly, as quickly the coffee notes and the scent of sweet dishes capture my attention.

I enter the room and find everything I had suspected to be true and also discover one or two guests who are already welcoming the day with champagne. The sweet notes continue to prevail and remain persistently present. It is not a single scent that can be perceived, but a constant shift of sweet dishes, warm honey notes, and finally very soft butter. It is like enjoying a warm pancake with maple syrup, but not dominated by sugar, rather in a sweet-buttery balance.

Excellent. Interesting notes with a strong progression. Sweet and yet noble.

review_title: The Perfect Lemon Cake from Trieste
review_content:
It was love at first sniff. I discovered Il Colore del Vento for the first time on vacation in Trieste, in a charming little niche perfumery, where the owner smiled while spraying it and said, “This is fun!” And she was so right...!

The fragrance is simply beautiful, from start to finish. Zesty, gourmand, delicious. It fits almost any occasion, radiant in summer, warming in winter, but it's perfect in autumn.

Recently, a colleague asked me in the afternoon what smelled so delicious here. “Did someone bake waffles?” No, it was "Il Colore del Vento | Nobile 1942," which I had sprayed on at 6:15 in the morning.
So we’ve also immediately clarified the question of longevity and sillage. The fragrance lasts quite a long time and has a decent, yet pleasant sillage.

Forget Lira, Devotion & Co.! This is the perfect lemon cake.
At the opening, a juicy lemon shines, accompanied by a fine spiciness from ginger and pepper, a bit of warmth from cardamom, all very subtle and harmonious. Then comes this sparkling champagne effect, followed by a hint of coffee and caramel. Sweet, but never sticky, probably thanks to the fresh bergamot that perfectly balances the fragrance.
In the drydown, it gets really delicious. Butter, caramel, and a soft warmth that reminds you of freshly baked waffles.

The fragrance naturally moved in with me the same day, and I have not regretted it.

Il Colore del Vento is a fragrance that simply makes you happy.

I am in love.

review_title: from Citronella Candle to Italian Café
review_content:
Il Colore del Vento initially reminds one of a citronella candle when first sprayed, but this extreme lemon kick quickly fades, thank goodness, as I find the scent almost unpleasant in the first few minutes; the spritziness of the champagne combined with citronella makes one wrinkle their nose.

Fortunately, I tested it on my skin and it was able to develop..

Relatively quickly, Il Colore del Vento transforms: the citrus freshness settles like a fine veil, and beneath it reveals a creamy-warm depth. Now you find yourself on an autumn afternoon on the terrace of a beautiful, elegant Italian café, the sun shining in your face. Fresh butter pastries, cakes, and a warm crème brûlée pass by, with a hint of coffee wafting in the background - soft, lightly roasted, never dominant, more like a quiet companion, just like the lemon now. A cozy blanket wraps around you, giving you a wonderful feeling of security.

This contrast of lemony clarity and gourmand warmth makes the scent so fascinating for me. It is airy yet deep, bright yet cozy. A fragrance that begins with ease and ends in softness, like a gust of wind transforming into an embrace? Perhaps that's where the color of the wind comes from. But it could also simply be the wind from the Italian café ;-)

For me, an absolute feel-good scent, very pleasing, for gourmand fans. As for the sillage, I can say that I hardly notice the scent on myself after a while, but it is never completely gone. I left my lightly perfumed clothes from the previous day in the dressing room and entered it the next morning, and there it was again, completely present: the delicious Italian café!

review_title: You Are So Close to Me!
review_content: A day has fallen out of time. Everything that is usually so ordinary and familiar carries a delicate, golden-brown shimmer. The moment stretches out, and a hidden space opens up. The wind carries with it a long-forgotten child's laughter. My hands, which have only touched you until now, have finally held you for the first time today. I am enveloped by the "color of the wind." It allows me to become the woman I could be. The serene warmth softens the edges of protective strength without compromising it. For a stolen moment, I see the world in a different light. I want to linger there. To surrender, to sink into you, to simply be without words. We will meet again in our dreams.

Conjures images of a blooming, creamy, yellow-white floral that gives off the scent of an otherworldly custard… the ylang and heliotrope are blended about evenly, and combined with the other gourmand items of caramel, vanilla, coffee, clove & benzoin an incredibly rich and dense foundation is made—and then given an herbal-green twist by the oregano, patchouli and violet leaf, also complimented by vetiver in the base.

Really delightful! Ingredients are showcased well while still nicely blended into a pretty novel scent. There are some very pleasant chocolate and banana nuances as well, creating such an interesting nutty, creamy, herbal dessert.

I also applaud the use of oregano here, very deftly added and I feel a great choice of herb for the job. Well complimented by the tang of the patchouli.

Bravo, good sir!

Captivated me with its unique blend of freshness and sensuality. From the moment I first experienced its enticing aroma, I knew it was a purchase worth making. This unisex perfume manages to strike a perfect balance, making it a versatile choice for various occasions.

The fragrance opens with a woody and resinous accord, evoking a sense of warmth and depth. It is accompanied by a subtle smokiness that adds an alluring touch to the composition. As the scent develops, sweet and spicy notes emerge, further enhancing its complexity.

While it may not be an everyday fragrance for me, Sexy Garrigue is perfect for seasonal wear, providing a refreshing change of pace. Its versatility shines as it transitions seamlessly from day to night, making it suitable for both daytime and evening occasions.

The perfume’s clean and well-balanced character ensures that it can be worn throughout the day without overpowering the senses. However, it truly shines when worn during evening events, exuding an air of elegance and allure.

Overall, Sexy Garrigue is a captivating fragrance that leaves a lasting impression. Its combination of woody, resinous, smoky, sweet, and spicy accords creates a unique and memorable experience.

Whether you’re seeking a scent for a special occasion or simply want to add a touch of sensuality to your fragrance collection, Sexy Garrigue is a worthy choice.

A very sweet, sticky dripping spice honey. It reminds me a bit of dried fruits lying outside on a table to dry on a hot summer day. The light herb garden fades a bit, but the heavy sweetness of what is surely a very good honey remains and remains and remains. The scent clings to me for a loose 6-8 hours. I wouldn't actually describe it as sexy - it intoxicates the senses and leads my counterpart to think there’s someone who has taken a honey-date-fig-mandarin bath and is exuding from every pore. Many might like that; it is indeed very intense and lingers in the room for a long time. An oriental perfume, it suits women better, or men who enjoy such perfume calories. Price over 200 euros, the bottle looks noble and elegant. After about 3-4 hours, it becomes a bit more subdued, but the scent progression remains unchanged. It smells of honey and dried fruits. I unfortunately have to say this, and I normally never do - it’s not my candidate, but it will surely find its fans.

review_title: Sharp, spicy, leathery tobacco, a bit of a varnish vibe
review_content:
Sampling Fulton & Roark Sterling, a sharp blend featuring prominent notes of tobacco leaf and amber, almost with a varnish/lacquer/borderline whiskey type of vibe, as well, striking and fairly powerful, though not extremely dense. It’s a non-sweet contrast to Calle Ocho, the boozier sweeter blend. It expectedly dries down to be a little calmer, though its character does not change much, with still a lot of sharpness, borderline metallic, some hours in.

Like the rest of the extrait collection, Sterling is priced at $205 for 50ml, far from cheap, so I’d really only recommend a full bottle if you love it, and while I like it, I don’t love it, but I think it will suit some people very well in the cooler months, especially. My favorites of my sample set of five were ultimately Calle Ocho and Narada.

7 out of 10

CHLOE ROSES dries down to smell like a completely different fragrance than CHLOE. This flanker isn't trying to be her older sister. She's her own woman.

review_title: my first independent step into becoming a fraghead...
review_content:
my mom was into fragrances, but I would always borrow hers. I had never owned a fragrance myself or chosen it by trial and error. this perfume marks me developing a taste and getting it myself...

it's funny, the bottle I have will always be something special and nostalgic about it. I was rebellious and was trying out shoplifting for the first time, and this was the second thing I ever stole, from a Macy's I believe. so the bottle is a tester bottle that looks a little worse for the wear, but it was like 80% full.

the scent is slightly on the soapy side, but it's a really nice non-committal fragrance for me. great for layering with other fragrances as this is basically a lot of light, airy notes. I like to pair this with Dusita's Oudh Infini for added girlishness and sophistication.

it does tend to fade on skin super quick (almost immediately even), but on fabrics it can last a while.

It does soften over time, but the rose is always right there with you. Decent sillage and longevity.
It’s a far cry better than the Tom Ford Rose Prick I bought last month and a lot less expensive.
Again, if you want real rose, look no further than Roses de Chloe.

review_title: This is a date night in a bottle.
review_content:
It begins with a youthful excitement (the bergamot), as you put on your dress and makeup, getting ready for the date you've been looking forward to. The citrus perks you up as your date picks you up and takes you downtown.
And as the evening really begins, the roses bloom. You smell of love and romance. You raise your arms to touch your partner across the table, and roses breathe with your movement.
And finally, towards the end, everything settles down into a comforting rosy musk, and you feel, above all, like a woman in love.

This was one of the first perfumes I ever got myself (in travel spray format). I was big into fresh florals back then, and this one had just been released. Definitely a youthful take on rose, bright and fresh, not at all powdery. The lasting power wasn't great, and if I remember, that's why I never ended up buying a full bottle. Which turned out to be a good thing, because I outgrew this scent pretty quickly and never ended up finishing the travel spray I bought. Nevertheless, I still appreciate it to this day as my introduction to perfume.

The bergamot top note is very welcome, but quickly fades to leave behind a rather immature fragrance. I love simpler compositions, but I also want to be able to discern the notes. At least one in the top, middle and base. Once the bergamot goes you're left with a sweet, non-descript floral. It's very much like Dahlia & Vines , but perhaps just a tiny bit better in...

I love roses, especially the scent of a damask rose (my dad grows a bush in his garden). This scent is like the essence of that rose scent, soft and pleasant. I would even call it the Lacroix of rose scents. I'm actually not sure what those other notes are for, because this is just rose all the way for me. Unfortunately, it doesn't last very long at all. I wonder if it's...

I tested it once and I am truly in love; this could become my new everyday scent, one that stays...

Roses de Chloe is a fresh-sweet pink spring and summer fragrance. Chloe starts off with a zesty freshness from bergamot, shortly followed by magnolia, which gives the scent a "shower gel" feeling. The...

I perceive the bergamot top note only very subtly on its own, but it contributes to the immediately noticeable brightness of this scent. The rose is present right away, a completely natural light pink...

What did the saleswoman put in my bag yesterday with my fragrance purchase? Roses de Chloe. She showed a sure hand, because I love rose scents! And this one is wonderfully done. A clear, unadulterated rose scent, accompanied by delicate magnolia. And the rose is captured in its entirety - with its leaves and stems. It’s more of a rose bush than a single...

review_title: Rose is a rose is a rose is a rose
review_content:
This was already recognized over 100 years ago by the American poet Gertrude Stein.

And it describes exactly what this fragrance evokes in me:
I lose myself in roses, red-radiant, pink-floating, yellow-vibrating, white-glowing, orange-warming, and they all scent in harmony in this perfume.
A rose intoxication, enchanting, tender, intense. Like entranced, I get caught up in the fragrance, wanting to sing with Knef in the rain of roses, lie in a bed full of roses as sung by Bon Jovi, compose poetry with Hölderlin “To the Rose”...

And above all, the Damask rose scents, gently supported by the magnolia. A minimalist touch of bergamot brings a bit of freshness to the abundance of floral fragrance, but without minimizing, restricting, or dominating the rose. The rose remains, radiantly central, fragrant.
Amber and musk bring depth and softness, but only to carry the rose within.
All the ingredients of the fragrance pyramid serve only to honor the rose, to roll out the rose-red carpet for her, to place the little crown upon her head.

And I fully agree with Gertrude Stein:
Rose is a rose is a rose is a rose.

Friendly it is, the spring of the year 2014, very friendly.
In March already, it flattered our spirits with temperatures in the upper double digits, emerging from this time's not too deep winter slumber, allowing flowers and shrubs to burst their buds ahead of time and making my soul rejoice with joy over warm sun rays on winter-pale skin and the most colorful, vibrant scent veils that divided the air in the gardens and meadows of our settlement.
Each day became a little more colorful, a little greener, a little friendlier, until the first week of April could have made me believe, without looking at the calendar, that I was at the beginning of summer.
Who could believe it was just a coincidence that handed me a vial of "July" in anticipation of the month of joy?

And indeed: Already the first spray catapults me into an early, young, dew-damp high summer morning somewhere far down south, in the warm, in the sunny, right in the middle of a densely leafed, light yellow-green and dark orange-green speckled grapefruit and mandarin grove.
The air is delicately cool and silky like a gossamer veil drawn through bubbling spring water, cool-matte patinated fruit skin explodes into millions of tiny, herbaceous, penetrating yet not at all sour, not at all sharp, not at all biting scent molecules, tickling my nose and expanding my lungs, driving the blood faster through my veins and making my eyes wider, brighter, more alert.
No sticky-sweet juice drips from freshly peeled zest - firm and plump, the fruits hang on the tree, nestling freshly picked in my hands, tenderly bitter oil wells around my deeply dug nails into the skin, so pure, so unadulterated, so mouth-watering naturally, that I cannot believe, that I do not want to believe, that this dream-drunk realistic impression is solely due to the fragrant puddle on my wrist.
Hour by hour, this delicately fresh breeze surrounds me, a little leafy, green, a little softer, creamier, becoming even friendlier, deepening over time, woodier, saltier, just a little, very little, and always putting a smile in the corners of my mouth, in the corners of my eyes, holding it, warming and cooling me, encouraging and soothing me, making life feel light and softly whispering: "Summer is yet to come, summer is yet to come..."

review_title: Psssst! Welcome to the Realm of Subtle Scents!
review_content:
Knock, knock... excuse me, is anyone there?! Open the door! I can smell that you’re home! This, or something similar, would be the beginning of any mediocre crime film. At least if the perpetrator were a perfume.

Here, the loudest fragrances often receive the best ratings and the most attention. After all, you want to get your money's worth!
This will be my first journey into the world of subtle scents. Those that are meant just for oneself. For all those days ...
~ when you have an occasion that calls for discreet fragrance but still need a protector
~ when you just want to happily immerse yourself in your own scent and draw strength without being immediately noticed
~ when you ...

Where other perfumes can comfort with their enveloping nature, Juli offers a very gentle embrace. It combines excellent self-perception with an almost nonexistent external perception. I have never experienced this to such an extent before. It’s as if it crawls directly from the skin to the nose. Tested on others as well: I hardly notice it as a non-wearer.

Enough now, let’s get to the point: It starts citrusy. A lovely grapefruit opens and soon makes way for plenty of green! And that is what Juli is and wants to be all the time. The light green, likely marked by the fig leaf, is so well integrated with the grapefruit and mint that even critics of the latter will find nothing to complain about here. The rather citrusy start gradually transitions into a green woodiness that never loses its freshness. Vetiver, along with cedar, ensures that the scent becomes a bit darker. The wood is so ethereal and floating that one could almost describe it as a refreshing top note. Exactly this little cloud hits you from time to time... when you’ve held your head down for too long, as if it’s gathering under your chin, just waiting for you to lift it again...
However, one should not forget: It is still a little green thing. Neither highly complex nor an olfactory artistic masterpiece. But beautiful. And all ingredients are easily detectable.

It is unisex simply because it only wants to please the wearer. I find the longevity quite good for a light green scent. Two sprays, definitely applied to the neck, provide a lovely fragrance experience without drowning in it.

It’s so green ...
and the grapefruit is fantastically bitter. Here it feels fruity, there it’s more green, and then again wooden. I didn’t want to ask the other day so as not to seem intrusive. Yet my impression that colors play a special role in these compositions is once again reinforced, and I already think I possess something quite personal with these fragrances. Synesthesia is something very personal, if my assumption is correct, and therefore I prefer to be cautious in my description. The matter is understandable, unfortunately not at all comprehensible for me, and commands my utmost respect. Ah, I am still standing in the garden, breathing in the scent of rain-soaked leaves and tasting grapefruit. Cool, fresh, refreshing. Someone has put mint in the cool water. It sparkles on the skin and then comes the first, clear break. Now July becomes more floral and almost caressing. The heart note makes me think of magnolias and jasmine. Rarely do the top, heart, and base notes separate so distinctly; rarely do I perceive the progression of a perfume so clearly and understandably. That back there must be vetiver, and that fabric softener note is definitely the musk. Everything is pleasant, wearable, light as a cool morning in a garden. It’s so beautifully green ...

Sometimes the very first impression can be misleading - with people, as well as with perfumes! “July” was such a case for me.
In my notes, I had written: “Citrus, a bit green, rather insignificant.” This was apparently after testing a sample. But I must have ignored that when I signed up for a sharing. Luckily!
Without further testing, I assigned the fragrance to the month of July (one might smile at my monthly categorization, but it helps me keep track of my mega collection).

Yesterday, I sprayed “July” for a longer car ride to my card game group - and was pleasantly surprised. A wonderfully fruity-citrusy scent with very little sweetness. This perfume showed no development on my skin; it essentially consisted only of the top note for several hours. So basically grapefruit and mandarin, but no mint, fig leaf, or anything else. However, I found this enduring top note to be very pleasant. It gave me the illusion of a warm sunny summer day, which could hardly be said of the rainy, cool day yesterday. I raised my rating from an original 7.0 to 8.5.

I’m already looking forward to the bottle, which I was offered shortly after clicking “I’ll wear this” by an attentive user!

In the store of 1000 & 1 Seifen, you can always purchase a limited fragrance that the owner has developed and produced himself. Currently, it is a vetiver.

And this vetiver belongs to the group that pairs vetiver with cedarwood in the base. I have already posted a detailed overview of this special category:

http://www.parfumo.de/forum/viewtopic.php?t=531&highlight=Zedernholz+und+Vetiver

To get straight to the point: The base note consists of nothing other than this special combination. Thus, this perfume is a distinctly purist representative of the cedarwood-vetiver category. In fact, this perfume is said to consist of only seven fragrance notes.

However, I find that the heart and top notes do not quite do justice to this intense combination. They are light and delicate. There are subtle, yet high-quality grapefruit and mandarin. The heart is complemented by fig leaf, but only very subtly. I know it differently and better. One could compare it - if one has it - to the unfortunately now discontinued Salvatore Ferragamo pour Homme. Here, the strong fig leaf serves as an equal partner to the vetiver.

The delicate top note lasts about 10 minutes, while the heart note, which also contains a bit of jasmine, lasts at least half an hour. However, the base note lasts for many hours. I would have wished for a bit more endurance from the top and heart notes, as they are truly very beautiful. After all, a hint of citrus freshness and floral lightness is carried into the drydown.

I think that in the realm of cedarwood-vetiver fragrances, the air is quite thin for perfumers, as there is much good out there. Just think of the successful Terre d'Hermes, which can now be considered a reference fragrance for this direction.

As a men's fragrance, I do not like this vetiver so much. There are more interesting variations of the theme elsewhere, with a more individual expression. The contrast between the base and the delicate heart and top notes could not be greater; it feels torn. And the base is too pure for me; I would prefer a bit more complexity here.

As a women's fragrance, however, I find the perfume successful. Because - let's be honest - vetiver and cedarwood combinations are simply too good to be reserved for just one half of humanity. The delicacy and lightness of the top and heart notes, which do convey a bit into the drydown, make this combination wearable for women. I mean, I have also read on Parfumo the desire from the female side to be able to wear Terre d'Hermès. However, a distinctly feminine fragrance is fig & vetiver by no means.

review_title: A Phantom of carnation and leather

Gideon is a fragrance of classic aromatic, ambery, and musky, steeped in a dark, brooding elegance.
Thick, animalic civet rises like a phantom, dense and untamed, entwined with the delicate sweetness of carnation and the raw, unyielding edge of leather. The presence of carnation and leather exudes a classic sophistication, yet it is the deep, fecal civet that leaves an incredible mark, a shadow lingering long after its gone. It strikes with fierce intensity at first, rich and uncompromising, only to settle into something quieter, composed, yet still pulsing with an untamed spirit.
A scent that does not fade, but transforms into spectral refinement drydown as same as TF Oud Minérale

The "give-aways" with orders of skincare products from Dr. Pierre Ricaud are always very impressive: often they are valuable skincare products in full size, and often also fragrances from the now quite extensive collection of ID Parfums/Isabel Derroisné.

Last autumn, it was a bottle of the new fragrance "Cap d'Ambre"; which had, however, been forgotten in a "cosmetics supply collection box".
Why actually?
Certainly not because I don't like this brand.
All the fragrances I know are very well crafted and have their own charm.
They are not "chart-toppers", but due to their special personality, they are extremely wearable.
Especially on those days when nothing loud, pompous, or demanding should come near.
We all know these occasions; especially when we are testing through our fragrance sample stash and suddenly realize that our senses need a break to reactivate themselves.
But who among us wants to be "naked and bare" during this time?

Many of the fragrance creations from ID Parfums/Isabel Derroisné are for me a pleasant pause from fragrance stress in these moments, without having to forgo scent.
Among them is "Cap d'Ambre" - a grand name for a delicately vanilla-scented fragrance wrap that does not weigh down or burden; consisting of coarsely knitted scent meshes.
Bergamot and pink pepper (without which it seems one cannot go these days) easily break open these first scent meshes.
A very light, delicate, yet expressive vanilla with its own unique charm takes up this scent thread. By the way, it remains very faithful on the skin for a long time without becoming annoying or musty.
The fine yellowish-white scent hue gains a slightly earthy depth from patchouli's golden brown.
Even now, this scent fabric radiates warmth and harmony.
Noble resins, here myrrh and light, not too heavy incense, add a spicy-smoky note that neither scratches nor becomes too dominant.
On the contrary, a warm vanilla note with a pleasantly smoky spice develops as the finale of this artisanally well-balanced composition; it hums and resonates softly!

These are not passionate vanilla-erotic vibrations that tease the senses with golden brown resins, but a wearable little piece of fragrance art for all day.
To call "Cap d'Ambre" a "daily fragrance" would be unloving and also wrong.
A charming and quiet elegance accompanies one calmly through the day, leaving a feeling of being protected.
A light fragrance cape that shields against external disturbances and gives the over-saturated senses protective time to regenerate.

Today was certainly not the last day I will reach for "Cap d'Ambre's" fine accompaniment.
I do enjoy these quiet tones that pleasantly weave through gray days with golden, softly glowing light.

review_title: Colonial Goods XI: Quite much, and perhaps a little confusing!
review_content:
This cologne, which I would have classified as rather unknown, yet has 180 owners here, is a bit exhausting. The unknown artist who created it packed five scents into this compact bottle that overlap with each other, and the olfactory impression depends on the respective nasal perspective, much like a moiré pattern.

Fragrance No. 1: A classic Farina cologne. With bergamot, neroli, lemon, and lavender, it has almost everything. Nice and fresh, well done.

Fragrance No. 2: A white-synthetic, freshly-laundered scent in the style of Byredo's Blanche and LM's Chemise Blanche; this impression is the dominant one in the first minutes; responsible here are the thick, fat, plump aldehydes along with geranium and lavender (yes, the lavender is used twice, just like in a moiré pattern).

Fragrance No. 3: A green powerhouse from the 70s/80s (with chest hair); responsible here, of course, is the note that is as characteristic of this type of fragrance as patchouli is for hippies: the clary sage, found in all major men's fragrances of this era (Antaeus, Paco Rabanne, Kouros, Cacharel Homme, Zino, Azzaro pour homme, YSL pour Homme, Aigner Super Fragrance for men) along with predecessors (Aramis, 1964) and modern reinterpretations (Tomo, Honos). And alongside the clary sage, of course, it also holds true here: No moss, no glory.

Fragrance No. 4: A dirty, masculine rose scent (geranium, incense, leather, vetiver, earthy patchouli).

Fragrance No. 5: A conciliatory, moderately sweet, yet still very masculine base note pleaser (after a hard day for men, it’s nice to relax): musk, sweet patchouli, sandalwood.

This is a bit heavy for the wearer to digest (perhaps for the surrounding world as well), but there is (just barely, with a groan and creaking in the beams) a coherent overall picture where the scent does not fall apart. In any case, it gives the fragrance a distinctive character.

I see the same polyvalence in the (strange) name "G-man." The following layers of meaning come to mind:

No. 1: The men's scent from G like Gainsboro (as a short form for Gainsborough, the Swiss brand that no longer exists independently but is supposedly attached to Juvena, is said to be named after the British landscape painter).

No. 2: A play on words with G-spot, which I won’t elaborate on here, let your imagination run free.

No. 3: A scent for G- (gentle) men.

No. 4: A scent as tough as a G-man (gangster slang for hard-nosed FBI agents = Government Men).

Edit: No. 5: More for fun and to make it five: A scent for ze G-er-man. Edit end.

For those who want to embark on this roller coaster: Go ahead! I find it a very exciting and highly original fragrance. Whether the enthusiasm with which I (against my usual habit) made an immediate purchase at an online perfumery after testing today was perhaps a bit hasty will show. With about 25 euros, however, the loss would also be bearable.

review_title: In Honor of a Very Special Man…
review_content:
… this is my first review on Parfumo. I specifically chose this fragrance for it.

It was a mild sunny spring morning, sometime in my life at the age of 15. I was at my grandparents' house, where I loved to spend my time. I wandered through the hallway in the apartment to get to the kitchen for breakfast.
The first rays of sunshine streamed through the bathroom window onto the brown tiles of the hallway, fine dust particles floated through the air, and the birds chirped loudly.
In front of the sink, with the door open, stood my grandfather in freshly ironed pleated trousers, house slippers, lowered suspenders, and he wore a fresh pure white "fine ribbed undershirt." His silver-white hair was combed back with Seborin. In his hand was his safety razor, looking into the mirror, one could hear the scratching of the stubble as the blade glided over it.

“Moin Obba!” I called and waved my hand. “Mooooin!” he grumbled and continued with his morning routine.

I entered the kitchen, and it smelled wonderful of coffee. My grandma sat freshly dressed and smelling of 4711 in the kitchen. Around her neck was an amber necklace that has burned itself into my frontal lobes. The radio was playing, on the table: the Hanauer Anzeiger and perfectly jam-spread bread. My grandma was an artist at that.

“Moin Omma!” I replied to her with a gentle smile. A short hug and a kiss on the cheek… “Aaaaay mein Bub!” she responded. I sat down on the bench, took a sip of coffee, and started to eat a piece of bread.
A few minutes later, my grandpa joined us at the table. Freshly shaved, suspenders in place, still wearing the bright white fine ribbed shirt. The white curly chest hair slightly peeked out from the wide neckline. He took the newspaper and flipped directly to the sports section.
At that moment, a scent came to me that I will never forget…

It was this very Gainsboro G-Man… So multifaceted… Strong, spicy, fresh, slightly sweet, masculine!

Me: “Wow Obba, what are you wearing!?”
Grandpa: “My scent, the Gainsboro. Do you like it?”
Me: “Absolutely! What is it?”
Grandpa: “Of course! Your mother loves the scent too! Even as a little girl!”

So I jumped up, went to the bathroom, and at the sink stood the dark bottle with its distinctive gold print. I pulled off the cap and smelled the bottle again. “This is it!” *sniff… *sniff… “Absolutely amazing!” I immediately applied two sprays. Seventh heaven.

Over the years, the scent faded from my memory. My grandparents passed away… At some point, I asked my mother what “de Obba” always used as aftershave. She pronounced the name, and immediately it shot through my mind like a lightning bolt. Including flashbacks.

Shortly after, I searched for the scent and found it at Galeria Kaufhof. Even on sale. I immediately took a bottle and also got the shower gel.
By now, I wear this scent very often. So often that I have a bottle in my locker at work.

My interpretation: Floral, spicy, fresh.
The opening is definitely characterized by aldehydes; you can also notice the alcohol content, but that fades within a few minutes, revealing a fresh clean scent that somehow reminds me of a flower meadow, forest, and a slight citrus freshness.
After a certain maturity, it retains its floral character but becomes “spicier,” and a hint of sweetness reveals itself, but only very lightly.

On my skin, it doesn’t last long, maybe 1-2 hours, but that applies to almost all scents on me. On clothes, however, it is still well noticeable even after a hard day’s work. It’s like a good red wine. The riper it gets, the better it becomes. It is a very multifaceted scent that I cannot compare to anything else. It has a distinctive character with recognition.

Not a scent for the boys of today, definitely not. This is a scent for a real gentleman who wears it as a statement.

Like Superman, when his cape flutters in the wind, fists on his hips with bent arms, chest puffed out and extended. The slicked-back hair flutters in front of his forehead. And not to forget: The underwear, over the pants! That is also a statement.

Thank you, Grandpa! Through this scent, you still accompany me.

As the title says: “In Honor of a Very Special Man…”

Thank you for your attention.

Isn't it amazing how angelica, proud like the Engelberg in the canton of Obwalden, has been providing well-being for half a century now?
This herb has been bridging the gap between earthy and green aromatic since 1971.
Beautifully packaged in a striking, elegantly black bottle with a flawless spray head.

Sometimes you feel down, tired of the most unpleasant scents, and uncertain due to your battered nose.
Here, the Swiss company Juvena gladly offers the following remedy.

Sizzle!

Ahh, golden aldehydes herald gentle citrus fruits and soft lavender.
And just like that, the mood lifts!

Soapy moss from the base is in a hurry and cheekily froths up with a robust geranium.

But the magic builds up slowly.
Blazing incense transforms the initial aldehydes into a nurturing, resinous cloud.
So delicate and gentle.

And then, yes then, the refreshing heart of the fragrance starts to throb.
Well-measured angelica bridges the gap between heaven and earth.
Wonderfully aromatic with slight citrus sprinkles reminiscent of lemon balm, it brings the earthy patchouli to bloom. The grass lay softly and sleepily and has now been awakened.

Oh, what a main accord!

Incense, angelica, and patchouli finely rounded off.
Green vetiver supports from the second row.
Everything is carried by glazed sandalwood.

Warmth, coolness, heights and depths, all of this the fragrance lovingly captures.

One easily climbs the gentle Giferspitz near Gstaad, and the world looks wonderful again!

And this extremely likeable type of people from the Bernese Oberland has the perfect expression for a kiss ready.

Müntschi

Because this is exactly what the fragrance delivers right to your doorstep!

By the way, the shower gel is practically the next mountain peak of restoration.

And for that, I can only shout with full team spirit:

“Hopp Schwiiz!”

Dear Precious recommended G-Man to me, she knows quite well what Mrs. Pluto likes. So I relied on her judgment, bought the fragrance blind, and gifted it. Heaven, what a fine chypre scent, finally a men's fragrance that comes untamed, rugged, and without any softener. And I’m giving it away, tzz, tzz. No worries, I’ve already bought it again - for Mr. Pluto.

The beginning is strong, very fresh, the aldehydes enhance the green bergamot and lemon note, the lavender gets a bit overshadowed. It continues with spicy rose geranium, briefly reminding me of Geranium Bourbon, but this scent was much gentler. I can also sniff out masculine, robust leather, while the incense is rather timid and stays softly in the background. It becomes increasingly soapy, very shaving cream soapy. My association is a small men's barbershop, with dark wooden panels on the walls, tattered newspapers on the shelf by the mirror, with a barber chair that still has a manual height adjustment, an endlessly chatting barber in a shabby apron, a straight razor in one hand, and a cigarette in the other. Along with the soap come a lot of musk and moss, the patchouli spreads the scent of earth, thus initiating the warm-spicy base.

G-Man is truly a rugged, spicy scent that strikes me as dynamic and incredibly attractive. The bottle, well, black, practical, good - just for guys. And a fragrance that is not bound to any season, perhaps just a tad too fresh for winter. The sillage is strong at first, quickly settling into a medium level, the longevity on me is about 5 hours, quite contrary to the rated longevity here - perhaps G-Man is a victim of reformulation or this is due to my cool skin.

Oh yes, I wear it occasionally too - ideal for conferences or meetings where a woman needs to assert herself, there’s no “sweetheart, up to here and no further…”

One more thing, it reminds me a little of Explosive by Aigner - just a tiny little bit...

Alright, the headline is provocative and it goes without saying that G-Man by Gainsboro is neither extremely stimulating nor euphoric.

Nevertheless, this Eau de Cologne has steadfastly and reliably established itself as an olfactory "go-to" for over 45 years.

Even though G-Man may seem relatively complex on paper, in practical life, there are three components that are absolutely characteristic of this fragrance and reveal themselves quite quickly.

On one hand, there is a fresh aldehyde/bergamot combo with a slight sharpness that evokes a bit of an association with a classic aftershave, while also providing the necessary kick.

Almost simultaneously, the geranium appears rather elegantly. It gives G-Man a light gentlemanly touch without drifting too much into the noble. A clever building block within the creation.

As a third layer and thus an interesting counterpoint to the fresh aldehyde/bergamot combo, a wonderfully soft dominant musk base emerges. This ultimately remains, although one wishes for much more endurance from the top note to give this congenial liaison further lift. Unfortunately, you can't have it all.

The comparison to Etienne Aigner No. 2 as a fragrance twin is not far-fetched at all, as both are nearly established musk monsters, although the refreshing prelude of G-Man along with the geranium appears to be quite fascinating.

Another advantage is this sinfully low entry price - especially when I always see those huge shower gel bottles for little money.

However, all the curious should double-check their birth date on their ID and perhaps ask their conscience whether they possess the necessary maturity for this fragrance. Otherwise, enjoy!

Childhood, hopefully a carefree time for most of us. Highlights of that earlier time were always going out with family, such as family celebrations or the village festivals known here as "Hocks." Naively, I still approach the topic of fragrances with a childlike perspective. G-Man was a blind buy due to the great criteria here but also because of the low price. When I...

review_title: A Gentleman of the Old School
review_content:
He has style.
Education, charisma, and excellent manners in all situations define him.
Art and culture are as familiar to him as literature.
Restraint is his credo, although he knows how to express his viewpoints as emphatically as he does politely.
Exaggeration is foreign to him.

A gentleman of the old school will never be loud, never vulgar, never intrusive.
He is the rock in the surf, reliable, unshakeable.
He never violates common conventions, even if the whole world has thrown them overboard.

All of this is embodied by this fragrance in a stylish, subtle, and highly skillful manner.

Cool it is, this fragrance, reserved yet strong.
Lavender and clary sage provide it with support, giving it an explicitly very classic, conventional direction.
It is wonderfully clear, it is wonderfully unambiguous.
Unimaginable to wear this fragrance with anything other than a well-fitted suit!
It exudes freshness, brightness, tranquility.

No, this is not a fragrance to be worn by a young man.
It is a fragrance that belongs solely to the adult man, that man whose face has already been marked by the first wrinkles of life.
This fragrance distinguishes men from boys.

Rose geranium softens its severity, giving it a light, almost sun-drenched note, without allowing it to slip into the playful or overly cheerful.
The gentleman of the old school smiles quietly, but he does not laugh loudly and boisterously.
Composure!

This composure is emphasized by gentle musk, which adds a delicate, warmer note.
Vetiver and sandalwood round off the almost tangible cleanliness and fresh coolness of this fragrance perfectly.
The complexity of the very subtle and yet robust leather note, which only gradually reveals itself, hints that the gentleman of the old school is not unfamiliar with the rougher sides of life, despite all his refinement.
He has mastered them ...

April, April - and Dad's birthday was approaching. My mother had drilled into me that I needed to have a gift ready by the 26th, so I strained my child’s mind and came up with a gift. I knew my father liked perfume, and so I set off alone to the best perfumery in town with the melodious name "Er&Sie". I had emptied my piggy bank and felt rich. What a wonderful place the...

With prices under €20 per 100 ml, G-man by Gainsboro is a real bargain. The brand seems to belong to the Juvena group. But does that mean it has to be a bad scent? G-man has been around for quite a while, since 1971, and it is a true macho scent of that era. Strong and rugged, it shouts: “Look at me, I’m a real man.” However, a glance at the pyramid reveals that...

How does one approach a fragrance about which one of the most renowned German fragrance experts once said it is "a loner among men's fragrances with its pronounced hay note"? And what might be hidden behind a "hay note"?

I actually expected anything but to find G-Man among the 100 most popular men's fragrances on this site. G-Man is indeed robust, albeit with a sweet base; he is quirky, full of fragrant contradictions, and demanding. The fact that such a fragrance is ultimately quite popular shows that there must be a strong desire for original men's fragrances that stand out from the monotony of most contemporary compositions. After all, G-Man is from the early 70s and has thus survived all the trends in between: from the musky scents (mid-70s) to powerhouse perfumes (80s), from leather notes (somehow always making a comeback) to the sporty-fresh colognes that have olfactorily pursued us since the 90s.

If the fragrance can be associated with a hay note, it seems to me that it refers less to the grassy, green smell of freshly cut hay, but rather to the scent that hay emits when it is dried, interspersed with many meadow flowers that are preserved under the sun but still exude a hint of fragrance. This comparison has always made sense to me, even in the absence of other compelling associations.

It is hard to guess where the soft notes in the base have gone. Where is the musk, the sandalwood oil, and the leather note? One must give the fragrance a lot of time to decipher the code of this hidden base note. For me, G-Man consists almost entirely of classic top and heart notes, meaning components that are rather fresh, a bit sharp, but also floral in nature.

The fragrance pyramid on this site reveals that, in addition to geranium, frankincense is also included. And that could be the key to understanding this fragrance. In fact, the strong contrast between frankincense, which is usually softly embedded in other fragrances or competes little with other components (see Comme des Garcons Avignon and Kyoto), is likely responsible for the contrasting and tension-filled nature of this cologne.

The fruity, hesperidic notes in the opening remain well recognizable even after a long time: neroli, lavender, bergamot. They dominate the fragrance alongside the frankincense-geranium axis in the heart note.

Anyway: This composition unites fragrance accents that have never been combined in this way in other fragrances. Therefore, it can indeed be said that this cologne is a loner. Certainly, this is not a fragrance for everyone and not one for every occasion. While G-Man is neither strictly for everyday wear nor for the evening, one must be in the right mood to endure the tensions that characterize the fragrance. This presupposes that one is somewhat relaxed, has a desire for an extraordinary scent, and perhaps also wants to stand out just a little bit.

When I smelled the hay note, I immediately thought of Jürgen Drews' overplayed hit "Ein Bett im Kornfeld": also from the 70s and not always bearable. However, in the right mood, it can actually be quite amusing.

G-man, a relentlessly masculine scent since time immemorial.
As far back as I can remember, it has been the signature fragrance of one of my uncles; by the way, it was also the only fragrance he owned and still owns today.
It's actually funny that this particular scent has not noticeably been reformulated to this day and stubbornly remains on the market. However, I am not surprised, as G-man simply has its qualities. Whether it's the black-violet bottle with golden lettering that feels good and valuable in hand, or the scent itself, it is a must-have for a man!

Immediately after spraying, an extremely soapy bouquet unfolds, which needs to sort itself out. Shortly thereafter, however, the other notes come to the fore, primarily the dominant geranium that stands out strongly here, yet never seems exaggerated. I would have suspected clove here; I'm surprised that none is listed, perhaps this aroma comes from the interplay of the ingredients...
As the scent develops further, the musk and sandalwood come through well, forming the foundation. Here, G-Man does not change much anymore, but it surprisingly lasts quite long on the skin for a cologne, and the sillage is also not bad for hours.
For me, G-Man is a statement. You feel very well-groomed and comfortable after a shower and shave!

Its scent twin Aigner No.2 unfortunately cannot quite keep up here, even though it is not bad; I still see G-Man at the top.

If this scent were ever to be discontinued, a lifetime supply would be procured : )

Or: a versatile wandering chypre could be called "G Man".
All the fragrance notes seem to revolve around a center: the rose geranium, fresh-rosy and slightly minty. Like planets around the sun. In the "initial stage" of the scent, lavender and clary sage form a "double system" that approaches the rose geranium and then slowly drifts away again, without staggering "out of space".
Thus, frankincense gains a bit of momentum, without really racing by. It approaches leisurely and remains perceptibly at a respectful distance.
Yes, I almost forgot the aldehydes. They enhance the scent structure, make it stable and long-lasting, without gaining the upper hand.
In their "sphere," the ingredients typical of chypres also feel at home.
The moss with its green "orbit," the patchouli that reminds of the "earthly," sandalwood, and vetiver join in the "carousel game" and move in waves around the center.
Musk is as important for "G. Man" as the moon is for the earth. It maintains the stability of the system and causes
fresh-animal tides.
Birch tar greets from the dark void. The whole thing not only has its own movements circling around a center, it moves as a whole into unknown expanses and depths.
One thing I can already sense, no, I KNOW where it’s headed: to Cyprus. Many have been there before, some don’t want to leave at all. From this colorful, vibrant world. And G. Man is a stop on this journey through the perfume universe.

I like all incense fragrances, so I keep ordering ones that feature incense in the fragrance pyramid. I had already added this scent to my Amazon cart last year but never ordered it. I "accidentally" ordered it now and unfortunately also got 2 bottles! Then I applied it today before going fishing. I already had that déjà vu experience. I know this scent from somewhere?! ...

Not mainstream but a strong character from the 70s. I sometimes thought it was an "Edel Hattric," but that's not true. The fragrance has much more depth than one would suspect at first. I constantly smell a fine and fresh soap that doesn't let go. The scent is very masculine and the longevity is surprisingly good. A fragrance for every season and every occasion, best suited as a business scent.

Anyone who has ever had the soap bomb "Aigner No. 2" on their skin knows which direction this is going. Soap, soap and... oh yes, soap. According to the fragrance pyramid, both share the notes of sage, lavender, geranium, and musk. In my opinion, the musk is more pronounced in the G-Man than in Aigner's classic. It is straightforward, just like its little brother, No. 2....

review_title: When Men Were Allowed to Be Men
review_content:
Once again, I've made a truly beautiful fragrance discovery here.

I don't think such things are produced anymore today. Nowadays, men shave their chests and sometimes even their legs; if they have a beard, it's often trimmed to millimeter precision like the hedge in a community garden, and instead of aging with dignity, they buy anti-aging creams and tinting shampoos.

I feel like I don't belong to this time or this trend. Three-day stubble, hair on the chest. And I often believe that one becomes more attractive with age.

Perhaps this explains why I feel very comfortable with this fragrance - and why I feel absolutely uncomfortable and out of place with scents like One Million, etc. - and this at just 25.

In the first few seconds, the scent starts off alcoholic/aftershave-like and then develops into what I imagine a typical men's fragrance to be. Herbal but not too heavy; not sweet, but also flattering; spicy but not oriental; fresh but not lemony.
I can't really pick out any of the individual notes here. But I find that absolutely okay. A successful overall work of art - and I wish that nowadays people would dare to create something like this again.

The sillage deceives one into thinking it's subtle. However, with not particularly careful dosing, others can still perceive G-Man from meters away, even when you yourself find it harmless. The longevity is unbelievable for a cologne. From 6 AM to 9 PM, the old Gainsboro was well noticeable until I went to shower. Some EdPs could take a lesson from that. The scent suits a man in a T-shirt and jeans just as well as it does a man in a suit. Just please, no 15-year-old teen.

Whether I'm too young for it... I don't know. But I feel comfortable with it.

I have known the old gentleman in the suit for years. And only in a suit and with a hat. When he greets, he lifts his hat and “Kiss the hand” comes to him with the greatest nonchalance. That means, actually, no one really knows him that well: he used to work in a ministry or an embassy - so the story goes. Even his old Mercedes looks just as clean today as it has on all of...

Exactly! Urinal stones! That's what "G-Man" by Gainsboro smells like!

Let's rewind time a bit.

I often used "No.2" by Aigner as shower gel back then. But only as shower gel. Never as a fragrance, as I didn't feel old enough for that yet. The short burst of freshness in the shower had to suffice.
At some point, I could no longer find "No.2". By chance, I then saw the shower gel by Gainsboro, which looked similar to "No.2". I smelled the bottle and thought to myself: "This smells almost like Aigner No.2!"

Almost, but I indulge in memories... nowadays, I believe you can hardly find these urinal stones in porcelain urinals anymore, can you?

At least I need to turn back time. I still remember clearly, back when my dad was in the bowling club, and the ESI guys were rolling a quiet ball again, and took us kids along on the weekends. ESI... a brief explanation: "Einer Steht Immer"... the name of the bowling club.

So, we had touched the sponge to moisten our hands a few times, rolled the ball between the pins, and ordered another Spezi. Spezi naturally puts pressure on the bladder, so the gentleman also has to go for a little girl and heads to the men's restroom.

Of course, you wanted to use the urinal like the grown-ups... back then it was difficult, but today it's no problem anymore. And now we come to the point... back then, these urinal stones were probably used more often in the urinals.

Why not anymore today?? I always found the scent awesome. Yes, awesome! And I stand by it!

And G-Man smells exactly like those stones, and at today's price of €29.50 for 100ml, I jumped at the chance.

Today, I won't say anything about the fragrance notes, as I can't sniff anything anyway. No... today I'm just indulging in memories... memories of bowling, balls, sponges, and.... urinal stones.

What kind of fragrance philistine am I, I ordered this - curious due to the comments here - without testing it.
My impression is an extremely unpleasant, sour smell of "very old man",
I could hardly wait to get home from work and wash it off.

So due to the excitement, I am editing this again:
Of course, I have read the guidelines, and under "Style" it says the following:
"It is completely indifferent whether you want to analyze more objectively or express your personal experiences with the fragrance."
I have done the latter, and I must correct myself, I find it quite factual and to the point, below it says it smells like toilet stone aroma - but still somehow positive, I thought it smelled like old man, and I found that very unpleasant and if I explain it more precisely now, it won't get any more positive: nursing home, hospital were the things that emotionally came to mind. By the way, I am 48 and felt about 40 years older with this product on.
However, one could also interpret it as a compliment that a perfume is capable of making someone decades older with just a spritz and transporting them into a completely different - albeit in this case not necessarily positive - feeling of life.

It is the only EDT (and I even own it twice) whose name I simply cannot remember. Is it a name from the FRG, Switzerland, or GB? The manufacturer is called Juvena .... ?? pfffttt. After I finally discovered the actual name in the bathroom, it is called G-Man by Gainsboro (from Gainsborough, similar to Marlborough). This refers to British regions or cities, after which nobles...

review_title: Leather-soapy scent that has washed itself!
review_content: Wow, "G-Man" is probably the soapiest men's fragrance I have ever smelled in my life! Soap that thoroughly lathers itself. At least as much as in Eisenberg's horrifically bad "Diabolique," but Gainsboro plays in a completely different, higher league. The opening is aldehydic, already somewhat leathery, fresh-spicy with prominent clove and lavender. Clearly masculine, it...

Don't worry my friend, you're far from old, rather you carry most of the young vegetables, those pretenders who can only assert themselves with a quick, cheap fireworks display, easily in your pocket. You generously spread out on my skin, even bringing a note of inflatable beach toys at the beginning, is that youthful mischief? Throughout your not short life, you show me what...

I'll keep it short. It smells like really good soap, like freshly washed but not over-perfumed. I will wear this as a woman too, because it is not typically masculine, but neutral and very, very pleasantly clean, as if you just came out of the bathroom. I only know very few perfumes categorized for men, but I must say, I have rarely smelled such an elegant one. I can't pick...

review_title: The best is only good enough for us.
review_content: Many thanks to the many and sometimes wonderful comments and commentators before me. I should mention that I have succumbed to G-Man by Gainsborough, his charisma and power, and have become a loyal follower for many years. A fragrance composition like I could only imagine in my dreams, perhaps it was conceived and created in them as well. Developed in the noble barrique (bottle), it unfolds its precious bouquet (scent), impressive in the finish (longevity) and glowing red like lava (sillage), you acquire a friend for life. Come to the flickering fire and unfold yourself in our circle, G-Man.

review_title: Powdered Soap of the Old School
review_content:
What a soapy scent! Just from that, one can guess from which era G-Man originates.
A fragrance that is certainly not for everyone. Normally, I am not someone who believes that certain scents can only be worn by older gentlemen (I have been wearing Tabac Original for almost 2 years at 22), but G-Man can, may, and should only be worn by older men. Without the appearance of an older gentleman, G-Man simply would not come across as authentic enough.

Now to the scent itself. It is truly astonishing that G-Man is supposed to be ONLY an Eau de Cologne. To me, it is as strong as an Eau de Toilette.
G-Man starts off spicy and leathery. After a while, it begins to turn powdery, but not in the sweet and soft way like Dior Homme. No, no! It is a bitter and old-fashioned powderiness, combined with the soapy note that makes G-Man truly an "old-schooler"! After a long-lasting presence, the powdery note fades, but the soapiness remains until the end. The moss and leather notes then slowly fade away.

One day I will wear it. G-Man, we will meet.

review_title: When is a man a man
review_content:
Even back then, as a young woman, I was completely puzzled not only by the name (no details) but also by this scent.

Alongside the Russian leather, it has never failed to make an impression. I must admit, this seems to have not changed to this day.

A noble masculine fragrance that can transform a reserved romantic into a fierce feline. It simply has that certain something. It smells fresh, elegant, and at the same time provocative. The composition is so harmonious that I can pick out the individual notes, yet they are excellently intertwined.

Short hair, long hair, no hair

Tummy or not

Beard or not

With this fragrance, there's no need to make a man look good by drinking. With this scent, he already shows plenty of taste, and if he lets me sniff it, even more so :-D.

When is a man a man: You know the answer.

The sillage is just right, and the longevity, it holds and holds what it promises. Bet :-D.

A tough perfume with a soft guy... For real gentlemen (G-Men?) of the old school, with a three-day beard or more, in the midst of life, married for the third time :D Very mature perfume, it has classic potential, very good for dates with more mature women I think...not for the dignified everyday life, maybe just suitable for working suit wearers... Subtle moss, combined with...

G-Man has completely passed me by until recently. There are several reasons for this: On the one hand, because I had such a good memory of Exception by Gainsboro and I didn't want to let that go with G-Man. On the other hand, there is the truly terrible bottle in my eyes. Black and gold as a combination strikes me as unattractively old-fashioned and very difficult. It just...

In the mid-80s, when I was still a young lad, I got my hands on a sample of G-M. Of course, I was far too young for such a bold fragrance, but I could no longer run away from IT. In no time, the sample was empty, and the last scent atoms were sucked away. Since I was still in school at that time, I had my older (and working) sister gift me this fragrance. The waiting time...

It's so great!!! I like it sooo much!!!!! This is the seduction - the right scent for a vintage porn in the afternoon. When the decor is antique and dark, wearing a matching little dress.... then one is gladly persuaded to have what is called coffee....

review_title: What is more masculine than G-man
review_content: ........... what is more masculine than G-man?? for me, not much. I started 12 years ago with my dad's shower gel, which smelled so masculine, so distinctive, simply strong in my nose!!! Then I slowly started to empty his natural spray :-) until I finally received it as a birthday gift and have been wearing it again and again ever since. For me, it expresses confidence and strength :-) Men who take care of themselves wear "G-man" in my eyes/my nose :-) simply dreamy this scent.

review_title: Etienne Aigner No.2..a different take..and yet the same ;)
review_content:
G-man is truly the "twin brother" of Etienne Aigner No.2!!!
The Aigner scent was the first one in my life. My mom (who has always been on top of beauty trends) gifted it to me when I was the tender age of 16 *g*. I loved it!!! This freshness.....this longevity...sprayed once in the morning...and I was the well-scented boy next door all day long ;)))

Even today I still occasionally get a bottle...for sentimental reasons ;)....thanks to Rossmann, it's also available at a good price now ;))

So...
...and G-MAN is, in my opinion, from the exact same fragrance family as No.2 by Aigner.
Just a bit more aggressive...and EVEN longer-lasting!

As is often the case, it's best to apply it sparingly here as well...otherwise it will take your breath away ;)

But, also highly recommended!!!
For "daily wear"....at the workplace & so...... always a pleasure;))

G-Man was the first fragrance I consciously noticed in my adolescence. It must have been in the spring of 1987, and I have been unable to resist the fascination of this refreshing, distinctly masculine scent ever since. This is MY fragrance, and it can still be easily ordered at Douglas. G-Man is long-lasting and can be worn excellently both at work and on special occasions....

Or better said, at the second sniff. ;-)

G-Man meant nothing to me until a few weeks ago.
I was in a perfume store and the scent was behind me, SALE...

The matter was settled. (I thought).

User Terra suggested I test Azzaro and G Man, as they should be good in terms of longevity.
