review_title: Ultra-Masculine Classic with a Soap Aroma
review_content:
Thanks to a tip from a friend and the rather good yet ambivalent comments, I've been circling around G-Man by Gainsboro for two weeks now and have tested it repeatedly... The perfume initially smells very harsh, dry, and piercing, somewhat like the yellow toilet blocks you might remember from old urinals....

One might think that can't be pleasant, but if you don't smell it directly on the skin, but from a certain distance, the perfume smells completely different.... noble, soapy, masculine, and simply good....

When smelled directly on the skin, I find that the perfume doesn't really register... it smells somewhat chemical, like gunpowder or somewhat metallic... I find that very unfortunate, as the scent from a distance is much more harmonious than the skin scent... this makes it less pleasant for the wearer, or at least for me, almost exhausting. You think, wow, who smells so good when the wind blows from the opposite direction, but when you smell it directly on the skin, you think (or I do...), who or what stinks here?

The scent strikes me as a mix of Aigner No. 2 and Kouros, which also has that toilet block aroma. All very masculine and very successful perfumes, but not so easy to wear in today's times. Among the three, I find Aigner No. 2 the most agreeable, as it becomes softer in the end and the toilet block aroma is hardly noticeable here.

Nevertheless, I find G-Man very interesting and at prices around €19 for 100 ml EDT plus shower gel, I can hardly resist a purchase. It is a true classic, so complex that one can hardly unlock the individual notes. With this different scent effect for the wearer and bystanders, it comes off almost modern.... similar effects can be found in modern fragrances with Iso-E-Super or Ambroxan... they also come across quite differently for the wearer than for those around them...

Longevity and sillage are insane for an old classic and outshine many EDPs by far.

review_title: I think I am still too young for this...
review_content: ... I can't say that I don't like the scent, on the contrary, it's actually very good, but I think I am still a bit too young for this fragrance in my early 20s because I always associate such scents with my father's fragrances. Therefore, I currently give the scent 70%, but I will revise my rating here in 15-20 years and I think then the fragrance (if it still exists) will...

This fragrance reminds me of my youth. Back then, we often had Mon Cherie by Ferrero for my mom. Of course, as an 8-year-old, I wasn't allowed to drink alcohol, but I found the pink glittery paper in which the praline was wrapped so beautiful that I had to try the precious drop (hic : ) ) Naturally, I didn't like the cherry flavor. At first, the scent strongly reminds me of this childhood association. Alcohol in which cherries have been drowned (top note). After that, the fragrance develops very elegantly. The vanilla stands out and blends the skin molecules into a delicate skin scent. In the dry down, I still perceive a hint of cocoa that makes the fragrance more lasting. Musk gently caresses the spirit. The scent is very delicate and very refined. Unfortunately, it is no longer available.

First, the good news: if you want my opinion, I see almost no difference between the “vintage” and the more recent version of Dreamer. I said “almost” so I’m not saying they’re identical – the vintage smells a bit more natural, slightly darker and smoother, without the synthetic harshness of the recent (current?) version you can smell loud and clear at its very opening; but since in a matter of minutes it goes away and the scents perfectly “tunes in”, I think the two versions are 99% equivalent overall – just use a little patience with the more recent one. The drydown is pretty much identical, I surely don’t get any “ruined” juice as I read online about the current version. This said, the scent itself is just an excellent piece of modern perfumery. Almost nondescript for me, and it took me a while to “understand” it: it smells just really beautiful, uplifting and terribly pleasant. I don’t get how did they make it precisely, but all works perfectly. I smell tobacco (cigarette type), lavender, spices (Jaipur Homme’s kind of Oriental, talc-infused sweet spices), a clever touch of something balsamic-green, but most of all I smell overall a fantastic feel of cleanliness, peace, fulfillment with a really peculiar “ambiance” halfway naturally and earthy, and so clean and slightly musky it almost smells futuristic.

I usually can’t stand reviews romanticizing scents and I try to avoid mentioning feelings and suggesting “images”, but this time I can’t help it, as Dreamer has a really strong evocative quality for me – evoking this sense of neat, clean, “natural versus artificial” brightness with a fantastic shade of “barbershop” notes and a touch of Oriental mystery. The way they’re blended makes the difference here, Dreamer is incredibly harmonic and compact, there’s just a perfectly consistent unique smell that smells of, well, “Versace Dreamer” and that’s it. This fragrance has them almost all – it’s elegant, versatile, but at the same time informal and fun, and has a really nice set of shades and a subtle “enigmatic” vein, I guess due to its Oriental notes. An easy-going but fascinating “chiaroscuro”. Plus I think it brilliantly takes inspiration from several families of perfumes – from classic tobacco-floral fragrances like Zino Davidoff, to dandy Oriental gems like Jaipur Homme, both under a decidedly “younger”, more modern light. An outstanding work of synthesis of many diverse inspirations, brilliantly projected into the future. Excellent creativity, excellent skills to give it shape. But above all, it smells just fantastic – the vintage version does it since the very first spray, with the recent one you’ve to wait some 15-20 minutes, but then it works as good as the previous one. Easily the nicest Versace ever for men, together with L’homme from 1984 (which is as good as conventional and a bit outdated for me though, while Dreamer is way more timeless – or more precisely, completely “out of time”).

8-8,5/10

There are very good reasons for owning a bottle of Versace´s The Dreamer, starting with the bottle itself. It is stunning, with that acid finished Medusa, the greek gold frieze ornament... from all the perfumes of the brand this one channels the most the spirit of Gianni Versace and the golden age of fashion and supermodels. It is unique and alluring.

It has a very fresh start, aromatic lavender and citrus, astringent and invigorating... i particularly enjoy the election of mandarin in this case over other citrics, because its rusty bitterness doesnt feel soo clean and high pitched. Just sprayed, it has a powerful fougere identity, but very soon comes the twist: a warm sensual wave of tonka bean arises to stay until the very end. The Dreamer gives the wrong impression of hesitating between an honest, butch, down-to-earthyness and a pretty, seductive sensuality, and challenges you to figure out. The dry sharp edges of the lavender end in flowery lily petals. It is and adorned macho. I see this easily as a shared fragance, and ecourage ladies to try it.

The fragance as it evolves, looses the pungent aromatic coolness, but gains in herbaceousness: the geranium leaf takes place, strong and muscular. But in this riddle, the sweet tobacco becomes more apparent turning the fougere into something else, calmly sweet,powdery and enveloping.

I feel i am now watching a skyscape, the clouds slowly shapeshift in front of my eyes and get me in a true dreamy mood... In this mid stage ,along with the make-up type of iris root and the dry sweet tobbaco flower, there is an incredibly cacthy, intoxicating scent, that smells synthetic (to me this is not bad) like vynil or play-doh. This rare artificial accord is bitter and conforting and merges seamlessly in the fragance. Is it tarragon? pistachio? what is this?

Sometimes you smell a clean body after the gym, sometimes you smell lipstick, or gasoline.

In the late drydown it gets woodier and ambery, but the balmy touch stays, like an interrogation mark.

As for the longevity , you will wake up the next morning with a drydown that will still keep the full identity of the fragance. Projects very well. The quality of The Dreamer in terms of ingredients and originality is remarkable.

The Dreamer has a soul that feels inspired by art and antiquity, but , as the starry print of the box implies, looks in the eyes of the future and the unexplored galaxies. He is a seeker of beauty and a nerdy kid...and when he looks up to the night sky, sees both the planets and astronomical object as well as the mythologies of the constellations... The Dreamer is a designer, a model, an adventurer and an astronaut.

review_title: Moments of Intense Fear Mixed with Extreme Euphoria
review_content:
Dream on! Yeah, sing with me, sing for the year, sing for the laughter, sing for the tears, sing with me, if it's just for today, maybe tomorrow, the good Lord will take you away. Dream on! Dream On! - Aerosmith.

I've owned a bottle ever since it debuted in 1996, to replace my previous cologne Solo Soprani. Pretty good segue, considering it was considered a light scent and not too dangerous. To this day, I must have a bottle to go back to and "remember." That's why I recently decided to buy it once more when I saw it online for a funny price around 20 something bucks.
The Dreamer depicts the essence of this perfume very nicely because when I wear it, I feel like I'm floating between the dream and the real world. Some notes are pulling me to one side like the clean and light opening, and others like sweet and smoky dry-down to the other. Oh, man! What a beautiful fragrance. It's is one of those fragrances that makes you stop dead in your tracks, in the best possible sense, so unusual, so creative, and just so damn good, in my opinion. I like it when I smell a risky fragrance, one that was not designed to sell to the average consumer, one that is controversial, one that receives complete contradictory reviews. I've concluded that I adore challenging fragrances, and this is no exception if you like Dreamer, another outstanding one to try is L'eau Bleue D'Issey. Man or woman, yes woman, wear this if you want to stand out from the crowd and bask in your uniqueness!

The Dreamer is something of a hybrid between fougère, oriental, and gourmand. It's remarkably light, yet crisp, with hints of sweetness and richness throughout, with that 90's cleanliness keeping it all in check.
The opening is like when you first open a pack of cigarettes, I'm not a smoker, but I always loved the smell of unlit cigarettes, a gorgeous sweet fresh tobacco scent. It is a sheer opening, both warm and refreshing at the same time. which gently enwraps and gives a pleasant sensation of well-being. It is very aromatic, bitter sage and floral lavender blend magically with spicy tarragon, juniper grains, and poisoning artemisia. It's harsh but settles down to a comforting and warm male floral.

The oriental aromatic heart combines notes of waxy and soapy lily and powdery iris that blend in with the amber very smoothly. It's got the fluffy powdery floral note that has a smokey woody masculine undertone. The iris stands out a little more loudly as a member of The Dreamer's heart, with the token geranium and an almost invisible touch of rose rounding it out. It can be cumbersome and in your face in time. Overall, It's got the good, the bad, and the ugly layering all in one. The old formulation was quite powdery. The new one is less powdery and more floral.

The dry down is the most stunning I have smelt in a long time. It has that lovely sweet tobacco smell, with what kind of scents like vanilla and musk, animal musk if you feel it close to your skin. It's that glorious leafy tobacco flanked by tonka and amber, with literally nothing else to get in the way, with maybe cedar aftertouch bringing in some sustain. The tobacco isn't of the already-dried or smoked variety like with some scents, and more of the "raw leaves and blossoms in the sun" kind of feel, lending it an outdoorsy vibe that its other ingredients don't suggest. By the time this reduces to the skin, all you smell are tobacco, amber, coumarin, and wisps of those aqueous florals, including the potent iris coming up for encores when the air hits just right.

The more I smell the Dreamer, the more I fall in love with it. It is the rare fragrance that is beautiful and interesting in all of its phases, although I like the dry down the best. It is unusual, ever-changing, and mysterious. I find myself smelling my wrists very often when I'm wearing this. I do this because it offers a moment of serenity, of inner peace, that takes me away from the bustle and stress of everyday life. It has a gorgeous bottle I might add too, with one of the more unique integrated sprayers I've seen, which becomes the cap rather than fits inside the lid like most of this type. The usual Mediterranean business adorns the cap otherwise, and the bottle itself features the classic Versace Medusa head.

Fall and winter are the best times for The Dreamer. Sillage and longevity are average, so it's going to take some reapplication for an entire day's use, but if you keep this to evenings and weekends, it will get you through all right. If you were going to get just one tobacco-themed designer scent and didn't want to break the bank on something from an exclusive line, this would be a pretty strong contender for that pick. In the wise words of Aerosmith: Dream On!

-Elysium

review_title: Sweet dreams are made of these.
review_content:
There is something about this fragrance that makes me feel so comfortable and relaxed. I would have said it was the lavender but it has been reformulated and there is no lavender in it anymore.
Still this fragrance has the ability to make me feel like i am wrapped up in a bed of soft feathers and ready to dream away.

I often spray this at night when i am having trouble sleeping and feeling stressed as i toss and turn trying to get my much needed beauty sleep. It just says to me, soft, comfortable linin and at the same time there is something masculine about it which i think could be the tobacco flower.

Some people called the original the washing machine detergent fragrance because of all the lavender scented detergents out there today and is probably why they changed things up a bit because you don't want that to be the association of the last fragrance that was created by Versace himself before his untimely passing. Even though the lavender is not there anymore there is still a resemblance to that kind of scent which is probably why people get that feeling of relaxation and comfort from it.

The Dreamer has this ability to transform the way your clothing feels. You could be wearing that horrible scratchy wool everyone hates, but with one spray of this it would make it feel like you are suddenly wearing some of the softest materials on Earth. It really is amazing how this fragrance works on more than just the sense of smell by affecting other senses also. I find i feel like my skin is softer when i wear this.

I love the bottle with the frosted medusa head, it looks very classy and the atomizer is one of, if not the best in my collection. Both in the design and the performance from it as it gives out an amazing blast of juice that is well distributed.

The price is amazing, you can always find it on sale at reputable stores from the RRP of roughly £50 for 100ml down to roughly £25 and it is absolutely worth it.

It's not something you will find yourself wearing on a night out because longevity is just not there so unless you have a way to bring it with you and keep respraying you are always going to find something else in your collection for that purpose. No, this is for as i said previously at night, relaxing at home as i often see many other people say they use this every night before they go to bed as it makes them have a good nights sleep and it definitely has a great name for such a thing.

When i first got it i couldn't help keep respraying it i loved it that much but now i like to keep it for those nights where i am feeling anxious about something as it will instantly have that calming affect on me.

If you don't have this in your collection you should go for it because for the price i don't think you will find anything else quite like it. I have a number of fragrances that smell similar in some way to each other, but i can't say the same about The Dreamer.

The Dreamer was a fragrance that I was not overly fond of when I first tried it. The combination of the aromatic, camphorous accord which results from lavender and juniper and the sweetness seemed to clash with the underlying tobacco note.

I had the same reaction to Bogart pour homme, which is similar in that it is a sweetened tobacco fragrance and it took me a while before I "got it". It seems a strange thing to say that I did not understand the fragrance, after all shouldn't it be the case that either I like it or not? To answer this hypothetical question, it must be pointed out that senses can be tricked, there are optical illusions so why not olfactory ones? In fact perfumery relies on them.

The Dreamer is not a straight forward scent: it is complex and takes time to appreciate it. The lavender and other notes which give this a sweet camphorous edge battle with the tobacco and leafy notes at the beginning giving it a bit of a chaotic start, but when they subside slightly the tobacco becomes more obvious and the scent becomes more balanced. The initial sweet notes continue to fade for a long time like the gradual diminishing of the light in summer.

The fragrance lasts very well and has good projection.

I like The Dreamer very much and am glad I persevered with it.

review_title: I'm actually quite fond of Versace's Dreamer. But...
review_content: Brace yourselves for the first half. Which is un-apologetically Loud, Crude, and yet Sentimental. A date night scent worthy of a truck-stop diner! It's a cloying blast of synthetic and powdery floral cliches, made doubly brash next to a (cigarette) tobacco note. Boldly unsophisticated, but never insincere. This is either a real Cowboy's misty-eyed idea of romance - Handing her...

Oh boy, first of all, Versace Dreamer was Gianni Versace last creation, back in 1996, for his own house, Gianni Versace/departament: Versace Profumi.
He would be murdered a year later, in 1997, and the history was written.
This was an bold and very creative creation. An neo/ mid 90s fougere with accent on tobacco flower and original leaves, mixed to perfection with lavender, neroli/petitgrain, some dusty sandalwood or some woods on the back bone and of course something that creates that sophisticated aura thats still original, even after 27 years, now...
I aint know the older bottles, but certanly i know the current 2011 and up formulation.
Its great, but i wish i had an old bottle, older than 2010, to see there are some changes or not.
All in all, a very stilysh fragrances, perfect longevity, beautiful aura sillage and projection, for those who needed.
I will hunt and find a vintage version for The Dreamer, in this live, for sure!

Versace Dreamer captured my heart immediately back in 90s. At the time I had just purchased Versace blue Jeans, but the Dreamer smelt more mature and carried a "let's go out in the night" vibe that I loved. Fast forward 20 years later and with my rejuvenated enthusiasm for scents I purchased a new bottle of Versace dreamer. This fragrance is also subject to debate about...

Complex and multifaceted. Florals, pipe tobacco, amber, spices and soapy tonka.
Dreamer opens with a pretty vinagrette-like bittersour chemical blast of... tobacco? Comes on sort of like a smoky wet dog or wool. Passing through the heart you slowly enter the realm that in my (and apparently also others) opinion is the best part, the drydown. It's kinda oriental and in this stage I find it to have some slight similarities to the original D&G pour Homme.

No doubt, this scent is pretty unique and probably was even more so when it was first released. There's no way you can complain about the performance vs. price ratio here, as it's quite cheap to get a hold of most places, but also even in the newer formulation very powerful in regards to both sillage and longevity - sometimes bordering on nuclear, depending on setting and temperatures. No doubt this will be cloying in the summertime, but quite fitting for a winter or fall evening.

Overall, I'd say that I used to like it but since I got Feuilles de Tabac by Miller Harris I feel that FdT is a more contemporary version of Dreamer, without the sort of old-schoolish Versace PH vibe.

Still, this one holds his own.

I don’t know anyone who has a neutral opinion on this perfume, it’s either an underrated gem or a stinky mess, no in between. I happen to fall in the former camp.

I’ll give the haters one thing: the opening is not great. There is something muddy, messy and harsh about it that it’s sadly gonna turn must people away. It’s kinda like hot glue mixed with some sort of cleaning product, but if you let it dry down for a couple minutes then the magic starts to happen. The mid of this fragrance is something truly hypnotic, as someone said in a different review, it smells purple, like purple clouds to be exact, it is truly entrancing. The dry down is a bit less interesting but it is still quite good, it just smells sweet and fluffy. The name The Dreamer truly describes what this fragrance smells like.

This is an outsider in the current landscape of fragrances for men. It’s a masculine floral, it smells feminine, and it smells old. In a world dominated by fresh blue fragrances and gourmands this has no place, but that’s what makes it more unique. It takes the right kind of man to pull off The Dreamer in this day and age, but if that sounds like you then you should try it out, it’s super cheap.

I’d be lying if I said I was always in the mood for this, it is not a dumb reach and it needs just the right weather to shine, but when I do wear it it becomes my favorite fragrance during the couple hours it lasts.

Please give it a chance if you can, embrace it, let it transport you. After a while even the stinky opening will become charming.

The perfume of my youth! I lost it, but I rediscovered it! Wore it in the time when the name wasn't so much for me, but the smell itself.
I always imagined (me as a) Yves Montand, with its cigarette in the corner of the mouth, wearing this gem.
Tobacco note is peerless and the lavender complete it so good! Citrusy, fresh and cool. I can't get why some people said that it's sweet or unisex. Not sweet at all, on the contrary! Manly, yes! Classy and expensive smell, a piece of art from an italian more refined than french creators.
Bravo Versace!

The Dreamer is a unique and special fragrance. So unique that even the tobacco is different from what you're used to. It's a tobacco flower based scent. Also, it's the last creation under the direction of Gianni Versace shortly before is assassination.
Another thing that is kinda mysterious is the note breakdown. You'll get a different note breakdown in every website. To me, Dreamer starts out very sour and synthetic, yet addictive! It drys down surprinsingly alluring and mysterious.
I remember the first time I smelled this one, i hated the opening. But after 10min I started to like it. I ended up buying a bottle. After 3 years I can say that I love this. It's definitely unique and dreamy.
Talking about the scent itself: I smell a herbal-aromatic note (juniper and tarragon) at the start. It's kinda harsh but vicious. After 10min the tobacco flower starts to bloom. After 1h the cumarin joins the game and the scent turns more sweet, alluring but still kind of floral.
This stage will be the ending one. The dream is over but not until the 10-12 hour mark. This one has great performance and strong projection in the first 2 hours. Also, it performs greatly on clothes as they will smell like The Dreamer for weeks! At this point, I don't know if this it's still in production but you can find it easily online and on many stores.
My advice? Grab a bottle now. It's very cheap (20-30€/100ml) and it's a fantastic scent. A true masterpiece. And the bottle is probably my favorite of all time!
8/10

as i continue to relive my journey of fragrances of the 80s, 90s, This is one of the best fragrances of that era with an amazing and unique dry down. i actually reach out for this when i remember how fantastic and unique this smells. I do think it was reformulated at some point.. but still a a very good smell with good longevity just spray more.
Solid

Sweet tobacco that lasts for a long time, with big sillage and big projection.

That's a great choice for cooler seasons. The price is also very good. Definetely worth a bottle!

Updated January 2014

I bought this as a blindbuy many years ago, I was attracted to the luxurious opulent bottle design. I love Versace clothes, furniture and fragrances.

This is by far the best fragrance from Versace I have ever smelled.

The first time I smelled this, there was no youtube, insta or fragrance influencers to already make up my mind on fragrances, I was really excited to smell this.

The scent is perfect. It projects really well from the start, and all I can smell is rich, soapy, creamy opulence. I have never smelled any other fragrance that smells this clean and soapy, Versace really nailed this.

Other fragrances that are supposes to have the same soapy-creamy scent, is nowhere near this masterpiece. They often have too much spices, cinnamon or are not that well blended. This is so smooth, and I have nothing bad to say about it. I wish it could last forever, the performance is pretty good, heavy projection for 3-4 hours and last up to 9 hours on my skin.

I want to wear this everyday, all year.

I got this as a blind buy and its great for how cheap it is. Soft floral, clean and soapy and i get a bit of pine personally too. The florals, freshness and the aromatic characteristics makes it old school-ish but definitely not dated. Elegant/formal but casual meanwhile, very versatile in my opinion. Doesnt last that long on my skin but its just such a calming lovely scent....

It's a nice fragrance, Herbal, Floral and Green. This is a new reformulation but The Lavender and The Tobacco notes are dominant in this perfume and reminds me of Dolce &Gabbana Pour Homme, It is more lighter. The Dreamer opens up with like fresh green and floral notes in the background then dry down is ambery woody. It is perfect for the all seasons. The art of bottle design is very beautiful. I like The Dreamer EDT for Men by versace.
Rating : 7.5 / 10

Holy crap,this was impressive I been wearing it a lot and I’m not getting sick of it’s pretty mellow for a tabbaco scent and I only paid 25$ for it,this is a fragrance everyone should check out, everything about this fragrance is great but I recommend 6 sprays because it’s not so overpowering but it unfortunately does not have great longevity,the bottles slick nothing...

review_title: Wish it would be more powerful
review_content: Its a scent which i like very much but the problem is that it lacks in terms of being strong. After i spray it on my skin, it becomes skin-nearly even in 30 minutes. Its not a perfume that people will notice you easily. The scent gives me a feeling of freshness, when I bought it the smell reminded me of the after shave smell when my grandpa left the bathroom when I was a child. About versatility, its very versatile, can be worn all seasons in my opinion. I blind bought it and i dont regret it. The only thing that i miss is that it could be more powerful in sillage longevity and projection as i mentioned above. But if you want a fragrance for work, office, or just to smell like you jumped out of the shower, its the best you can buy. I would give a massive 8/10.

This great fragrance to me smells 3 dimensional with depth and personality. It's not your simple straightforward scent, you have to wait and be patient for the dry down before you can appreciate that sweet fresh rolling tobacco note that I love. Couple of sprays and I can smell it all day. This has always been in my collection because it works on my skin like no other...

Very good floral scent for men. If there is a blue fragrance, this is gonna be a purple fragrance. Smells like very good fabric softener. Creamy, floral, but gave me a little bit of a headache for some reason. For the price, this is a steal. Also, doesn't smell dated, or old-school, or "something an old guy would wear".

I finally purchased and original The Dreamer with the cosmic design on the box. I remember this at TJ Maxx around 1999 and could not bring myself to even touch a bottle as I was still in morning of its creator. I was also inundated with the Jean series and was confused as to why this was ever released. Looking back as the dust settled and the tears dried, this was the major...

The output is too strong for my taste, a penetrating smell similar to camphor, which makes me itch as if it were a small allergy. Already in the dry down this fragrance shows its potential. It is a slightly powdery floral with a sweet but very subtle base... Smell of modest and clean flowers. The truth is that it seems like a very unisex scent to me. Good stay on my skin,...

Ein sehr Frischer nicht zu Aufdringlicher Duft, er erinnert mich Jedes mal an meinen Kroatien Urlaub, wo ich ihn gekauft habe!
Trotz Designer Namen verhältnismäßig billig. Ich bin zu 70% mit der ersten Flasche durch und würde mir auf jeden fall eine 2te oder 3te Flasche kaufen.
Jedes mal wieder liebe diesen Duft!

There is a note in this cologne that makes me nauseous. Maybe it's the tobacco flowers? However, i rated the cologne highly because I can smell that the cologne has a nice balance of flowers and herbal touches. If I smell it faintly on other people it smells nice, but even one spray on myself, I quickly get a headache and have to wash off. I keep trying every once in a while. But same effect.

Does anybody have this same reaction?

I bought it as a blind buy from the $19.00 shelf at Shoppers drug mart.

Fragrances are not made like this anymore! I read and hear more and more... With this nonsense, it runs through my marrow and bone, and I ask myself, isn't it fine? At the beginning, yes, there it is already, Juniper, Artemisia, and tarragon. In the heart, the iris, lily, and flax, make the fragrance a fine Max. And over time, amber and tobacco sneak in, making the scent...

Disclaimer: I am an older gentleman in advanced retirement age who has worn fragrances for personal enjoyment throughout his life. I possess neither an analytical nose nor professional background knowledge, nor the urge to remain as objective as possible in reviews, as this seems hardly feasible with fragrances.

When the first days of August have passed, one sometimes sits at the evening garden table, enjoys a glass of Portuguese red wine, and reminisces.
One reflects on the summer, takes stock of whether one has used their brief time on earth wisely and meaningfully in the past weeks, and doesn’t even notice how the gaze is gently drawn to a dark corner of the garden, which, however, does not appear gloomy at all, but rather promising.
There, at the very end, still behind the vegetable beds and herbs, the most delicious blackberries on earth grow on an old fence - probably for over a hundred years.
And then one stands up, walks slowly over there, smells them, and looks forward to the small harvest of the coming weeks.

In my eyes, hardly any fragrance captures the garden theme as wonderfully as Versace's The Dreamer.
Its fruity sweetness has such a delicate charm that it almost creatively intertwines with the herbal aromas. I consciously do not want to pinpoint individual notes in this Eau de Toilette, but rather let the entire garden affect me.

Not one of those dreadful concrete gardens with DIY store potted plants in antique design pots, nor a over-designed show garden with koi ponds and wooden bridges - no, I am talking about a real garden like the ones found at grandparents' homes, where hundreds of colors and scents rain down on a small person, with cherry and apple trees, where cucumbers grow, the brown-yellow leaves of the trees cover the lawn, and old wooden planks rot on the bank of a small village stream.

Perhaps this image is as kitschy as the synthetic nature of this fragrance, perhaps because the present has become too hectic to allow such gardens with all their back-breaking work to survive, perhaps we sometimes react cynically to this form of niceness, and perhaps I love Versace's The Dreamer all the more for this reason.

It should be mentioned that this fragrance also seduces with one of the most tasteful bottles on the market and a very attractive price, without wanting to diminish the beauty of the actual scent in the slightest.

...and that was almost exactly 20 years ago. My God, where has the time gone? Back in 1996, while flipping through a magazine, I stumbled upon a small article. Versace was releasing a new fragrance. "The Dreamer," what a name. And what a bottle! And what a price :-( Unaffordable for a student like me. I believe it cost almost DM 100.00.

I couldn't test it anywhere. No perfumery near me carried this scent. Very exclusive. So I didn't even know what it smelled like, yet I desperately wanted to own this fragrance. Finally, at Christmas, the moment arrived. Under the Christmas tree lay a small package, and inside... a pair of socks. Just kidding. Of course, it was "The Dreamer." A box that looked like a painting! Large, square, black, with blue in the middle (the Milky Way?), and golden stars shining everywhere. A bottle so beautiful that it could be displayed in a museum and a scent that smelled exactly as it was named. Powdery, sweet, very high-quality and sensual. So completely different from anything I had smelled before. I was overjoyed. I used "The Dreamer" for many years until I somehow / somewhere / sometime lost track of it. That's just how life is. Out of sight, out of mind, as they say. And sometimes that's for the best. Why? You might guess.

"The Dreamer" is now produced by EUROITALIA. They only make junk. In other words, primitive slush. They ruined "Blue Jeans" too. The COTY of Italy. In the past, the company "Giver Profumi Milano (Versace Profumi)" was responsible for the Versace fragrances. But that must have become too expensive for the management. And where do you cut costs? Exactly! It's just a perfume, and the stupid customer won't notice anyway. HAH !!

You can now get "The Dreamer" for € 17.99 at Rossmann. A more than clear indication and the reason for this kind of open letter. All fragrances (excluding the teen brands) available at Rossmann are reformulated to the max. Dead scents. Empty shells adorned with the aura of big names. But they are what they are: cheap flirts. It pains my soul that my Dreamer has now become one of them. € 17.99 !! That's street corner.

I strongly assume that most here did not know the original scent, but only tested the shadow of it. Then I can understand the critical comments. The real Dreamer was a true Versace. The last fragrance of the master. Before he too went to the stars.....

Howgh - I have spoken

review_title: A Journey Through Space and Time
review_content:
France. November 29, 1825. A boy is born in Paris. He is named Jean-Martin. He will one day revolutionize the field of expertise. No, not in perfumery. He will turn the world of conventional medicine upside down one day. We are talking about Jean-Martin Charcot.
In 1882, he becomes the chief physician of his own neurology ward at the Salpêtrière. The first in Europe, in fact. As a professor, he trains other doctors who later achieve great things as well. Georges Gilles de la Tourette (Tourette syndrome) is among his students, as is a certain Sigmund Freud (psychoanalysis). Charcot himself spends most of his time working on the phenomenon of hysteria alongside neurological fundamentals. When it comes to neurological insights, he is very successful and can identify (isolate) diseases such as MS, ALS, HMSN, Charcot's triad I and II, Erb-Charcot disease, and many others. His discoveries also have an impact on other areas of conventional medicine. His work on hysteria even influenced the development or reform of therapeutic approaches in alternative medicine. For in his research on hysteria, he often applied hypnosis. He believed that patients under hypnosis could detach themselves from the "here and now" and thus gain better insights into the backgrounds of their suffering. They are able to glide through "space and time" and "dig up" subconscious thoughts as well as memories from the distant past. We experience something similar when we dream.

"Dreams"; this also serves as a transition to "Versace - The Dreamer".
The alternative medicine has already been mentioned. Among other things, it includes the possibility of aromatherapy, which aims to treat physical or emotional disturbances using essences. Through aromas, one can also create trance sessions or guided imagery journeys. This very principle is utilized by The Dreamer. Certain ingredients are meant to put us into a dream state. Unfortunately, the main ingredient is not listed in the above fragrance description. Yet it is responsible for this imaginative journey. It is the clary sage. Clary sage is often used in aromatherapy for séances, where letting go and release are desired. It can also expand consciousness. The optimal condition for dreams or daydreams. On a physical level, it has a relaxing and antispasmodic effect. In Versace's Dreamer, clary sage is enriched with lavender and bergamot. These two essences share a chemical similarity with clary sage: the combination of linalyl acetate and linalool. They make up well over half of the respective oil, sometimes 90% or more. Furthermore, this note is developed into a chord with juniper, sage, and nutmeg. Especially nutmeg also has the ability to influence consciousness and even induce visions up to hallucinations (Hildegard of Bingen - "Physica"). If various floral notes are added to this chord, it creates something like a base. But only almost. The most important component for forming a base is hidden in the base notes. The amber, presumably enhanced with tobacco, combines with the aforementioned chord to form a base. It is indeed a very harmonious base because clary sage in the fragrance resembles amber due to some molecules present in both aromas. It should also be noted regarding the floral notes that daffodil likely plays a certain role. Daffodil plays a role in aromatherapy, which is very desirable here. It helps to overcome self-imposed barriers and stimulates creativity. Even though I couldn't identify daffodil here, it is possible that it plays at least a minor role alongside geranium and other flowers. Through other ingredients, which cannot all be listed here due to space constraints, the end result is a perfume that lives up to its name.

Contrary to all previous assumptions and conjectures, this scent is more natural than synthetic. It's just that the linalyl acetate/linalool component in clary sage, lavender, and bergamot gives a slightly medicinal impression, which many noses classify as synthetic. However, it can be described as airy, sterile, and pure. Particularly lavender possesses this characteristic. So much so that the plant was named after it. Lavare means nothing other than "to wash".

Synthetic or not. Ultimately, The Dreamer is a fresh fougère with an emphasis on clary sage over a floral-spicy heart note. Most of the time, it is quite light and airy, and it fades away so airy thanks to the special amber note. A fragrance that, although composed for men, I believe women can wear just as well. It does remind one a bit of the eternal expanses of the universe. Just like a dream, hidden in the cosmos. So to speak: Behind the moon, just left, a few light-years away, past a black hole, where it is beautiful and full of love. And no fear of the black hole. Thoughts and dreams are not attracted to it.

The whole thing somewhat reminds me of music from the 80s. Neue Deutsche Welle. There was a "Golden Rider" over the city. A man saw the "starry sky". A woman saw "99 red balloons" drifting toward the horizon. Who knows, maybe with the help of "The Dreamer," we can take off one day and be "Completely Detached" from the earth. On the way back from the "Rocket in a Rush," we might bring back love. Like the girl from back then, who would later become Germany's most successful musician.

In accordance with the music that I feel reminded of, I hereby give an 80. Maybe more when I find my way back to earth. This refers to the missing earth note. A hint of moss or a bit more vetiver would be perfect. Because even after the sweetest dreams and the most beautiful imaginative journeys, time catches up with us "somehow." We usually only remember that we were "somewhere" not long ago. We wake up and have to get up "sometime" again. Then it would be very advisable to have solid ground under our feet. But this solid ground, the earth, is missing in this composition. But that is just a small drop of bitterness. Nobody is perfect.

In this sense: "DREAM SOMETHING BEAUTIFUL"

Today I discovered a package at my fragrance dealer with the label "The Drummer".

That fits perfectly with my drummer friend, who already has his birthday in January - barely after Christmas.

But the Versace scent reminds me of my dear friend's upcoming birthday celebration.

This Versace will delight my Little Drummer Boy.

As I take the little box in my hand, I decipher "The Dreamer".
But I'm also right about that, as my friend is a dreamy nature - a dreaming drummer, so to speak.

Dreaming and calm, a pleasant lavender note greets me - beautifully old school.
Also fitting, as my friend is a gentleman of the "old school".
He always brings flowers with him on every visit - quite chivalrous.

Tarragon and juniper appear subtly spicy.
Delicate floral notes mix in - rounded off by soft amber.

An unusual men's fragrance - gentle and masculine at the same time.

The calm that The Dreamer radiates also makes it a good bedtime treat - which will have a sleep-inducing effect.

Perhaps The Dreamer will also bring sweet dreams?

That was the title of a book and the miniseries based on it in the mid-80s, both extremely successful at the time. The content is of little importance; it was about the life’s work of an ambitious woman, about love, revenge, hatred, intrigues. Pure drama. And that is what Versace's (back then still Gianni, remember?) The Dreamer is all about. Drama. Life. Bitter. Sweet.

Versace was basically suspicious to me back then, and fundamentally, nothing has changed. Loud and nouveau riche, bling-bling, Medusa heads, practically Glööckler in the 90s, the bottle is quite harmless! And yet - The Dreamer was one of the first men’s fragrances that dared to be sweet, really sweet. There’s no comparison to the flood of cheap sweet scents that haunt us today - no, it’s definitely a rounded fragrance that develops - from floral-smoky (Lily! Who else used lily for men back then?) to fragrant-rough (Rose! That too! And tobacco!) to leaden-numbing sweet (Tonka! Amber! Cedar!). That was shocking, that was a surprise twenty years ago!

The Dreamer. It’s provocative, on the verge of vulgarity, no, actually beyond it. High longevity, sillage almost disturbing, synthetic aromas can do a lot when you let them. It lures, heats up, signals availability - 'will fuck on first date' to spray on. Yet it’s so comforting sweet, intimate and - yes, very beautiful - that one forgives it any cheapness. A scent for boys and not for men. Sweet like Bailey's. Porn. Unfortunately awesome.

Conclusion: in the words of Rosenstolz: 'I am now. I am here. I am me.'

When thinking of the big fragrance houses and popular perfume brands, Versace is rarely mentioned at the beginning. After all, most scents from this brand seem to be permanently on sale. However, I had never seen one in a store: The Dreamer receives practically no attention from Versace, even though it is produced regularly. I had imagined that it would smell rather outdated...

A men's fragrance that couldn't be more special. A name that couldn't be more fitting. Like a timeless relic, whose era has long passed, yet seems to endure through all times. A scent that could waft over the fields and plains of Tuscany, as the wind rustles the dry stalks and carries the fine aroma of hay bales into the emerging night sky. The fragrance, which mingles with...

review_title: The Well-Groomed Man with a Cigarette in Hand
review_content:
That's exactly who I imagine when I spray the fragrance. Do you have him in mind as well? He sat at the bar with his friends all evening, but didn't talk much. He seems to be the quiet type who occasionally drifts off into his own world. However, he is usually up for a social evening. Beforehand, he shaves, showers, and quickly styles his hair to leave a well-groomed impression on those around him. Because that is important to him. He is around thirty years old. Now he stands up, puts on his leather jacket, and moves towards the door to get some fresh air. Once outside, he leans against the wall and lights a cigarette. It won't be long before he goes back inside.

These are the associations that the fragrance evokes in me, without wanting to drag it out. Dreamer is actually a very inoffensive, light fragrance. It smells a bit soapy to me, like soap flakes, and therefore partly reminds me - really only partly - of Mugler Cologne. But why do I say "actually"? Because alongside the soapy base, spicy notes stand out, particularly a distinctly noticeable tobacco note for me. These notes make Dreamer what it is. There are days when I can spray this stuff 8 times and still find it very pleasant and light. On some days, however, the piercing tobacco note bothers me (as a non-smoker) so much that I have no desire for the fragrance. It is also due to the tobacco note that I envision this perfume more for going out or leisure time. Except on very warm days, you can actually wear the fragrance in any season. For some reason, I don't like to wear the fragrance when the sun is shining. It has to be either cloudy or already evening. Even on summer evenings, however, the fragrance should still be wearable due to its moderate sillage. The fragrance has been around for 21 years now and has probably been reformulated several times. However, I don't find it diluted. My 2016 batch lasts about 6-7 hours, with up to 4 hours of moderate sillage. After that, it becomes close to the skin.

So if a man simply wants to smell fresh and well-groomed, while also being in the mood for a cool tobacco note, Dreamer is recommended. By now, it is also quite affordable, which is probably due to the fact that it cannot keep up with current trends. To be honest, I have a better alternative for most occasions.

I was very surprised that The Dreamer is declared as a purely masculine fragrance. In my opinion, it’s almost as unisex as it gets.
Right after spraying it on, I thought to myself that it was a bit too sweet, floral, and generally too feminine for my taste. However, The Dreamer then developed such a pleasant and soft scent that I couldn’t resist and bought it right away.

It is perfect for unwinding, chilling, and diving into a dream world. It has no sharp edges. Depending on one’s perspective, this can be seen as an advantage or a disadvantage.

Of the fragrances I own, this is the one I use the most in my free time. For example, when it’s cold outside and I make myself comfortable on the couch with a good book. I find it very pleasant when this scent dances around my nose as I turn or adjust the blanket.

I would describe the longevity as very good. The mentioned blanket still smells of The Dreamer the next day.
You can also wear it very well in the evening, for example, to go to a café. However, I wouldn’t necessarily recommend it for the disco. There, it gets overshadowed by Le Mâle...

The Dreamer is definitely not for macho types and wannabes. It’s a scent for daydreamers and gentle night owls. Some may find it too soft, but I love it as a fragrance to unwind, as it can have a very calming effect after a long workday.

Unique,
The name "The Dreamer" symbolically reflects the way the fragrance is perceived. The protagonist of this metaphorical scene is a thinker who dares to dream.
Imagine a warm summer night outside on a rise in the woods.
You can see the lights of the city in the near distance. The time doesn’t matter, you pay no attention to it. The church has already announced midnight some time ago, is it already morning?, you don’t think about it. It doesn’t matter, thoughts are free.

There are four of us here, we know each other from vacation, we spent the evening in one of the cozy little bars in the Italian alleys. We’ve made ourselves comfortable, lying side by side on a blanket, all enjoying the same view. It’s not the lights of the night, rather it’s the lights of the stars that we can clearly see above. With our hands under our heads, we all look up.
Soft melancholic music drifts from one of the small groups towards us. Guitars sound, crickets chirp. But everything fades into the background, we enjoy the break from the hectic city.
We let the evening wind down, starting to think, even to dream under the stars.
I spot the Big Dipper, yet my thoughts are elsewhere, not far from the city, but turned inward.
I dare to dream, even without sleeping. Or am I already asleep?, am I dreaming of sleeping?
These thoughts I do not have, I am in the here and now enjoying the melancholic music, the unique atmosphere underscored by nature and the lights.
Whether I am awake or asleep is of no concern to me, for I can certainly dream here.

The fragrance The Dreamer encompasses a truly exceptionally pleasant warmth of tobacco, it is a rather classic men’s scent that is nonetheless unique.
The notes are well balanced and have a certain creaminess. It is a fragrance that is perfect for relaxed evenings or can serve well as a daily scent.
It is by no means intrusive and does not clash.
A very extraordinary scent that inspires dreaming. For all those who want to wear something that not everyone would wear, even with little money.
Suitable for those who do not want plain restraint through aquatic fresh scents or full attention through sweet sugary explosion of spices in everyday life that polarize.
The Dreamer finds the middle ground and is simple elegance with that attention to the simple question of what fragrance one is wearing.
The bottle, a kind of column, from whose upper part a small fountain could flow. A majestic appearance of a sculpture that could stand high above the clouds, among the Greek gods, encompasses the entire artwork of the perfume.
The fragrance fits very well into the overall picture of Versace and was created under Gianni Versace. If Eros is already the Greek fragrance of love, then this is the fragrance of Nyx, the Greek goddess of the night.

I hadn't heard anything about The Dreamer until now, which is probably because it doesn't seem to be on the shelves in stores anymore. But it was included in a decant package that I received from a very dear friend for Christmas (thank you!) and I really liked it. Unfortunately, there aren't many fragrances from Versace that smell this good (in my opinion!), The scent: The...

The fragrance found its way to me because I heard almost only good things about it in some YouTube videos, and the reviews on Parfumo were also positive. I was also surprised by the low price for the bottle, even though a brand like Versace stands behind it.

Therefore, I got the fragrance here as a sample at SOUK and was correspondingly curious.

I can say right away, I was not disappointed.

With the first generous application, I was immediately enveloped by a very pleasant, floral, and slightly sweet scent. It also brings a certain freshness at the beginning that I did not expect.

As the fragrance develops, the initial sweetness subsides a bit, leaving a continued floral impression. But not in a way that it is disturbingly floral. Thank goodness, because I tend to prefer scents that are less so.

In my eyes, the fragrance becomes very "pure" when the sweetness fades. It then has a slightly powdery note, which I find quite pleasant over time.

I definitely classify the fragrance as an all-rounder, as it seems to fit almost any occasion and season. In terms of age group, I would place this fragrance more for men around 30 and older; in my opinion, it is less of a "teenager scent".

It is definitely suitable for the office; even though it reflects well at first, it is not to a disturbing degree.

I would also rate the sillage and longevity as good, especially considering the price. The fragrance lasts a good 5-6 hours on me. The last hours are more intimate.

Even though the fragrance is a bit older, it is by no means outdated or unsuitable for today's times.
I will definitely continue to wear the fragrance and can only recommend to anyone who feels addressed by the fragrance pyramid to give it a chance.

review_title: The Double Test Reveals the Truth
review_content:
Double tests are good. Double tests are important and enlightening...

A "double test" for me involves spraying an unknown fragrance (this one, on the RIGHT) on one forearm and spraying a fragrance that I know well and consider "natural" (in this case "Tuscany" by Aramis) on the LEFT forearm.

This test primarily serves to assess the "naturalness" of a fragrance. It is said that stubbornness increases with age. When it comes to perfumes, this is fully true for me. The more fragrances I test, the more important "naturalness" becomes to me.

The triple quotation marks in connection with "natural" require a brief explanation. By "natural," I mean that I can recognize and distinguish the listed ingredients and perceive a fragrance progression. This is certainly the case with "Tuscany." Lavender, lemongrass, etc., all smell unadulterated and authentic.

With "The Dreamer," however, the perfumer has relied on a single ingredient, let's simply call it "D-500." This stands for the pathetic attempt to synthetically represent softness. Furthermore, Versace has also used "D-600" (spicy-synthetic - in "Versace pour Homme"), "D-700" (fresh-synthetic - in "Eau Fraiche"), and "D-800" (sickly sweet-synthetic - in "Eros"). Additional formulas (aquatic, leathery, citrus) are still in development.

Seriously, Versace has so far created exactly one very good ("Versace l'Homme") and one good ("Versus") men's fragrance. Since "Versus," the concoctions from the "D" series have been bottled as needed.

It's a shame, this was not meant to be a rant, but age-related stubbornness demands its toll. This synthetic stuff just annoys me now. I can't list 16 ingredients in the fragrance pyramid, none of which I can pick out. It's incomprehensible. It's astonishing that the fragrance is already 17 years old. Back then, there were other things. In a blind test, I wouldn't have dated it before 2010.

This fragrance was created in 1996 by Jean-Pierre Béthouart. 1996? Gianni Versace was still alive then! 1996 - I wasn't even in this world yet, and yet this scent evokes a certain nostalgia in me. Oh, how I would have loved to admire Versace's fashion creations and experience the launch of this fragrance myself. But unfortunately, I was born in this millennium. Generation "No Interest".
The bottle is heavenly. Erotic, simple, yet somehow extravagant and very special. I am particularly taken with the milky Medusa head. Luxurious, but definitely not gaudy. The spray nozzle is also very good, although the cap, into which the nozzle is already integrated, could be a bit more "sturdy".
As for the packaging. Dark blue background, a few stars in the distance. In silver, it says Versace - The Dreamer. When you close your eyes, at least I do, you think of a cool summer night, lying on a meadow with your beloved, laughing a lot and admiring the stars. Beautiful and truly dreamy.
But how does this fragrance smell then?
SYNTHETIC. Yes, Versace's The Dreamer smells synthetic, but still beautiful.
At the beginning of the composition, it smells very floral and almost feminine. One has to come to terms with that. Personally, I find it great. The top note becomes a bit more masculine and rounded with slightly spicy notes, which, however, seem to stay in the background.
Then the fragrance becomes a bit "powdery". Quite sweet and perfect for a cool summer night. In my opinion, it also becomes a bit spicier here.
Towards the end, many say that The Dreamer resembles Le Male by JPG. Personally, I only find a similarity with a lot of imagination.

The fragrance has apparently been reformulated multiple times, and I would love to smell the original once.

The longevity is quite good. The sillage is initially very strong but then quickly fades. In my opinion, this fits perfectly with the image of this fragrance. First loud, exciting, and then completely sensual and close.

Versace The Dreamer had been on my wish list for a long time; I have owned it for a few months now. And what can I say? It is the beautifully expected fragrance! The Dreamer is many things at once: powdery (iris, flax), fresh (juniper berry), green (wormwood, tarragon), and floral (lily, tobacco flower). Perfectly balanced. It clearly reminds me of Dolce & Gabbana's "Pour...

review_title: A Dream for All Cheapie Hunters!
review_content: A sweet, floral scent - reminiscent of fresh laundry. The designer and 90s version of Reflection Man by Amouage. With this, you are a true clean guy. Here’s the scene I pick up: It’s Las Vegas in the 90s. Gianni Versace strolls through the streets of the city during the day. He appears relaxed, cheerful, and down-to-earth yet somehow extravagant. The sun is shining, he...

A great Versace fragrance/EdT at more than a fair price. I see it as an office scent. According to some reviews online, it is meant for both ladies and gentlemen. One can see it that way. In my opinion, it has no sharp edges. It is well-rounded. Fresh and elegant at the beginning, then subtly spicy. The elegant note remains until the end. The longevity is quite decent. On me, it lasts about 6-8 hours. At no time is it intrusive or too intense. A modern fragrance for the warmer days.
I really like this scent.

Best regards

review_content: A nearly unclassifiable scent...either you don't know when to wear it, or you like it so much that you can wear it anytime & anywhere... I haven't really decided yet, but I tend to not like it that much...at first, this very powdery scent even gave me a slight headache, but after wearing it several times, I've gotten used to it & I'm starting to like it a bit more or...
