(For all daydreamers and fantasy beings, this scent is just right. It invites you to think in other times, slows down everyday life, and reminds you that there once was a time without mobile phones and smartphones and constant availability. When I smell it, I feel like I'm in slow motion. Calmed by the floral notes. It is too slow for our fast-paced time. A dreamer indeed, and that’s exactly what I love about it! Good night)

"The Dreamer" is a fragrance that truly blew me away. While I am a lover of very woody/smoky scents, "The Dreamer" is one of my favorites despite its sweetness. In the opening, it smells very sweet, but it quickly develops, within a few minutes, into a very masculine scent. The tobacco notes are clearly recognizable. I also perceive patchouli, even though it doesn't seem to be included. The fragrance fits perfectly with a guy from Miami zooming through the hot streets in a Lambo. But it also works on a bike, as an office worker, in Germany. I even wear it sometimes at the gym and have been approached about it multiple times. For me, a fragrance for eternity!

Dark, dark I remember the late 90s when this Versace was still seen relatively often everywhere. In the last 10 years it has practically disappeared and is currently available online in clearance sales.

I thought back then that I found it quite nice in the realm of sweet fragrances, although I was also 15 or 16 at the time, and at that age one tends to naturally find sweet scents like "Le Mâle" and the like absolutely fantastic in a pubescent exuberance.

Well, the reference to Gaultier's sweet sailor is not without reason, as my predecessor GoodSmeller already hints.
"The Dreamer," stylistically really located in the unisex spectrum, spins quite high-speed in the floral-lovely area and is truly not free from synthetics. Vanilla-infused, with a slightly artificial-spicy touch.

By the way, there is a different ingredient list circulating online, which deviates significantly from the above, so Cappellusman may not be unjustly surprised:

Top: Juniper, Lily of the Valley
Heart: Iris, Linen Essences
Base: Amber, Tobacco, Tarragon

This might hit the nail on the head, although the extremely artificial tarragon note in "Dreamer" bothers me just as much as in the "Dolce & Gabbana pour homme," which I don't particularly appreciate.
The overall arrangement feels a bit powdery (Iris?), but rather slightly pasty and bland, lacking the finesse and perfection of a "Dior Homme."

What I perceive as vanilla seems to be more attributed to the above tobacco flower, which sometimes comes across as something like artificial vanilla aroma, floral undertones included.

Overall, it's not a horror in perception, as it's not as loud and detectable from 20 meters away in terms of sillage like "Le Mâle," but ultimately a quiet representative of copying it and not particularly pleasing to the nose.

As the title suggests, the performance of this fragrance is not the best.
Which I find very unfortunate, because the scent is a true experience that you won't find anywhere else.
When you spray it on and smell the top note, you might want to put this fragrance away and look for something else.
But as soon as it has settled a bit on the skin and mingled with your own body scent, a very attractive floral yet seductive fragrance emerges.
I have already received many compliments for this scent, which I never would have believed before.
And the name of the fragrance "The Dreamer" is, in my eyes, a philosophy of life.
From dreamer to doer.

I received this sample from LosPepes as a friendly gesture, sending him warm greetings at this point. First, I want to briefly comment on the bottle, which I find very successful; it's classic, and you can immediately recognize the features that define Versace. For a fragrance that was released in 1996, I think it still appears very present and elegant today. As for the...

HA! Totally caught!! I love Mediterranean herbs, especially those with aromatic, silvery, often delicate foliage. Alongside rosemary and lavender. And juniper scent, preferably from the original blue prickly variety! Exactly these 3 main herbs are united here in a fragrance that is both extraordinary and extravagant as well as wonderfully zesty-spicy, possessing a "blue floral glow" and powerful woodiness.
Perfume makers have to manage this so well that it smells as dreamy as "Versace". A cheerful and down-to-earth romance included. A play of light and shadow in the forest, flower garden, and herb bed. Noble and casual at the same time. Furthermore, nowadays it is worn quite rarely, but for me, it is timeless and something special. Especially "Versace", actually an Italian fashion house, often manages to combine the top quality of several "niche" fragrances with affordable prices. And most scents do not conform to the usual "mainstream", although they often smell quite "pleasant". But here too, the difference lies in the detail. The "little extravagances" :-))

review_title: Ancient Rome, a Meadow, and My Bed
review_content: A little story to begin with, a simple short explanation to end. Referring to the new formulation. Act 1: I spray a lavender relaxation spray on my pillow after I have washed my face cool once more... I fall into my bed, my legs become heavy and the last thoughts rush through my mind... Slowly I notice how I am slowly but surely falling asleep... And before I can write...

I have to say, I have rarely encountered a fragrance that has blown me away as much as this one on the first spray. Unique af. Beautifully floral, slightly sweet, with a lovely green note and so much more. A great clean man scent for daily wearing. For me, The Dreamer is the best fragrance from the Versace line for men, and I find it infinitely more pleasant and charming than Eros. The only thing I would improve is the longevity; on my skin, it lasts 5 hours, and then you need to reapply. It is also quite subtle in terms of sillage.
But what you get here is truly amazing.
1. Very high-quality fragrance
2. Top brand Versace
3. One of the last creations from fashion icon Gianni Versace, and simply a fragrance to feel good in, all for under €25 for the 100 ml bottle!!!!
Chapeau

The Dreamer, what a name! Perhaps the most beautiful name among perfumes.

At just 20 euros for 50 ml, I had to buy it blind… First impression: it smells like a 350 euro niche perfume! And that’s the great thing about it! You get a fragrance that is so unique, almost incomparable to anything else, whether you like it or not.

Upon the first spray, a hefty dose of floral notes hits you, slightly synthetic, but by no means unnatural or bothersome. In the background, a tobacco note slowly but surely unfolds, smelling slightly burnt. The tobacco note increases while the floral aspect diminishes, but it never completely disappears.

It’s hard to describe, as it’s almost incomparable; you just have to smell it yourself.

Fragrance-wise, it’s a 10/10 for me,
but there will certainly be some who can’t relate to it (a friend of mine: “You smell like my grandma’s house”), although I believe most people will like it more than not.

Longevity and sillage are okay, but nothing groundbreaking.

Best worn in the evening when it’s not too hot (e.g., on a cool summer night), but it generally works anytime.

So for under 30 euros, you get a perfume with niche character; there’s nothing comparable in terms of scent, but unfortunately, longevity and sillage are only “okay.”
Still, it’s one of my favorites overall.

This question arises when you see the price of the perfume for the first time.

We are in 2021 and the first summer vacation with my new girlfriend was approaching. Slightly nervous because I wanted to make a good impression, I went to the perfume store a few days earlier with the goal of buying a Prada L'homme, as I was sure she would like it.
Well, since Hanae Mori had planted the thought in my mind not to use standard fragrances, I ended up choosing The Dreamer against the advice of the saleswoman.
In her opinion, this scent was too outdated for a 20-year-old due to its old fragrance DNA (as far as I know, it was even the last fragrance by Gianni Versace himself?) and I would be better off with a Dylan Blue or Eros if I wanted to stick with Versace.
But I decided on this fragrance.
Why?
The scent is fresh but in no way citrusy or shower-gel fresh.
No, it is a beautiful sweet herbal blend with a very pleasant tobacco note, which allows the herbs enough space to unfold, along with a slightly floral note that rounds off the fragrance.

And what can I say, the vacation took us to the small Croatian town of Rovinj. And there, the fragrance felt very much at home!

A small finca, evening sun, a light breeze, a few fruit trees, two glasses of white wine, a light linen shirt, and a beautiful woman. In the midst of it all, “The Dreamer” subtly but perceptible, sweet but not cloying, fresh but far from shower gel.
In a club, this fragrance would go completely unnoticed, but that is not its aim at all; evenings or days like the one described above are its purpose. There, its restrained sillage is just right, as the scent should not overshadow the moment.

My girlfriend still loves the fragrance, and it cannot be missing on our joint vacations.
Who knows, maybe this fragrance laid the foundation for a happy relationship during this vacation because of such evenings.

The Dreamer is a fragrance that has been around for a really long time, and not without reason. This scent is simply wonderful. This lightly floral freshness with a pleasantly spicy character and subtly sweet nuances. It has a bit of an old-school character, but for me, this fragrance is completely timeless. This floral freshness at the beginning is just mega beautiful. Lily,...

Last week it happened again. Five o'clock in the morning, duty-free shop at the airport. First past the familiar ones, the ones you already know. Internally hoping to make a wonderful discovery. Spraying here, spraying there. The fatigue hits hard because you’ve been awake for four hours and still have four hours ahead. The light is way too bright, everything seems unreal,...

This scent seems somewhat difficult to grasp descriptively, and its perception appears to be heavily dependent on the individual sniffer. This can be easily seen in the contributions here, as the range of opinions on "Dreamer" is, in my view, above average.

And indeed, even for myself and the same bottle, the impression is not always the same. During my very first test (on the forearm), I thought, "Hmm, it's actually just lavender." On the second (scent cloud in front of my face): "Ugh, ashtray!" After the third attempt, I smelled marzipan.
I don't know how that happened. I hope those weren't all strokes. ;)

After longer use, however, my nose and the scent have synchronized, so I can give the following overall assessment:
The herbs listed in the notes play only an absolute supporting role. In contrast, the initially strong tobacco quickly loses presence in the drydown and then helps to tame the sweeter and floral notes of the fragrance in the background - to which the herbs likely also contribute.

Clearly dominant in "Dreamer" throughout the entire scent journey is a very soft, soapy aura - referring here to that of freshly fabric softener-laundered laundry. The scent gives me an almost tactile feeling of fluffiness - with a slight sweetness of marzipan (wherever that comes from, probably a result of the amber mixed with some of the herbal notes).
The "Dreamer" is truly a cuddly scent - however, it's more suited for one person; it's too innocent for more.

I will repurchase it, although it is actually very nice, but probably not. The scent is a bit too floral for a man, too fluffy for summer, too light for winter, and the tobacco might stand out too much on a lady. Finding the right occasion to wear it, aside from a cozy evening at home, is really not easy, and I think that might even be the main reason why it doesn't gain more popularity. Because, to conclude, the "Dreamer" is truly not bad. It just might be too much in between all the chairs.

There is a little angel.
He is so beautiful and delicate and intricate. And he plays a note on his golden harp, the shape of which reminds me of a pear.
I need not worry about this angel, even though I find him very vulnerable, for he is protected by a cream-colored cloud.
If I keep my distance, I hear a clear note that I have never heard before. As soon as I try to approach the heavenly being, the cloud is there and gently blocks my way.
I am initially astonished, for the note, despite its strangeness, conveys to me a feeling of trust. Trusting that there is a world where there is a place for me.
And I am grateful to be a witness to this moment.

For me, The Dreamer by Versace is a pure hit, although I have a slight feeling that the fragrance has come to me: the packaging, the name, the bottle, the affordable price of €20 for 50ml. Everything fits. I couldn't help but buy it without having smelled it before. And I must emphasize that this Eau de Toilette has a magical effect on me. Its scent cloud is the entrance to a new world. When I wear it, I am "grounded" in this new world. For me, The Dreamer radiates the great happiness of having found a home. All the money in the world is worth nothing when you let yourself fall backward with closed eyes and are caught by this fragrance.

If it is true that this was Versace's last fragrance creation in our world, then it feels all the more like a heavenly hint to me. A transcendence without any bombast.
As far as I am concerned, The Dreamer has come to stay.
But angels come and go, and I whisper: Thank you!

(Strange what images The Dreamer evokes in me, I am actually not an esoteric person!)

The Dreamer - Der Träumer

Why this name?

I think I understand why.

It invites you to dream.
It gives me that all-around carefree feeling that helps me get through the cold season without any problems.
When it gets colder and more uncomfortable outside, when the fog creeps under the sweater and stepping out the door takes some courage, this fragrance gives me a good feeling - and it lasts all day long. Even in the evening, still noticeable under the blanket...

The scent starts off harsh and angular - like a cold ashtray. And yet somehow floral. A bouquet of flowers next to an ashtray...
Fascinating.
It immediately captivated me.
The angularity quickly gives way to an aromatic, woody, and soft warmth - and here it begins to show its true strength.
This power and expressiveness easily lasts over the next 6 to 8 hours.

For me, a masterpiece and a jewel in my collection!

Perfumes must evoke feelings for me - and The Dreamer does that.
A scent that makes me happy, drives away the cold - and despite its strength, it doesn't stand out negatively in the surroundings.

Compliments? Not really. I wear it for myself and my well-being.

Great scent!

In 1996, this fragrance was created as the last under the personal involvement of Gianni Versace and has lost none of its radiance to this day.

For me personally, it is THE everyday scent, and I have developed a little tradition of always buying this perfume at the Duty Free shop in London Heathrow. Either as a souvenir or for myself when my bottle is empty again.
I don’t even know why London and why Dreamer, but somehow I keep doing it, even if it’s not necessarily cheaper than online or elsewhere.

But why has this particular scent become my everyday choice?
It is noticeable but unobtrusive. Elegant but not showy. Timeless but not outdated.
Fresh and floral, this men's perfume tends a bit towards the unisex area and is perceived positively with only very few exceptions.

What the Dreamer definitely is NOT, is a flashy party scent. Especially when you are in an environment where a lot of perfume is worn, you will fade into the background with the Versace classic.
Sillage and longevity are just enough to be noticed in everyday life, but not to annoy anyone.

One day I came home late from work....just before midnight.
Tired, exhausted, and glad to be home.

A package was delivered to me, which contained among other things The Dreamer EAU DE TOILETTE.

A small, dark blue perfume box with little stars on it...
Inside was a beautiful, small, transparent bottle that had a special effect on me...

3 sprays into the air..."very pleasant" I hear the voice in my head say...
3 sprays on my forearm...
Immediately, a situation unfolds before me...
My best friend and I are 11 years old, sitting in his room playing Gameboy Advance.
All impressions feel very realistic...
Am I dreaming right now?
Did I just doze off?

This scent in the opening is exactly what I think I know.
This special spiciness at the beginning, which quickly becomes more floral, powdery, sweeter, and softer.
This calming and relaxing nature...

The little perfume box, which is designed a bit old-fashioned and dreamily, already triggers a special feeling in me...
the bottle, which radiates something magical...
this scent profile and the realistic childhood memory...
me, sitting half awake/half asleep in my chair just after midnight...
this name "The Dreamer"...
15€ for 50ml...
Everything seemed very surreal...

I immediately fell in love with this perfume...
The entire presentation, combined with this special situation I was in when I first tested the scent, was like a little film.

I really enjoy wearing this scent.
It works best when the weather seems a bit strange...a little overcast and gray, but not cold or warm....on a day when nothing is particularly pressing.

A very peculiar perfume...
It almost seems as if the scent itself has a personality...

The scent has been on the market for so long, and yet, I became aware of it very late.
No one in my circle has ever worn the scent...
no one has ever talked about this scent...
no marketing, no TV commercials...
nowhere displayed in stores...
an absolute phantom...

Just the way it seemed to suddenly appear out of nowhere a few years ago was already very strange.

Now it is in my collection and I am very glad that it found its way there.

review_title: The Dreamer - For me, the All-Year-Rounder
review_content:
My first review on Parfumo simply has to be for this fragrance. When the fragrance was released in 1996, I was just one year old.

For me, this scent is something truly special. In my opinion, only a few fragrances (especially not in this price range) can compete with this extraordinary composition.

Upon the first spray, a floral note is perceived, rounded off by a masculine tobacco. Longevity and sillage are good.

Why would I call this fragrance an all-year-rounder? Because, in my opinion, it can be worn in any season and there are few occasions where this scent wouldn't be appropriate.

I reach for Versace The Dreamer when I can't decide on a fragrance, and I immediately feel uplifted as soon as I catch a whiff of it after the first spray.

The scent reminds me of a time when you are outside on warm summer nights, looking at the stars. In the distance, you can hear the crickets chirping - a gentle breeze sweeps over fields and meadows, and a seductive fragrance wafts in. Many may not like it (I personally don't care), because it might not be anything special or new, and it is also a reformulation. However, the current version is extremely pleasant for me, and I will wear it in spring and summer, when it's not too hot, especially in the evenings, for example, during a nice walk. Powdery, a fougère, slightly synthetic - but never intrusive. When it's in the air - a dream! It definitely has something mystical about it.

review_title: Outside great, inside just as great!!
review_content:
I have always wanted this fragrance, even if it didn't smell good, I would still place it in my perfume cabinet because it simply looks elegant.
At first, the scent reminds me of Sculpture Homme (but not as extremely penetrating), and as it develops, a perfectly measured amount of the Le Male DNA comes in, which smells very good with the tobacco blossom. However, this also takes away a bit of its uniqueness.
Overall, it is a masterpiece by Gianni Versace that hopefully won't be forgotten anytime soon.

So, as a long-time visitor of this site, I’m finally writing my first comment and not without reason about this fragrance.
I stumbled upon it through a video by the good Jeremy. The fragrance was not only one of my very first scents (I believe my third) but also my first blind buy (you can let me know if you've ever smelled it in any store. I certainly haven't seen it anywhere).
When the fragrance was delivered at the beginning of summer, it smelled quite indefinable to my untrained nose. However, it didn’t take much longer than an afternoon in summer with friends, iced tea, and canoes on the nearest river for it to become MY summer scent.
"A powdery, floral tobacco scent" describes it best. While I see that many classify The Dreamer as an all-rounder, I personally prefer it in the summer during the warmest temperatures and even then mostly for leisure activities or freshly showered after an evening jog.
I would have categorized the longevity and sillage as not particularly above average, like most light, fresh summer fragrances, but when I recently showed it to a friend, he said he had smelled it on me before. And since that could only have been during the aforementioned canoe trip, despite sunscreen, sweat, and hours of swimming in river water, it really surprised me.
So if you want a blind buy for summer, top quality from a legendary brand for little money, then you must not miss The Dreamer.

The "Dreamer" was my first fragrance with a floral origin that I liked. This scent has been around longer than I have, and to this day it is still available on the market. I think that says a lot about the fragrance - a timeless classic indeed. You get a very green start that quickly transitions into a floral note. The sweet note remains subtly in the background,...

If you know the original Versace The Dreamer, then you will be disappointed when you see what Versace has done to their best Eau de Toilette. The original was indescribably elegant and refined. The new one is just water. For €20, you can give it a try, but no one will smell it (except for you), even if you apply 20 sprays. I rated the old original version. It was incredibly...

I bought the "Dreamer" blindly after the almost universally positive reviews. The price was too tempting.

What can be said in advance is that the scent is very loud and contains demanding sage-like fragrance oils. The sage note is long-lasting and present until the end.

You have to like sage; if you do, then you are in the right place. I don't find it disturbing, but from my perspective, a bit of restraint wouldn't hurt. It would make the scent rounder. It would evoke a Christmas feeling.

The longevity is very good, as is the sillage. As for the scent, see above; if you like it, it's a 9. If you are more of a quieter type, then I would stay away from this one.

The bottle is appealing and has an oriental feel.

In conclusion, I fully endorse the "Dreamer"; it comes across as authentic and self-assured (is a dreamer self-assured???) I don't regret the purchase; I just have to figure out whether I like sage. Sage as a scent ;)

Update: You can scold me for this line of thought, but somehow I draw parallels to Amouage "Reflection Man." I don't know if it's the scent progression or the - yes - far-fetched "similar" fragrance note ... I can't say. I just know that immediately the thought crossed my mind, "there's something you know." Amouage - to be honest - comes across much more pleasing and is absolutely rounded! The Dreamer hits hard; one should act according to the motto "less is more" when applying, and even then, you might expect a slight headache. That's what happened to me.

review_title: Memories... / The Perfect Introduction / A Little Masterpiece! / For Very Little Money!
review_content:
Hello everyone,

I would like to talk about a rather special and somehow unique fragrance in a price range where you probably won't find a second one under 30€, The Dreamer EAU DE TOILETTE! (Except for clones)

I’ll say it right away, a truly massive plus point is its low price, which ranges from 17€ to 30€ depending on the offer and bottle size, and I find that absolutely fantastic! There are fragrances from niche houses that cost ten times as much just for the basic scent direction, just to mention that!

Back then, fragrance notes were combined that had not been combined (in the designer sector) until then, such as floral notes with tobacco. I found this combination very exciting back then, and it still is today = timeless!

Even with the aspect that one is somewhat knowledgeable about fragrances, it is one of those scents that always brings a certain smile to my face!

It works always, fits always, is well received, and costs little! It doesn’t always have to be a fragrance from PDM, LV, Xerjoff, Chanel, or, for example, MFK.

A brief note on performance (S/I), it is good. It was good back then and still is today. Back then it was a bit sharper and not as pleasing as it is today, but in my opinion, you can't go wrong at this price. This is one you should know ;) .

If I really weren’t convinced, I wouldn’t recommend it to you!

And now, have a nice day/evening or whenever you read this review, best regards, Benny
_______

Many thanks to Silke for the sample :-) In fact, The Dreamer EAU DE TOILETTE only made it onto my "Must-Try Wishlist" because of the rather positive reviews. The fragrance pyramid initially put me off, but this Eau de Toilette is proof: It doesn't always have something to say! I was immediately excited from the start. It's such a beautiful, clean scent. And the...

Here it was,... fresh in my hands, I opened the appealing packaging and was very taken with the bottle. This slightly angular shape and a Medusa head framed in relief, the well-known trademark of Versace. So far so good, the exterior matched.
The first spray already impressed me with its fragrance intensity. I first smell a decent amount of tarragon, paired with intense juniper, which is gently enveloped shortly after by the iris, creating a very calming effect. Subsequently, it becomes powdery-floral with an interesting tobacco note. Suitable for everyday wear and office-friendly. Never brutally loud or intrusive, but always present. A fragrance that has its "right to exist" in the perfume world. !!! Classic !!!
Longevity is a good 6 hours, sillage is above average.

For me, The Dreamer is a unique medicinal sweetness that seduces in a very pleasing way. You are sickly, weak, perhaps even feverishly daydreaming in your sickbed, cared for by a gentle and empathetic person who administers you a sweet medicinal syrup, changes the bed linens, airs out the room, waters the flowers on the windowsill, and strokes your forehead with a warm, gentle hand before placing a cool, damp cloth on it.

This sweetness wraps around the senses like a soft blanket, the floral and green notes are like fresh bed linens and cool air flowing in through the window, while the tobacco and the faintly alcoholic amber lull you into a warm drift into sleep and dreams, the spirit escapes through that very open window, becoming weightless, surrendering to the sweet frailty of being ill and slipping into equally sweet daydreams, probably about flying, and into the embrace of the caring person.

Dreamer is a scent that I actually only wear at home, under a blanket in the armchair while reading or right in bed. Cozy soft and light, but also with a seductive sweet heaviness that feels a bit intoxicating, like a slight buzz from alcoholic cough syrup or something. But I have a tip if you want to wear it outside: if you combine it with something distinctly woody or oudy, it takes on very everyday, palatable forms. Vetiver is particularly suitable here. For example, it surprisingly pairs well with the Encre Noires.

Longevity, sillage, and presentation are all convincing, and at that price, probably more than that. Everything is very coherent, just like the scent itself. I'm glad it's still on the market.

In loose succession, I take a closer look at the fragrances of my friend, which I sometimes use myself when the devil rides me, and write what I think of them. This one is a "men's fragrance that women like." In fact, it is so floral that it could have been designed as a women's fragrance.
Versace hasn't released a men's fragrance since the first women's fragrance that I would have bought for myself. But this one is a nice one.
The top note already shows the direction: floral freshness with a slight oriental touch.
The heart note then becomes almost powdery and at times resembles - don't hit me now, or send me threatening letters - Habit Rouge. Okay, they stand next to each other in our bathroom, but I believe my master had something in mind. And I think so too.
Of course, this slight hint of HR doesn't last long, as the dreamer then takes big, adult steps into the oriental. Unfortunately, I don't smell tobacco, which I think I would have liked very much.
In the drydown, I still sense a light, sweet spiciness that lingers for a long time.

Well, actually a very nice perfume...
At first, there's something herbal that reminds me a lot of cold medicine, sage/mint cream, you know what I mean :)
The scent is very similar to JPG Le Male (the regular one) or goes in that direction and stays that way the whole time, so I personally feel like I'm wearing JPG Le Male when I spray it... you notice it a lot in the first hour, so it has great projection, but then it settles down. In between, you can still smell it, but you have to be a bit close to catch it. All in all, a very nice perfume even if you've smelled something similar before. The longevity on my skin was about 5-6 hours, and on clothes, you could smell it for a good 8 hours until it really faded away.
I haven't generated any compliments yet... thanks to the lockdown... well, that's about it... Versace - The Dreamer

Warm light streams through the half-open window onto white sheets, a hint of herbs clings to it. Soft birdsong, bees buzzing, and from afar, the church bell calls to mass. I blink, lift the corners of my mouth, turn around once more, and doze off again. Today is Sunday - the world can stay outside today.

What makes this scent particularly special for me is its "Laissez-Faire" attitude. It does not impose itself but unfolds gently and subtly on the skin. I sense soft notes of lavender, sage, and iris. This combination conveys a light, airy elegance and sophistication that is far too rare in the world of "Pour Homme" fragrances. It is refreshing to experience a scent that does not try to impress with overwhelming masculinity through loud tones and aggressive aromas. Instead, it radiates a natural allure based on the inner calm and serenity of its wearer.

The Dreamer has once again convinced me that it is a completely wrong approach to choose a fragrance based on the notes listed in the fragrance pyramid and then to interpret something into it that is not there, or to convince myself that I should like the scent because ingredient XY is included. Or, more importantly, to not like it because this and that ingredient is present. Tarragon and juniper, that actually screams bitter, dry, and dusty, the unloved siblings of the great culinary herbs - that does not appeal to me. But: It is the combination, the complexity, that defines the scent.

For me, it is a summer fragrance - not really for the brightest sun or at the beach, but more for the morning and evening.

The bottle is simple and elegant by today’s standards - the only thing that bothers me is the matte gold-colored plastic cap in the shape of a gemstone - a failed attempt to appear noble and exclusive. The fragrance does not need that.

This is it, the unexpected waystation on the fragrance journey. I didn’t actually want to get off here, but now I no longer feel that I need to get back on and continue my journey. A fragrance that gives me a calm aura of Sunday every day - that is more than I ever hoped for.

The house of Versace is responsible for one of my absolute favorite fragrances, "L'Homme" from 1984, and due to this good experience as well as the pretty bottle, I took a chance on a blind purchase of "The Dreamer." Initially, there is a sharp lavender note, juniper, and a general tea/tobacco aura. In a dream, the characters sometimes suddenly change their shape, without it...

Today "The Dreamer" has arrived, and when I tried it directly on my arm, Italy and an Italian bathroom immediately came to mind. At first, the scent reminds me in the first few seconds of Prada L'Homme, which then fades away. After a few minutes, there's this mix of Sculpture, Le Male, and Versace L'Homme < (which I don't like at all, it smells like old men to me) and a very...

review_title: Synthetic doesn't have to be bad
review_content:
I discovered this today in a German department store (50ml for €20) and checked the reviews here before purchasing. Synthetic, a LeMale offshoot but consistently good reviews. I then bought it because I thought the price of €20 was reasonable for this fragrance.

Yes, it reminds me of LeMale, but this LeMale experience is overshadowed by iris and tarragon, offering a rounded cut, if I may say so. I also tested Versace L'homme as a counterpoint, but although many praise it, it was too powerful, penetrating, and far too masculine for me. Almost like a masculine No 5. I can't wear something like that. I prefer something synthetic in which I feel comfortable. I also find the name "The Dreamer" very fitting for the fragrance experience and can get on board with it, but I wouldn't have spent more than €20 on it.

review_title: My Sleep Ritual for a Restful Night
review_content:
As someone who often struggles to fall asleep, I can say that Versace The Dreamer has become an essential part of my sleep ritual. This fragrance is so calming and relaxing that I apply it every evening to help me enter a deeper state of tranquility.
The Dreamer is a subtle and gentle scent that soothes the senses and calms the mind. The top notes create a soothing atmosphere, while the heart notes add a subtle sweetness and a certain kind of floral bouquet. The base note of tobacco gives the fragrance a warm and cozy touch, making it perfect for the evening and night.
I love how the scent evolves over time. It lingers on the skin long enough to provide me with a pleasant ambiance as I fall asleep, yet it is not so strong that it overwhelms my senses or influences my dreams.

The dreamer is great and exceptional for this price range. It smells of tobacco and a slightly sweet rose. In fact, it also has a somewhat powdery scent. The sillage and longevity are definitely acceptable for this price, and the bottle and name fit well and are beautiful. Definitely a recommendation for an extraordinary, affordable everyday scent.

review_title: A Dream in the Herb Garden
review_content:
Sometimes the scent and title symbolize each other immediately. Versace's Dreamer shows the way. A path into the sun-drenched herb garden. The intensity of the heat slowly diminishes, the warmth is bearable and manageable. In the garden, there is plenty of tarragon and lavender. Both are more noticeable than the rest of the herbs. The bathroom window is open. Someone has showered. Apparently with classic soap and previously a smooth aura was sprayed. Vanilla? No, the brother. The tonka bean. On the windowsill lie fermented tobacco leaves, warmed by the sun. Everything combines into a sensually dreamy harmony and yet it is real.

That is "The Dreamer"! If there were a beauty award for bottles and packaging, Versace would probably be the king of all designers. Unfortunately, the scents often do not hold up to that. However, here they do, which is why the Italian dreamer is no longer a secret tip. Uncharacteristically, without synthetic influences, the herbs come forth, especially tarragon and lavender, very beautifully natural. This also has something distinctive. On paper more than on the skin.

It does indeed remind one a bit of "Le Mâle". The light soap-lavender combination in conjunction with a powdery base (here tonka bean) makes it so. In this respect, I do not quite understand the polarization. The dreamer is neither too cloyingly sweet (especially not with the current trend), nor does it have too herbal a sting on the skin. Tarragon, in particular, polarizes, but interacts harmoniously with the other ingredients on the skin.

The connections from all the fragrance components indeed create a very beautiful, sensual scent that, despite the slight similarities to the blue sailor, feels unique - positively individual. Not a playful, hopeless idealist, but a realist with ideals. "The Dreamer" is masculine, distinctive, and yet also smooth and flexible to use, as long as one does not overdo it with the sprays. One of the best Versace scents, where one does not just want the chic bottle.

I definitely have to say something about The Dreamer by Versace. This fragrance has already achieved classic status and is relatively seldom mentioned today, as well as not often encountered in public spaces. Essentially, The Dreamer is a timeless classic that can still be worn well in the current era, even though it has that slight 90s vibe. The fragrance belongs to those old...

The Dreamer! Even the name sounds seductive. But already at a glance at the fragrance pyramid, I had some slight doubts. Iris sounded good at first, as this note is primarily responsible for scents like Dior Homme, Prada L'Homme, Valentino Uomo Intense, or Givenchy Gentleman. So, quite to my taste. However, mixed with juniper and tarragon? Hmmm… whatever, blind buy and done…

Well, unfortunately, it was nothing! You can definitely tell that the fragrance comes from a good house, that much can be said upfront. However, I constantly get a spicy cinnamon note in the opening and throughout the fragrance progression, even though it is not listed in the fragrance pyramid. I have a similar experience with Joop Ice, even though cinnamon is also obviously not a component there. This scent perception in The Dreamer may also result from the mix of iris and juniper. Anyway, this spicy note somehow doesn’t fit with the sweet-powdery iris and unfortunately ruins the otherwise quite beautiful composition for me. This spicy undertone dominates the entire fragrance progression, which is why I cannot really understand the often-cited resemblance to Prada L'Homme. I rather see a similarity to the aforementioned Joop Ice.

In principle, The Dreamer remains a beautiful fragrance. It just has to fit scent-wise. The bottle is elegant, the scent is high-quality, the sillage is subtle but good, the longevity is also noticeable, and the price is affordable. Unfortunately, my expectations for the fragrance were not met, even though it could have fit quite well according to the many previous scent descriptions. However, this spicy-cinnamon undertone is disturbingly prominent, as if something just doesn’t want to fit together. For me, once again, it’s proof that you shouldn’t rely on other fragrance descriptions, but rather test for yourself…

This is what the wearer of Versace Dreamer says.
No ego, no alpha, no macho
The man of a young, in-love couple, or a loving father.

The fragrance radiates a calm, truly dreamy, and soft character without leaning into the feminine.

Not suitable for the midday sun in my opinion, more for the evening hours in summer.
Otherwise, wearable at any time.

The longevity is good, it actually lasts all day, however, the sillage significantly decreases after 2-3 hours and you can only perceive the scent up close, but still very distinctly, while many fragrances leave only a few notes lingering.

Overall, a great fragrance that is easy to like.

review_title: A dream in a dream in a dream …
review_content:
“Dreamer, you know you are a dreamer
Well can you put your hands in your head, oh no! …”

This is how one of Supertramp's most successful songs begins, which I think of every time I have “The Dreamer” by Versace in sight or in nose.

The song from the 70s by Supertramp is now an absolute classic, which unfortunately cannot yet be said about the fragrance. Why not? Just the bottle has strong classic features that clearly indicate that we are dealing with an exquisite and noble content. And this can be smelled:

“The Dreamer” comes sweetly with a slightly spicy minty note. The latter I would possibly attribute to the clary sage as well as the tarragon. Therefore, the fragrance has for me a somewhat Christmassy quality, but that is a rather subjective feeling.

However, this spicy, minty note is a bit too dominant for my taste. While it makes the fragrance unmistakable, it also makes it polarizing.

Accordingly, I stayed away from it back then and still can't really get excited about it today.

Nevertheless, “The Dreamer” is a great scent that has its place. The longevity is excellent, and even after many years, my miniature bottle has lost none of its intensity. This speaks for a high quality that at least other fragrances can only dream of …

My second blind buy inspired by parfumo.de arrived yesterday. While it doesn't quite excite me as much as my last one (CdG Incense Avignon), I do like it. After spraying it on, there's an overwhelming burst of aromas that I can hardly distinguish. Somewhat oriental, humid, and floral. All of this is supported and framed by a sexy smoky tobacco note with hot, sweetened...

review_title: The Dreamer! Great DNA - Mediocre H/S - Hopefully always a Cheapie!
review_content: The latest fragrance from Gianni Versace! A cheapie that you can safely buy blind if you enjoy light old-school scents. About the fragrance itself (8.2 out of 10): A fresh-floral scent with spice and a slight sweetness. In my opinion, a perfect interplay of old-school and newschool. In the top notes, I personally smell the mixture of tarragon and juniper the most. In...

review_title: The Scent of Dream and Love
review_content: I like to associate this fragrance with a dream vacation. It awakens your senses and your memories come alive, reminding you how beautiful traveling to exotic places can be. The Dreamer is a highlight from the low price segment, which is truly surprising. It is a fantastic scent. I find that many products from Versace are exceptional and hardly comparable to others. It smells...

review_title: The Dreamer - A beautiful, cozy quiet presence
review_content: I would like to dedicate my first review to "The Dreamer (Eau de Toilette) | Versace." I have only recently started to delve a bit deeper into perfumes and wanted to begin my fragrance journey with more affordable designer scents. On various social platforms, The Dreamer EAU DE TOILETTE has been frequently mentioned positively, and I was also drawn to its release...

In a forest lived three animals: an owl, a fox, and a stag. The owl could only see at night, the fox could see both by day and by night, and the stag relied on his hearing and sense of smell during the day. Although they perceived the world in different ways, they complemented each other and appreciated the diversity of perception. In our parable, one could say that "The...

review_title: A Floral Dream Full of Sweetness
review_content:
I have to say, I am really excited about this. It is a scent that, in my opinion, smells like a fabric softener with a fruity and sweet note. I know that many might perceive it differently, but for me personally, it reminds me of a mix between Le Male and Prada L'Homme.

To be honest, I wasn't very satisfied with the opening of the fragrance at first. I thought it might not have been a good idea to buy it blind. But then came the drydown, and it really convinced me. The scent becomes clean, floral, and sweet, and the powderiness is more present in the background.

What I really love about this fragrance is that you can't go wrong with it. It is such a versatile scent that can be worn both during the day and in the evening. It suits any occasion and any outfit. I have already received many compliments for it, and I just feel good when I wear it.

All in all, I can really recommend Versace - The Dreamer. It is a fragrance that has exceeded my expectations and has become one of my favorites. If you are looking for a scent that is clean, floral, and sweet, then this one is definitely worth a try. Give it a go and let yourself be enchanted!

I ordered this fragrance blind, like probably many others, because the concept sounds just too tempting and it is also very affordable. Once the strong alcohol scent of the EDT has faded, the spiciness of the top notes still dominates. But not for long. This completely recedes into the background as a sweet creaminess develops, which gets a mysterious touch from the...

……released in 1996. That's longer than I've even been around… and to this day I find it absolutely great. The Dreamer is a scent of the lighter kind, ideal for those days when you really don't feel like wearing a perfume. This fragrance can be worn almost year-round, perhaps not in the deepest winter, but nearly all year long, and is an absolutely solid companion.
The spray nozzle is indeed a complete disaster, but the unbeatable price easily makes up for it.
The Dreamer is not a performance monster, but that wouldn't suit it either. It is relatively close to the skin, yet lasts a solid 6-8 hours.
The scent starts with green notes and then becomes more floral with iris and lily as it develops. In the base note, you can clearly recognize the tobacco flower.
For me personally, this is already the second bottle, which is actually a rarity in my case. It is definitely worth a try, especially due to its price.

review_title: So this is one of two scents...
review_content: ... from the house of Versace that I do not like. I bought this fragrance because it was praised all over YouTube for being such a great scent. Well, I just can't stand this powdery, sticky fragrance. But hold on, that doesn't mean it's bad. I just don't like it. When applying this scent, the nose gets a green laundry detergent vibe. Then something floral comes in, and in...

the carriage is waiting. A dandy romantic outing/dinner fragrance (oriental-fougere) with strong references to GB Grey Flannel and Boucheron Jaipur (Euroitalia version). I would even go so far as to say that it feels as if both were mixed 1:1 and made a bit more extravagant, or rather lighter/thinner. Thus, the strong herbal/coniferous/plant aspect of GF is absent, and the for...

The Dreamer smells like fabric softener with an herbal sweetness. Very old-school - but not an old man's scent.

I think anyone who enjoys dressing in vintage clothes and is generally into vintage and retro can wear this fragrance perfectly. Because, as mentioned above, the scent is very old-school, but it doesn’t turn into an old man’s fragrance like others in this category do. Therefore, it is also suitable for younger people who want "something old."

The longevity could be better, but it carries you through about 6 hours well.

The bottle, on the other hand, is one of the most beautiful in my opinion. It looks really classy with the embossed Medusa.

Partly available for under €20 - you can't complain about that.

The Versace the Dreamer, what can I say? I use it as a high-quality room freshener and occasionally on myself. As you can gather from my review, it’s pretty average for me. Not a scent you necessarily remember. A decently solid fresh laundry scent with its iris. And a slight sweetness. A softie, really. Pleasant and surely popular with women, I perceive it as unisex and think women can wear it just as well as men. Longevity and sillage could be improved. Good value for money.

The scent starts with a very pronounced slightly alcoholic juniper note, which is accompanied from the very beginning by a sweetness (I suspect it’s coumarin). Quickly, some floral notes join in. These are rather synthetic but by no means unpleasant, like a pleasant fabric softener. The iris note comes through very dominantly throughout, evoking associations with fragrances...

Is this gem from the 90s? From Versace? Powerhouse and loud design? No way, right? With The Dreamer, I float away on fluffy clouds into cotton-soft dreamland. The Dreamer by Versace is very delicate and soft. It is sweet, but not sugary-sweet or vanilla-sweet, rather vetiver-sweet, tobacco-sweet, floral-sweet, and powdery-sweet. This ethereal sweetness is just one facet, as...

The Dreamer by Versace is basically like waking up from a dream but barely remembering it... The scent is very transparent and light, and therefore not really present in the nose. It is a beautiful sweet floral fragrance with a tobacco note. Very unique but very light in the air. To me, it smells a bit like cotton candy or caramelized desserts in general, with a hint of pipe tobacco in the background...

Longevity and sillage are rather mediocre... Sillage in the first few minutes is quite pronounced, but as mentioned before, not much remains; it fades relatively quickly... 4-6 hours absolute maximum!

If you have the money to spare, you can definitely use it for sleeping or watching series on the couch; it works really well for that.

It is a unique scent that is personally too sweet for me and ultimately not worth the money. There are plenty of other cheapies that perform significantly better... you can try it out for sleeping; it has a calming effect, but otherwise, just a gentle breeze.

review_title: A Masterpiece from the House of Versace!
review_content: I am relatively new to the world of perfume, and Dreamer was the second fragrance I bought (blind). I had no idea what an incredible scent was coming my way. After the first spray, I was immediately in love! The very prominent floral notes and the light tobacco in the background leave an impression, an impression of a well-groomed, very elegant man who knows how to present himself. My only criticism is the sillage and longevity, which, as expected for an EDT, are not too intense. On the other hand, I think it's fantastic that this DNA comes from the 90s and that you can still enjoy these beautiful notes today. Just like the bottle, it feels very high-quality, and the Versace Medusa as well as the capless spray head feel great. Considering that you can get this perfume for 25/30€, I believe you can't miss out on this masterpiece (as a man)!

Italy vacation 2022 near Perugia. Two weeks, but only one perfume packed. Therefore, I will forever associate this scent with the beautiful, yet somewhat quaint area around Lake Trasimeno.

This is exactly how the Versace smells. A bit old school, green, floral, fresh, and somehow different from all other fragrances. Does the blooming fauna in the heart of Italy smell like this? What always captivates me is its unmistakable character. This is certainly not a fragrance that influencers today would commonly refer to as a compliment-getter. Rather, the Dreamer is exactly what its name suggests. A dream of a memory from a beautiful late summer.

I wish the scent smelled as good as its name and as the composition of its notes suggests. At first, it caught me off guard, which I consider a positive thing, as it was unexpected and not necessarily in line with what I had smelled before. But now, unfortunately, I only smell old, albeit noble, soap. At least it projects quite well for about 4-5 hours and can still be perceived nicely on the skin afterwards. I can't imagine who would wear it and on what occasion. I could even see it more on a woman...
Some say it's for the cold season, but I can think of 20 much more suitable fragrances for that. Such a shame, the pretty bottle would have looked great in my collection, but no, this one is definitely going back...

First of all: I am not aware of any perfume that can be compared to this scent.

The fragrance is clean, fresh, deep, floral.
Sometimes I notice a distant similarity to Le Malé, sometimes I do not. I would describe The Dreamer as a very approachable, easy-to-like scent. The juniper comes through very well with the tobacco. I find it has a certain depth, a warm note, but in no way is it dominating.

A great perfume, unbeatable value for money. Timeless.

The Dreamer was one of my first fragrances and I bought it blind. With a pretty low price tag, I thought it might be worth a try.

For me, The Dreamer is the perfect scent for a white T-shirt and brown pants at the end of spring. The fresh juniper holds up well and it’s easy to reapply for the price. It’s not the most common combination of notes - personally, it reminds me a bit of the pages of a book - but it’s also an interesting and solid purchase for beginners.

On paper and on my skin, I unfortunately can't really warm up to this scent. As for Versace, I am a big fan, but this fragrance simply has an undertone that slightly turns my stomach the more I get it in my nose. It's a pity, I think, because at first sniff, you become very attentive and interested in it; you want to smell it again - but then, in detail, it turns...

I didn't like the opening with the juniper berries, but now it becomes really beautifully soft and iris-scented. The amber is creamy. One should patiently wait for the development on the skin, as it becomes, contrary to expectations, very very pleasant. It exudes a hint of freshness and naturalness. It already has a nice strong scent but is by no means intrusive. A lovely...

Even users of certain deodorants have to painstakingly overcome the closure or cap of their spray cans as a barrier to their freshness experience. With "The Dreamer," this effort is spared - dreamy! It's a pity that it doesn't spray itself.

As for the scent itself: A rather fresh, yet classically smelling fragrance. Very pleasing, not just for those who enjoy the scent of unburned tobacco (but quite sweet). It also has a floral aspect, so the experts of the fragrance pyramid seem to be right :)

Can I recommend a blind purchase? Yes, if you enjoy sniffing that tobacco.
But that's just my opinion. And even if it doesn't turn out to be love at first sight, take your time. Once you should part with it, you will miss it.

Then it remains just a dream, the Dreamer.

I don't think I'll be the first to positively associate this awesome piece with the oil that was rubbed on your chest as a child when you had bronchitis. Not at all medicinal or stinky, rather soothing due to delicious herbs, slightly spicy and lively. After a while, the spiciness subsides and makes way for super creamy/delicious scent notes, a light damp tobacco smell,...

review_title: REM Sleep Phase for the Skin
review_content: Creamy-spicy, an airy veil between heaven and earth. Warm light. Clean, but with a herbal component that makes it exciting without being too jarring. Good balance of a comforting scent and a stylish statement. Later, the soft, floral notes emerge, also a wonderful moment in the fragrance's progression - a soft, inviting powdery bed. A scent like the REM sleep phase, just before waking up. You're not quite there yet, escaping life for a few moments and remaining in your own world. Only criticism: smells a bit dated, the fragrance feels like it's from the 90s and gives me extreme 90s vibes. H/S totally okay.

Since this is my first review on Parfumo, I naturally dedicated it to a perfume that deserves to be the first review.

Well, what can I say...?
The last perfume by Gianni Versace himself is an absolute delight for the nose. Fresh, floral, and heavenly dreamy indeed.
I have rarely smelled a perfume that was so aptly named.
It evokes true feelings of happiness in me, especially in the top notes - of course, there’s also a certain nostalgia involved, as I already own the third bottle.

To all the amateur philosophers who also want to smell good in spring or summer, I can only warmly recommend this fragrance.

For me, it is a pleasant feel-good scent. The name matches the fragrance. Very dreamy and reminiscent of sunny, mild spring days. At first, I get a very zesty gin note from the juniper. Unfortunately, the longevity is a bit lacking. After 2 hours on my skin, it is hardly detectable.

review_title: Fragrance Note Deception: Flower Water Instead of Top 100
review_content: Well, blind purchases don’t always deliver what they promised in the fragrance notes. Personally, I came across this scent because I absolutely love "Tabarome Millésime | Creed," and the Dreamer was indicated as "similar." Similarity? Not a trace, at least not to my nose. Here, Versace merely offers a light floral water, minimal powderiness can be detected, otherwise the...

It's a difficult topic...
It was a blind buy. To be honest, I initially tried to convince myself that I was buying a nice citrus tobacco scent. Essentially, it is that, but someone once described the fragrance as a "fresh ashtray," and I must admit, that haunts me a bit.
It will be a summer scent, but in the summer, the scent of the "fresh ashtray" was somewhat piercing. That bothered me to some extent. However, I don't see it for winter, as it is very citrusy fresh.
On the other hand, Versace The Dreamer is a vintage scent, which doesn't necessarily have to capture the spirit of the times. It is definitely vintage in terms of smell and somewhat older; those who appreciate that could definitely find pleasure in this fragrance.

In summary, it can be said:
The scent is very unique, but quite fitting for the time it was released.
Even though I have been quite harsh on it in my review, I associate many beautiful memories with it.

such a beautiful scent...perfect now that the days are getting longer and the sun is starting to show, dreamily weaving through the grasses that are just beginning to unfold. Iris becomes clear over time and later, light tobacco vibes come in. But then........it was unfortunately just a short, gentle breeze. After a short time, about 1-2 hours for me, there’s unfortunately...

review_title: A fragrance that gives me goosebumps...
review_content: I have been a perfume collector for a few years now, or rather a fragrance freak... and I have owned or at least tested countless scents, and I have repeatedly come into contact with The Dreamer EAU DE TOILETTE. This fragrance is praised in countless YouTube videos, celebrated as a masterpiece, and I have even owned a bottle for several years. From time to...

The scent seemed a bit confused to me and smelled quite blurry.
I smell spicy woods, herbs, but also flowers, so really interesting.
I definitely wouldn't recommend it as a blind buy to anyone, but it's definitely something different to try out.
Longevity and sillage are average.
I really like the bottle.
I bought 50 ml and there's still about 40 ml left.
I've used it so rarely.

Top Versace fragrance. Elegant and mysterious. Definitely worth a sniff. But don’t buy it right away, test it multiple times instead. The fragrance components listed here cannot describe it very well and are certainly not all the ingredients.

Artemisia and tarragon? Plus iris and tobacco flower?! Sounds intriguing, and an Eau de Toilette will once again be a welcome change from the 2020s intense EdPs. Said and done! Upon...

Not fresh enough and too heavy for me. It causes a certain sting in my nose. I generally love fragrances from Versace. The Dreamer is not really my thing. However, the...

During my trip to Thailand, I was forced to change planes at Abu Dhabi Airport. I had to wait over 2 hours for my next flight. Abu Dhabi Airport is small and ugly, nothing really to see except for the wooden camel that everyone sits on to take photos. My wife, not really a fan of perfume, I had to beg to go with me to the Duty Free Shop. The perfume shop is small and only a few niche perfumes have made it in here. Amouage, Ajmal, Swiss Arabia. Just a few wonderful perfume manufacturers from the Arab League.

Incredibly cheap there. I know everyone will curse me now for not packing Amouage for you. Quite simply, I don't like it. I'm more interested in scents that haven't been overexposed yet.

Shadha by Arabian Swiss was a candidate for me, as it convinced me during testing with its freshness and intensity.

Shadha starts with fresh rose, not as strong as Rose Petals but rather mild and fresh. Lightly spiced with sandalwood. Patchouli is present only in small amounts. Oud can be sniffed in the dry down.

I find the longevity to be extremely good. The sillage smells voluminous yet elegant.

So I find the perfume oil very fresh and also good for men to wear. The rose is the main component of this perfume. The scent is spicy, and the oud is always present in the background.

The perfume is simple but very elegant. I like it because it doesn't come on as strong as other rose perfumes.

review_title: Sharp, spicy, leathery tobacco, a bit of a varnish vibe
review_content:
Sampling Fulton & Roark Sterling, a sharp blend featuring prominent notes of tobacco leaf and amber, almost with a varnish/lacquer/borderline whiskey type of vibe, as well, striking and fairly powerful, though not extremely dense. It’s a non-sweet contrast to Calle Ocho, the boozier sweeter blend. It expectedly dries down to be a little calmer, though its character does not change much, with still a lot of sharpness, borderline metallic, some hours in.

Like the rest of the extrait collection, Sterling is priced at $205 for 50ml, far from cheap, so I’d really only recommend a full bottle if you love it, and while I like it, I don’t love it, but I think it will suit some people very well in the cooler months, especially. My favorites of my sample set of five were ultimately Calle Ocho and Narada.

7 out of 10

review_title: And it smells good, by the way
review_content:
Kenzo has a great sense of humour, if you ask me. And if I translate the name of this fragrance correctly: Ça sent Beau meaning This smells good. What a great name for a perfume! But apart from being quite fun, there is a truth to it, that I shall have to comment on. Since with this astounding product I do sometimes consider the smell secondary. Perhaps that needs an explanation. Let us look at in what order this unfolds itself.
It starts with the wrapping: stunning. The EdP comes in a beautiful light green box with a beautiful black (hand) writing stating Kenzo. Next to this is a red seal like decoration, a Japanese ‘hanko’. The box has structures of leaves pressed into the cardboard. Inside, the bottle is wrapped in crisp peach coloured tissue paper, almost nesting in it. Oh yes please! Now, that is what I call decent wrapping. The whole act of unwrapping makes my nervous system go bonkers. So much, that I tend to forget what it is all about - the fragrance.
But then there is the bottle. I have the deodorant, the miniature EdT and the ‘real thing’ - the EdP. All are in the stunning category. The EdP, however, takes the price. It has a stopper shaped like two flowers, and the neck and bottle reminds me of the now again popular activity of stacking rocks on top of each other. Even though the top is plastic, the whole picture is a balanced, beautiful and bold design, that leaves me with a luxurious feeling. So much that I tend to forget what it is all about - the fragrance.
Well, the fragrance is out of this world and should be in the Top100 - despite its high ranking, it is not in Parfumo’s Women’s Top100, which surprises me. It is creamy, floral and soapy at the same time. When it warms up it has a floral expression that makes me want it to stay like that forever. Actually, I think it is timeless. Such a shame that it is discontinued. But then again, I get to enjoy it, because it is in my collection.
Year 2, 158/365

Today, I wanted to compare the Ça Sent Beau EAU DE TOILETTE on the right and left arms with the "Ça Sent Beau / Kenzo (Eau de Parfum) | Kenzo." To my surprise, the perfume lasts only 3-4 hours on my skin with a rather weak sillage. The Eau de Toilette comes across as much more concentrated, likely due to its age - both fragrances come from collection dissolutions and are in older miniature bottles. I find the DNA of the scent not too bad but also a bit old school. It smells very floral and fruity.

The top note starts fruity with peach but also floral-sweet with orange and jasmine blossoms. The heart note remains distinctly floral. I detect rose water, geraniums, tuberose, gardenias, iris, violets, and lily of the valley - what a sea of flowers! The base reminds me a bit of soap and fabric softener. Additionally, I recognize a green-earthy patchouli aroma. It also has a slightly vanillic and balsamic scent.

All in all, this is a fairly successful fragrance, but I wouldn't necessarily associate it with my "dream woman," as I find it a bit outdated.

EDIT 23.02.2024: Now I have tested another miniature. Here, the longevity was significantly better at around 12 hours. In the top note, I also detected bergamot and a jam-like quality. As it develops further, it also smells quite oriental, festive, and of cinnamon.

On me, Kingston Ferry opens woody and green with a bit of sharpness that settles down very quickly into a soft woody, green floral. There is something here- an almost undetectable gasoline/fuel "note." It isn't unpleasant at all, and you sense it more than you really smell it (I swear that really does make sense, I think). It's not unpleasant at all and is, with the seagrass, evocative of a ferry.

I don't get any "fish" smell at all, just driftwood and sea grass, with their hints of salt, but I really like it. The saltiness, on me, is bringing bit of a fresh, briny accord into the woody, green florals.

On me, this saltiness fades within a couple of hours, and the drydown is a creamy, aromatic woody scent, which is very pretty and rather unique I think.

IMO Dr. Covey really hit the mark with this fragrance. It's quite good, although not something I would want to wear everyday. It's a unisex, adult fragrance, which lasts about 6-7 hours on me; sillage is moderate through most of that time. Great for warm weather, casual events.

Let me start by saying that, while I have the utmost respect for Dr. Ellen Covey as an artist, I am clearly not the target demographic for this fragrance.

Here's an excerpt from my review of night flyer:

"What makes Dr. Ellen Covey a true artist, is how she breaks those expectations by creating very literal and unconventional fragrances. Dr. Covey doesn't just give you an ocean scene filled with coconuts, she brings you to the ocean "warts and all" and lets you breath the briny, salty air. This is great, transportive art. But not necessarily how a person wants to smell."

In the case of Kingston Ferry, you have a gorgeous forest smell. Very similar to her other fragrance, Olympic Rainforest (a beautiful fragrance). But here we have added a repulsive, briny, salty undertone.

As someone who can't even stand to eat seafood, this is one of the most disgusting combinations I can imagine. It smells like fish and algea. I usually try a fragrance on my skin at least once before I write my reviews, but with this one, I can hardly even stand to be in the same room as the sample.

review_title: The importance of preserving estuarine habitats...
review_content:
This occupies a weird sort of niche in the realm of aquatic fragrances. Usually they can be divided pretty evenly into three distinct groups: the "beachy" aquatics, with their lemon and coconut and warm sand; the "swimming pool" aquatics, conjuring images of clean towels and shower gel; and the "marine" aquatics, aiming for the cold and dark nature of the ocean, of which Squid reigns supreme. Kingston Ferry is none of these, and is what I would term an "estuarine" aquatic.

I know this is inspired by the Pacific Northwest, but to me (having never been to that side of the U.S.) this reminds me of the temperate salt marshes in southern Australia. The color palette is not blue, it's brown and green, pale and looking dried out even when it's not. Grasses and scrubs. But if you eat a leaf from one of them, you'll taste the salt drawn up through the soil, through the roots of plants that have been fed on seawater rather than rain.

Basically, it smells like what I imagined Wood Sage & Sea Salt COLOGNE would have smelled like based on the name. Except it also lasts longer than a slight breeze.

This is another fragrance from Olympic Orchids that I'm refraining from giving a numeric rating to because the scent itself isn't bad, it just isn't too my tastes. It's relatively unisex with a slightly modern, masculine edge. It has an informal feeling and doesn't really invoke association with a specific season.

It opens with a blast of harsh liquorice and tarragon. I don't know what notes are responsible for the fuel accord, but it's not subtle. If you're one of those folks who like the smell of gasoline, Kingston Ferry might be right up your alley. There is a lot of salt here at well. I grew up in a coastal fishing town, and this fragrance definitely invokes maritime memories -- but picture more 'riding a barely seaworthy lil' motorboat and drinking jagerbombs with the boys' kind of memories. It's kind of wild.

I don't get any of the fish or organic notes some other folks are describing, just salt, solvents and dried herbs. It mellows out a little bit and the herbal notes become a little bit more green and 'fresh shower-y' upon dry down. It's one of the more unorthodox aquatics I've smelled, but not for me

Ellen Covey and I have already undertaken the most diverse journeys together.
She has taken me to the mountains and onto the stage, shown me grain fields and rainforests, let me see the stars and her very own Salamanca - and now, it seems, she also wanted to show me the sea.
Not the turquoise blue with white frothy crests gently lapping at powdery beaches, not the salty wind sweeping over rugged cliffs, nor the elegant snow-white yacht on the open sea - one should not expect such clichés from Ellen Covey, no matter how beautiful they may be.
Her fragrances tend to be a bit rougher, a bit more natural, stubborn, and often rather austere.
That she does not appeal to everyone and sometimes even clashes strongly with tastes is something she accepts - yet even though I find this trait immensely sympathetic, I approached the test with quite mixed feelings, especially after Ergoproxy's comment.

"Kingston Ferry" opens herbaceous, gray-green-brown, and very strict, making it clear from the very first seconds that I need not prepare for a leisurely cruise.
Gray sky and wild sea, rubber boots and a raincoat come to mind.
It quickly turns dark, damp-woody-spicy nuances carry the scent of the not-so-distant, coniferous mainland over, mixing with the smell of smoke, machine oil, hot rubber, and a hint of tar.
Surprisingly authentic, it feels - I am catapulted back years and placed on the decks of ferries to Sweden, to England, right into the sharp smells of the massive ships.
Hot metal somewhere deep beneath my feet, black soot particles in the air - in the wind shadow beside me, a man rolls a cigarette, spicy warm tobacco aroma weaves golden-brown threads through the dark gray conglomerate of hard, gloomy, labor-intensive scent nuances.
For moments, I also feel transported back to "Salamanca," smelling the dark, hot, soft tar - yet "Kingston Ferry" feels less harsh, less resolute in its darkness, which is prevented by persistently ethereal top notes and the Coveyade present here, though less spicy.

"Kingston Ferry" is a remarkable fragrance - very authentic, very powerful, very masculine.
I can easily imagine it on big, broad-shouldered, well-built, dark-haired, go-getter guys, taciturn and seemingly full of energy - and perhaps it was exactly this image of a man that inspired Ellen Covey to create this fragrance.
Who knows...?

The ferry arrives. It jolts violently as it brushes against the wooden pillars. The engines fall silent. Pedestrians, cyclists, and then also the vacationers, commuters, and delivery vans leave the ship with a metallic clatter. It gets quieter. Finally, I scurry off the deck just before the railing is closed. This was the last trip for today. I have time and sit on the edge...

review_title: In the Pine Forests of a Mediterranean Island
review_content: Actually, I didn't want to comment on this fragrance at all, actually. But I must disagree with your fish association, dear EP, so I will comment after all! Because for me, this fragrance has absolutely nothing fishy about it. I find myself in the pine forests of Ibiza, on a autumnal, misty morning. The trees and the ground covered with pine needles smell still damp and...

review_title: The Fish Stinks from the Head!
review_content: Until now, I have always praised Ms. Covey, but with this, I simply call it a contraption, she has really outdone herself. I never would have imagined in my wildest dreams such a dreadful top note as the one that developed on my skin with Kingston Ferry. Sure, the name of the contraption hinted at a maritime scent theme, but dead fish in a brackish water bucket has no place...

Sometimes I wonder what such ingredient lists like the one above are supposed to achieve. Could it be that there are translation errors involved, or a lack of knowledge in botany?
Cedar leaf? What is that supposed to be? The cedar is a conifer, calling the needles "leaves" in German is at least strange. In English, tree needles are referred to as "needle shaped leaves," at least in the "Oxford Advanced Learner's Dictionary of Current English."
Strawberry tree and heather lead to strange expectations. However, strawberry trees belong to the heather family. Heather only has a very intense scent in heather honey.
I just brought in a young green sprig of heather from outside, with almost bloomed flowers, and crushed it. It is a scent very familiar to me from northern Germany, in mixed forests and areas with heather: Herb, green, slightly bitter, very specific and nostalgic for me.
But you can really only recognize that if you know the smell of heather well and individually.
"Kingston Ferry Fragrance" does not smell like that at all!
Rhododendron? It hardly has a scent, not even the flowers, but they also belong to the heather family. OK, when you crush leaves and flowers of plants, they at least emit indifferent green leaf scents. And firewood can smell like any wood. Driftwood smells dry and somewhat special, maybe a bit like the sea, somewhat aquatic. Garden and wildflowers are simply arbitrary; anyone can choose what they perceive from it, it is always correct.
So what do I smell?
At first, something delicate that transforms into a green scent, somewhat herbal, spicy. I can also smell something herbal and resinous.
Not a very expressive scent, but still pleasant at first. I can also perceive light woody notes.
Then the scent becomes milder, unfortunately a bit sweet and then also smelling of aquatic Ambroxan.
I have to keep my nose close to the skin because the scent of the crushed heather "Kingston Ferry Fragrance" overpowers it.
I find the real heather scent much more beautiful and interesting.
So I have to concentrate. But now "Kingston Ferry Fragrance" has almost faded after 2 hours, there is still a little remnant of an indifferent scent left.
I have a suggestion: "Kingston Ferry Fragrance" was created as a perfume to sell to travelers as a souvenir during the crossing.
Then it doesn't matter what it smells like and how it smells.
That's why it's also a unisex scent. And with the light sillage, it's not an intrusive keepsake.

The advertising created for this fragrance at the time said:

Someone beautiful just passed by, someone wearing Intoxication!

Intoxication - the poisoning, the intoxication - a scent that is hard to find today. The Eau de Toilette comes in the same "pleated" Lalique bottle as the Extrait de Parfum, but unfortunately, the EdT has a plastic cap above the metal cap that serves as a screw closure, which has the same pleating as the bottle.

And this is also the only flaw of the EdT: the cap is made of plastic, not glass, and has become brittle and fragile over time, which somewhat reduces the value of the Lalique bottle. The D'Orsay crest is clearly visible on top of the cap, which does not enhance the brittle cap either.

The Eau de Toilette is not quite identical to the perfume, which is noticeably softer than the EdT.
Here, nothing of the initial softness can be felt anymore. On the contrary, the scent reaches a dry, almost creaky floral quality, which only jasmine, gardenia, violet, lily of the valley, and similar candidates can achieve. The dryness of the heart note is not powdery but rather herb-dry, without being bitter, as the floral sweetness is clearly present.

In projection, the whole is less creaky but quite loud, very perceptible, and with a hint of the initial softness.

The base smells only slightly woody, more mossy, herb-dark with a distinctly resinous accord. If there are animalic notes here, they are only cautiously dosed. I cannot perceive them at all.

In any case, the EdT is significantly louder than the Extrait de Parfum, which is rather defined by softness. In contrast, the EdT is a huge floral accord with dark background notes. It lasts extremely long.

As so often, I was surprised by the difference between Extrait de Parfum and Eau de Toilette. They are largely similar but still different in their effect. Soft and gourmand (perfume) against distinctly loud and slightly creaky (EdT).

Both are, however, beautiful fragrances, even today.

review_title: A cool colony too expensive for what it offers.
review_content:
