The perfume feels quality, but its performance is very loose, staying on my skin between 5 or 6 hours, with a moderate low projection, and although it sticks to the skin almost from the beginning, the narcissus got into my nose , and I was dizzy, smelled continuously, but only me, because I told my family members to smell me, and they told me that it smelled soft, but very well, in short, things of each other's chemistry.

It is a perfume of warm and temperate climates, and for day use, for casual outings and morning walks is a good candidate.

Being honest is a perfume that smells good, but I would not recommend it, especially due to its high cost and poor performance. It is one of those perfumes that I highly recommend a test before buying, to avoid disappointment, and once tested, if you like it, you yourself will know if it is worth the disbursement or not.

Sorry for my bad english.

Bergamot and orange with an aldehyde edge kick off this fragrance. The aldehyde note remains and forms an aura that persists throughout the development of the perfume. At the center of the pyramid, narcissus and jasmine flowers contrast with the spicy note of coriander and quickly leave the scene to make room for a blend kept fresh by aldehydes, composed of cedar wood, patchouli and white musk.
A composition that makes use of good raw materials, but which is too focused on aldehydes.

I went on a mission this summer to try neroli-forward traditional colognes. I hoped to find something fresh that fits a casual T-shirt vibe for Westside LA. I grabbed 5 ml decants of Neroli Portofino, Mandarino di Amalfi, Colonia Essenza, and Colonia Pura and wore them throughout the heat. Pura ended up my favorite of the bunch. The twist is that the whole “neroli cologne” lane ended up reading formal to me. Pura is less formal, which leaves it in a tricky spot. When I want a dressy cologne, I would reach for Mandarino di Amalfi, and for truly casual, I would go outside the lane. I’m sure I’ll finish off the decant next summer, but won’t re-buy.

TL;DR: Easier-going Essenza energy with an ozonic, airy opening, then a smoother floral-citrus where orange shows more than expected, finishing in a clean woody-musk that sits close. Clean, modern, polite. Casual feel in a traditionally formal genre. It does evolve from opening to heart to drydown; not wildly, but enough to feel like a journey. Probably a good wardrobe piece for someone who likes this scent profile, less so for me.

Rating:

Opening: 3.1/5
Drydown: 2.8/5
Overall: 5.9/10

Opening
Early ozonic hit. Petitgrain pushes a clear soapiness on my skin, stronger than I prefer. I had hoped that skipping neroli would avoid that effect, but petitgrain plus white musks and airy florals creates the same “Cheap McDonalds Soap Dispenser” vibe (how my nose reads heavy neroli). It feels like a softer, friendlier Essenza that stays in the classic cologne mold, just airier. As the soapiness settles inside the first half hour, a gentle orange facet unexpectedly comes forward.

Heart
From about 60 to 120 minutes, it is an easier floral-citrus that is smooth and tidy, with a light herbal thread. The coriander note blends with the florals and reads greener than Essenza. It is pleasant and feels purposefully “traditional cologne” while clearly offering a unique take.

Drydown
By hour 5, you are in a clean woody-musk of cedar, soft patchouli, and white musks. It does not project much, but it has more presence than the airy opening suggests. Quietly masculine and easy to carry into evening. The core trace lingers to about 7 hours, mostly at skin level.

Performance on me
Polite, but strong for the genre. About 1.5 to 2 hours of aura, then close to skin. Roughly 5 to 7 hours total, with the last stretch as a subtle skin scent. I’d catch scents of it through the day if I applied it to my wrists if I was hand talking.

Versatility
High in theory and trickier in practice. The DNA says formal, but it wears casual on me. I would use it for a T-shirt-and-shorts creative meeting, although I still prefer other summer picks for that slot.

Use cases
Office days, client coffees, brunch where you want the first hug to smell clean. School events and travel days, anywhere conservative etiquette helps.

Vibe
White tee, good jeans, fresh haircut. It’s clean and modern, but not “too cool”. This is the well dressed guy who's wearing a white t-shirt tucked into jeans with a crew cut. He looks good, smells good, but doesn't have too much main character energy. The cooler dude with messy hair who may be stealing your girl is probably wearing Neroli Portofino.

Blind-buy safe?
No. I think this whole genre requires testing. Won’t perform well enough for some. Florals won’t land for others. Too mature for yet others. Give it a decant if you want a clean, modern feeling cologne that replaces some of the “Floral!” with ozone and aldehydes.

Comparisons
Colonia Essenza: Sharper, dressier, more neroli-forward snap and more obvious soapiness. Pura is softer and airier, a modernized take.
Tom Ford Neroli Portofino: Louder orange-blossom soap. Next to NP, Pura reads less soapy and more airy and orange-clean. Less floral, more white-musk and ozonic.
Tom Ford Mandarino di Amalfi: Juicier mandarin and grapefruit with *mint, basil, and thyme. More sparkly and aromatic in the heart; less overtly soapy than *Pura. Dries down to light citrus-aromatic over musks and woods, while Pura turns cleaner and more white-musk polished.
Dior Homme Cologne (2020): Brighter “iced-lemonade” citrus and better early projection. Pura trades fizz for tidiness.
Le Labo Bergamote 22: Greener, grapefruit-tinged bergamot with a diffusive *musky-woody* halo and a clearer vetiver and cedar second act. B22 radiates more, while Pura stays closer and cleaner. It still has a three-phase evolution, just subtler.

Conclusion

Colonia Pura threads the needle between classic Italian cologne polish and modern, low-key cleanliness. It was my favorite of the group, yet it is the least “me,” because it lives between dressy and casual. If you want that perfect just-showered aura without orange-blossom drama, this nails it. If you want sparkle, volume, or a signature flourish, reach for Bergamote 22, Dior Homme Cologne, or Mandarino di Amalfi. For hot days when you want to look put together without trying, Pura delivers exactly what it promises.

Context for review: Multiple wears from a 5 ml decant, warm weather, moisturized skin, mostly indoors with brief outdoor breaks.

Once a week, I have a regular meeting in a completely different, unfamiliar hallway. And because I like a colleague who is also a fixed part of this group, and her office is on the way to this meeting, I occasionally pick her up on the way there. Recently, she was still sitting briefly with her boss and signaled to me that she would be finished soon - and that I should wait for her for a moment. So there I stood among unfamiliar desks, and on one of them sat - still in its original packaging - a bottle of Acqua di Parma's Colonia Pura. And suddenly it dawned on me: that's for Chnuddelchatz!

That colleague - a rather prosaic and sober, but by no means misanthropic person - has been telling me for months about a colleague in her team who calls her partner twice every single day - once in the morning and once in the afternoon. She doesn’t address him by his name and doesn’t simply call him 'Schatz', but 'Schnuddelschatz'. And she talks to him in baby talk, where the 'sch' is pronounced like 'ch' in 'ich', so: 'Chnuddelchatz'. And my colleague never knows whether to quietly break down in her bag or go around the table and give the cooing lovebird a gentle headbutt.

Chnuddelchatz will soon be fifty, as the whole hallway has known for weeks. And as a very special gift, they are going for a long Chnuddel weekend at a totally romantic Chnuddel hotel, probably to snuggle from Friday to Sunday evening. But since just the Chnuddel card with the voucher looks a bit meager - and Chnuddelchatz could also use a new Chnuddeldüftchen - she has now considered that she could buy him such a Chnuddeldüftchen. It has turned out to be Colonia Pura. Nice that I’m finally up to date!

I don’t know Chnuddelchatz personally, but I’m sure he will like Colonia Pura. Almost everyone should like Colonia Pura - okay, FabianO not so much, I just noticed - it is harmless enough not to displease anyone. A really nice, zesty, hesperidic top note, a playful, sweet Chnuddel heart, and a warm woody musk base. It has worked countless times, and it will work again. For a house like Acqua di Parma, which has a true classic in its portfolio with Colonia, it actually offers a bit too little. As a cash cow for spring/summer 2018, it will still suffice.

Conclusion: a Chnuddel scent for Chnuddelchatz. And now I’m going to wash my mouth out with soap.

...one should ideally test perfumes in the early morning/forenoon, as palate, nose, and tongue are still unburdened. Said..done! Yesterday at Breuninger, I was quite surprised to encounter Pura, as I had been told two weeks prior that it would only be released in September. It wasn't even prominently displayed on a special presentation tray, but rather inconspicuously next to the cash register. The joy was even greater that it was already available for purchase and not just for testing purposes. Sprayed a little, took a city tour, bought it:-)!
I have done 3 test rounds so far, and today's test deviates a bit from the others.
But let's go in order...
Colonia Pura starts extremely fresh and zesty, freshly squeezed lemon with a splash of orange. It's fresher and more citrusy than all the Colonias combined. Wow.. I wouldn't have necessarily expected that from the listed notes. You immediately know you have THE Colonia - the original - under your nose, fresh, tart, and typically masculine. This is exactly the difference for me compared to many Atelier Cologne scents, which are "only" the world champions of top notes; a contrast, a (masculine) counterpart is often missing, they are often one-dimensional (still often smell good!). The original Colonia is immediately "there," and yet the scent feels new, fresh, modern, and somehow clean.. maybe that's what "Pura" is meant to convey!? Clean not in the sense of dirty, but tidy, slim, transparent, and each individual note can be clearly detected, except for coriander. Green stuff from the herb kitchen, yes, but coriander.. no idea, doesn't matter.
In the extremely muggy 30 degrees yesterday, only the citrus notes came to the fore during the first two tests, along with the slightly soapy-creamy musk base. This morning, for the first time, I picked up the flowers and a hint of sweetness. Mainly, I could recognize the enchanting jasmine, which is often difficult in men's fragrances because it takes on a feminine direction, but not here. Even the Hermes-worthy Narcisse can't change that. Well dosed and still thoroughly a men's fragrance, but certainly wearable by women, although it will probably still be too tart for many.
The fragrance passes through the individual phases at a gallop; after 30 minutes, you've experienced everything. The highlights for me are clearly the top note and the even more beautiful floral heart note, as the scent has a certain depth in this phase. The patchouli in the base can be neglected; it's more of a hint than something that gives the fragrance a base or foundation.
Even though Pura isn't extremely different (except for the mono-club), I like it best with the original and it can still be wonderfully worn for the next 4-6 weeks; I find it a bit too refined for autumn and winter. It is the same yet so different from its brothers. Those who own the others probably don't need to have this one. If Colonia was too old-school for you, you might find joy in this one.
Longevity and sillage are Colonia-like. I do not regret the purchase; however, the fragrance came to market 2-3 months too late, like Cedro di Taormina back then, as it is a perfect spring and summer scent.

A beautiful, fresh variant and facet from the original classic theme, which is absolutely successful.
Not a must-have, but a very good fragrance!

review_title: In Parma they now also know Iso-E-Super...unfortunately. Damn!

Very high quality, there's no other way to say it. Some may...

review_title: Timeless classic modernized with bright flowers
review_content:
Another fragrance from Acqua di Parma has found its way into my collection last month. I haven't had a strong desire for heavier scents this year, also due to extremely mild temperatures and a lack of winter feeling. This way, one can start buying summer fragrances a bit earlier. Especially since Flaconi had a 30% discount. So I bought the 180ml for under 90 euros. For the size and the upscale AdP prices, it's a great bargain. A good size as well, since it's a wonderful cologne that can be worn for many occasions.
Acqua di Parma is a brand I really like. It simply stands for elegance with Italian flair. A lot of classic, especially through this Colonia line, which started with the classic over 100 years ago. Many modern and new releases have also followed, including the Blu Mediterraneo line, of which I also own 3 fragrances. Perhaps one or two more will follow from this brand.

I really like the bottles from this brand. Great glass in a round bottle, along with a stylish logo, kept simple and elegant. The Blu line is even more beautiful with blue glass, but here the bottle simply conveys the content: style and elegance.
I will keep the fragrance description brief. The original from 1916 is listed as a twin. The resemblance is clearly detectable. Especially the opening with lemon and bergamot is quite similar. In my opinion, Colonia Pura smells more modern and contemporary throughout its entire duration. This is likely due to fresh bright flowers and a lot of petitgrain, which refresh the scent in a modern way. The original is 100% timeless, but one must like these classic vintage DNAs, and they must fit one's style. In this case, one can say: It always works. A wonderful blend of fresh-citrusy DNA paired with bright flowers and herbaceous-green notes. The base fades out with slightly woody notes. Overall, it's a well-rounded experience from start to finish. The big highlights are absent, which is not unusual for this cologne concept. Always wearable in warm to hot temperatures, especially in everyday life. It might not be suitable for work if you don't want to reapply frequently. It lasts 3-4 hours with good sillage, possibly even longer close to the skin. But in summer, I enjoy a great refreshment for a few hours. This is wearable from young to old, by both women and men. In terms of scent type, it goes in a similar direction as Artisan Pure by John Varvatos, which is a tad better and performs significantly better.

Conclusion: For me, a great modernization of an absolute classic. It works well at temperatures above 20 degrees. A fragrance I can recommend, but only if you can get it on sale or have a discount code.

Let's hope for a wonderful summer with many opportunities to wear great summer fragrances under the given circumstances. Stay healthy.

The special thing about the yellow Colonias has been, in...

review_title: Once upon a time in Cologne ...
review_content:
... and one wondered, how can we make our original Cologne scent, which has existed for a long time and rightly so, different without betraying it?

That’s how Pura might have come to be. It also starts with a citrus scent, but only orange is included. Okay, that’s enough. Because in the overall composition, the original Cologne is present, but somehow more modern. Pura doesn’t start as loudly as the original Cologne, and the development remains at that level. The beginning is fresh, and then it becomes something that you don’t quite know from the original father. It develops with a slight understatement into a truly elegant fragrance. It fits with a fine suit, leather shoes, and a loosely tied tie with the top button of the shirt open. However, it is less conspicuous to the environment; the scent remains close to the body. It’s like a fine watch that was a bit more expensive, but doesn’t come off as too flashy (my recommendation here would be the Junghans brand with the Meister series).
And is all of this bad in the direction of ISO-E-Super? Not for me. It might be an approach to a different audience segment that has previously been more dedicated to the modern and trendy fragrance area. If that were even necessary. If yes, then it’s the opportunity to bridge these worlds. But it is by no means an attempt to pander through copying the synthetic fragrance world. Not at all! Pura stays on its side, so to speak. It never slips into that sticky candy world or clings heavily to the top note. It is simply more noble, but it could pass as modern. Whoever wears Pura still appears fine, balanced, and indeed more elegant. When you hang up your clothes in the evening, there’s something else there. A very light hint of fresh laundry... does that come from Pura, or was it really the detergent? The mere fact that I consider it possible that it could come from Pura makes this fragrance something special.
I find it wonderful!

.... By the way, I can do without Chnuddelchatz. Because what he’s up to interests me very little.

review_title: Stylish Fresh Fennel for the Office
review_content: I usually don't evaluate a fragrance based on its longevity. However, with this one, I find it really a bit too short. If you set longevity aside, Colonia Pura is, for my nose, a truly wonderful, fresh, and floral cologne. Somehow, after about 30 minutes, I detect a fennel note that makes the scent seem unique and very high-quality to me. I think the price-performance ratio...

review_title: Fresh, elegant, and uncomplicated everyday scent with weak longevity.
review_content:
A fresh and elegant fragrance for men. Citrusy and floral, yet rather subtle and cool. I can hardly imagine that the scent could provoke negative reactions in anyone, which makes it very suitable for work.

It would be a perfect everyday scent for men if it weren't for the rather weak longevity - I have to refresh the scent every two to three hours.

I really have to emphasize this:
A long time ago, the lemons
(I just don’t remember exactly when
this was) were as sweet as rock candy.

Until one day they said: “We lemons,
we want to be big like melons!
We also find the yellow disgusting,
we want to be red or bluish!”

God heard the complaints from above
and said: “Nothing can come of this!
You must stay as you are! I regret!”
Then the lemons became sour . . .

By Heinz Erhardt

What else is there to say about this fragrance? I’ll try to describe it like music.
The piece starts very citrusy fresh, almost sour. After a short while, the petitgrain joins in. However, I can’t make out any oranges; there are probably just pauses in the score.
Over time, the flowers also join the symphony and gradually take the lead. The lemons become quieter as the flowers get louder, but they never completely disappear.
The musk adds a light, transparent quality to the composition.
The cedar and patchouli have only very soft notes on the sheet music. They are probably playing along, but I can’t... uh, smell... them out individually. However, if they weren’t there, they would be missed.

As beautiful as the symphony of composer Demachy may be, it is unfortunately very short: after 3 hours, the last notes have faded away. The volume is well-suited for all places where the surroundings should hear a bit, but not be overwhelmed.

Personally, I have found a very special place for Mr. Demachy’s work: I like to wear the fragrance while sleeping, as it has a cooling and relaxing quality and is not too strong.

... than what is written here. I wore this fragrance again today. Applied at 6 AM and I could still perceive it well at 2 PM. Now it’s two and a half hours later and I can still smell this fragrance close to my body. What a scent from Acqua di Parma that is anything but bad. It may also depend on my skin. Fragrances tend to last relatively long on me. When applying this...

My first fragrance review - it simply has to be for this amazing scent!
I tested this fragrance several times at a good friend's place and immediately had to get a whole 180ml bottle for myself.
The scent opens wonderfully fresh and citrusy and over a period of 1-2 hours becomes nicely light woody, with the musk becoming more prominent. However, it remains beautifully fresh and relaxing for me. Even now in winter, I have worn this scent several times a week during online meetings because it simply reminds me of a relaxed summer day.
Unfortunately, on my skin, the performance ends after 3-4 hours - but in the home office, I can just reapply every few hours ;)

Honestly, I don't quite understand the criticism at this point... For me, this fragrance is the successful evolution of "Colonia | Acqua di Parma" towards a sweet summery scent without becoming feminine. The scent starts with a sweet floral freshness. Unfortunately, I can't go into detail about the individual notes. My somewhat inexperienced nose can't grasp this fragrance...

Since I find that all Acqua di Parma fragrances smell very natural and I can imagine that a high proportion of natural ingredients make their way into the bottles during production, I don't expect much in terms of longevity. Yesterday, I was able to test Colonia Pura. When I sprayed 2 pumps on my neck and wanted to perceive my first impression... there was nothing... huh???...

I find that Colonia Pura is a great reinterpretation of the original (Colonia EAU DE COLOGNE) It is more modern, zesty, and youthful. The original fits well into past days, but unfortunately, it can no longer keep up in today's time. In my opinion, you can tell the fragrance's age. Therefore, this addition is all the more beautiful....

After this variant of the Colonia has come into my collection as a small sample, I tested it today and have a few words to say about it.

First of all, I do not find Colonia Pura bad or unpleasant at all; it just seems a bit immature and not as harmoniously combined as the original. There are a few notes that throw the fragrance slightly out of balance, which is why it receives a somewhat lower rating.

About the scent:

It starts classically with a modified DNA of the original "Colonia (Eau de Cologne) | Acqua di Parma." However, I find it consistently less citrusy and also less fresh from the beginning, which may be due to the missing lemon. Additionally, there is a herbal coriander in the top note with a slightly balsamic spiciness that I find somewhat distracting. It simply diverts attention too much and partially covers the floral notes of jasmine and daffodil, which only appear later. This slightly medicinal and clean vibe is supported by the petitgrain and white flowers, which emphasize a green fragrance direction. The top and heart notes are coherent in themselves, if it weren't for a coriander that has gotten out of control. However, I am quite sure that some people who smell the fragrance will really enjoy the green, slightly fresh coriander notes and will cling to them.

In the base, there is primarily musk, which is by no means animalic, but rather beautifully creamy, giving Colonia Pura a great texture. The dry down is also slightly earthy and woody, coming from the patchouli and cedar. In my opinion, the base is very coherent and offers a smooth transition to the end of the fragrance.

Longevity and sillage are not particularly convincing due to it being a fresh EdC, as the scent disappears after about 5-6 hours. However, since this is not unusual for summer fragrances, I find this not too tragic.

In conclusion, I can say that Colonia Pura is an average good summer fragrance that will be a good catch for many. Since it also smells somewhat like older ladies to me, I think it is a bit outdated and obsolete for this time and by far not as good as the original. As a sample, I think it is certainly a good catch.

Definitely my favorite from the Colonia line - a very fresh, almost aquatic-maritime scent (if you smell closely, you can also detect salty sea notes). This initial impression fades relatively quickly, leaving behind a citrusy freshness that, in my opinion, is characteristic of Colonia. Excluding the price-performance aspect, this fragrance is worth it just for the opening.

When I was on vacation at Lake Constance and spontaneously tested the fragrance, I was quickly hooked. It was a hot day, and I had it sprayed on for testing. We were sitting by the water, and the wind constantly carried the bergamot/orange notes to my nose. Exactly what I needed on that day. Never intrusive, rather subtle and not at all piercing. In my opinion, it is more of a classic, fresh scent compared to the Blu Mediterraneo line, which feels more distinctive.
A few hours later, I had already bought the bottle, mind you at a good price/performance ratio.
Due to the light sillage, I like to spray more of it on without worrying about bothering others. Also, because the longevity is rather mediocre; after a good 4 hours, it has almost completely faded.

Many thanks to Andreas for the miniature sample :-) I have to say, this scent surprised me in a way... unfortunately more negatively... I find the smell quite good, but the longevity is poor... I don't even want to talk about the sillage... And then there's the price... A purchase seems completely out of the question for me. At first, I was also very irritated because this...

review_title: An Olfactory Tribute to Natural Harmony
review_content: In creating this fragrance, Lucien Ferrero took inspiration from the pastoral and picturesque motions of Beethoven's 6th Symphony. In other words, he wanted to capture nature's beauty and experience its harmonious splendour, into an olfactory concept. The end product is a scent that is both invigorating and soft, a fragrant journey through a sunlit meadow, while a gentle breeze whispers through leaves, enhancing your earthy and grounding experience, Its balance and natural-smelling profile means that it is versatile and elegant.

review_title: Summer Rain in the Castle Garden
review_content:
At the outset and deep into the heart, unsweetened, very sour, almost bitter citrus aromas (more unripe lemon than mandarin) dominate, combined with aromatic notes (lavender, mint) and earthy-mineral notes (notably mastic, perhaps a bit of geosmin, and from deep in the base, the patchouli+vetiver combo). The official scent pyramid seems relatively truthful to me.

In my mind's eye, deep green, slightly floral, and cool-wet associations arise - to be precise, I think of a castle park with well-kept lawns and rose hedges and/or gardenias, from which water beads shortly after a summer thunderstorm, while the sky has not yet cleared. With the rain, the temperature has also dropped; it has become a bit too cool for short-sleeved clothing.

I am still not one hundred percent sure which other fragrances this reminds me of, but there are definitely candidates. Perhaps Floris' Elite, which, when testing, reminded me of a distinctly more aristocratic (Gucci) Nobile. The base vaguely leans towards late 70s men's fragrances, without me being able to name anything specific. However, I generally think more of Aramis than Quorum, which the creator himself mentioned in his fragrance description.

For this turn towards classic men's perfumery, I respect this scent very much, but I wouldn't want to wear it frequently. The slightly gloomy and very classic aura is too alien to my nature or not what a fragrance should radiate for me.

In this respect, I find it quite fitting that the naming references classical music. Is it Beethoven's 6th Symphony? Probably not. If anything, only the less cheerful movements. Perhaps more Mozart or Schubert than Beethoven. But what do I know, I’m not really well-versed in that.

If the fragrance had more cheerfulness before and after the rather gloomy main part, it would indeed be comparable to a symphony and somehow genius. As it stands, Harmonie Pastorale gets a thumbs up from me but no purchase.

review_title: Never has coffee smelled so noble...
review_content:
During my travels through China, I got stuck in the IT Store in December 2012. Not for clothes, no, but for the fragrances by Herve Domar from Paris. The IT Store sells all the clothing brands that are fine and expensive. Classics like Givenchy, D&G, and Versace as well as newcomers like Alexander Wang, etc.

I didn’t care. I sniffed my way through Domar’s fine bottle creations priced at around €80. All contain one to two gemstones. He names his fragrances after them. Not particularly original, but Emeraude (Emerald) blew me away. Those who know Montale Intense Cafe and find it too sweet and feminine will be happy with Emeraude. It is much nobler and more mature. Unfortunately, it seems to be completely unavailable in Germany. After my sample, I must buy it now. Absolutely.

About the scent: It starts like a mix of amaretto coffee and vanilla syrup. Not very fresh yet so powerful right away. One-dimensional but noble and inevitable like a Tobacco Vanille by Tom Ford. This amber that flashes through repeatedly is wonderful. People around me immediately noticed the scent, and it lasted a whole day or rather a 12-hour flight. That’s what you want from a fragrance. I sense little patchouli, but the sandalwood comes out perfectly and softly in the dry down. Has a bit of Black Afgano by Nasomatto perhaps hidden itself in the Emeraude scent? It’s always a pleasure to smell myself with this fragrance. Great for winter or elegant evenings.

Hands down Mr. Herve Domar. I am your fan. Whoever finds it, buy it! Please leave me the address :)

Scent: 9/10

review_title: high-quality spice bomb resembles Raghba Wood Intense
review_content:
As a tobacco scent, I wouldn’t describe this fragrance; I smell an incredible amount of high-quality spices here, the scent is wonderfully balanced, none of the listed ingredients stands out in a disturbing way, and the fragrance does not smell cloying, like Raghba Wood Intense. If you focus on the many ingredients, you can detect a very light cigar note, but lilies, ginger, and many other notes swirl around it ......
The sillage is good but not intrusive, a great fragrance from the renowned perfumer Michelle Moellhausen!

After reading several rave reviews of Brecourt L'AMOUREUSE, I came dangerously close to buying a bottle blind. Fortunately, rationality prevailed, and I ordered the sample set instead. I say "fortunately" because this turns out to be another jammy floral very similar in style and quality to many designer perfumes on the market today.

I think that I was expecting a different quality level of perfume, although it is true that this self-proclaimed niche line is quite modestly priced. Seems like a case where you get what you pay for. In this case, L'AMOUREUSE offers a sort of compote of red jam berries and flowers, including rose. But I myself would not categorize this as a rose perfume.

This perfume might be a good choice for people attempting to transition from designer to haute niche, but it's much closer to the former than the latter, at least according to my nose.

review_title: Not what I thought it would be
review_content: Huge no for me, the perfume was not as good and fruity as expected... The jasmine smells so wrong mixed with the fruits and actually kind of remove the super yummy fruit aspect. A very musty and dirty jasmine mixed with a bit of raspberry and cannot really smell any other fruits. The notes look so tempting but the fragrance is actually not that good.

review_title: And if they are not divorced...
review_content:
Maybe you just have to be in love.
In love and young and carefree.
You have to live in that state where the flowers are brighter, the fruits sweeter, where the whole world seems to be coated in a sugar crust and you float around in pop-art-colored soap bubbles.
To be in love, perhaps for the very first time.
Not yet knowing, not wanting to know, that this feeling is a state of exception, artificially induced in the brain's own chemistry lab, not unlike a drug high and equally time-limited.
Which is a blessing, by the way, because who would want to, who could live in a state of permanent euphoria - not to mention: insanity?!

Maybe you have to be in love to love "L'Amoureuse," to find yourself in it and nod in understanding.
Perhaps this is simply my problem: that I love, for a long time now, but am no longer in love, no longer suffering from racing heartbeats, from sweating, insomnia, and obsessive thoughts about the object of my desire.
Fortunately not - I would hardly have survived eight years of uninterrupted ecstasy unscathed.
On the other hand, it is precisely this non-state that prevents me from giving "L'Amoureuse" the respect it surely deserves, from enjoying the sweet fruits and the technicolor flowers that dance around me in a breathtaking whirl, from which only now and then a raspberry and a candied violet peek out.
Sweet and colorful and a bit exhausting, it's a little like being at a fair, where one carousel ride chases the next until I no longer know where my head is.
And it is quite similar with being in love.

If all goes well, infatuation eventually turns into love, the exuberance subsides and flows into calmer, more contemplative, but also deeper waters.
From the all-encompassing rosy hue, individual colors crystallize out, blood pressure and breathing slow down, and thoughts that do not revolve around the beloved return to the mind, and perhaps one is quite glad to use the night for sleeping, with the lights off, eyes closed, and bed socks on the feet.
The high tension gives way to the compatibility tester of everyday life, and "L'Amoureuse" also takes its foot off the gas, dims the sweetness, and sprays a little hairspray over the flowers, which now resemble a dried bridal bouquet more.
That is livable - and if they are not divorced, then they still love each other today.

I perceive "L'Amoureuse" as a young, especially playful fragrance in the first hours, and certainly one that needs to be dosed with caution, which sometimes reminds me of the first version of "Eden," without revealing its primal force.
Where "Eden" boasts powerful sweetness from the first to the last second, "L'Amoureuse" becomes quieter, more mature over time, and for me personally, also more bearable.
But to fall in love, to love at all, it takes just a little more...

review_title: Scenes from a Marriage - Today: Conversation at the Breakfast Table
review_content:
My entire family slept poorly last night. We were all somewhat restless and kept waking up. No idea what such phenomena are related to: weather fronts, earth rays, comet constellations? The look in the mirror this morning showed me a totally crumpled and tired being.

"When everything seems perfect and we feel the breath of eternal youth, the spirit is enthusiastic and the body is free - a euphoric moment." - the advertisement from ALzD for "L'Amoureuse" promised the suitable antidote for this state.

The ugly, black, bulky bottle does not fit my idea of love at all. Anyway, I have no intention of hanging this thing around my neck. It's all about the content!

Freshly dabbed with the perfume, I enter the kitchen and sit down at the laid breakfast table. I haven't perceived much of the perfume so far. It started off fresh and then became floral, fruity, sweet, and only barely perceptible to me. Individual scent notes do not stand out.

During breakfast, I sniff at my arm. Hardly anything to smell. Since testing a fragrance creation by Mr. Schön, I have become cautious. With that one, I also hardly smelled anything, but my surroundings were overwhelmed by the surrounding scent cloud. Maybe this is the new modern art of perfumery: you hardly smell anything yourself, just lightly and only as a single scent note, and the people around you fall to the ground?

I sniff at my arm again. My husband starts to grin.

HE: "I'm not going to say anything about that."

ME: "I promised Hasi I would write a comment. So how do I smell?"

HE: "I smell nothing!"

I get up, walk over to him, and hold my arm under his nose.

ME: "Do you smell anything now?"

HE: "Wait a moment... slightly sweet like fruit. Is that YOU?! I thought it was coming from our trash can. But now that you're standing next to me, I can smell it quite clearly. Yes, it's only since you've been in the kitchen that it smells like this."

ME: "Thanks, that's enough. I don't need any more impressions from you."

HE: "You don't want to write that in your comment, do you?!"

Yes, that's exactly what I'm doing here. I can't think of a better description for L’Amoureuse.

Well, the Brecourts. I haven't tried them all yet, but here is yet another fragrance in the "Yawn" category, and unfortunately, also in the subcategory "Wanted but Not Achieved." While other boring, pardon, unspectacular scents from this house are at least somewhat well-made, L'Amoureuse unfortunately also shows qualitative weaknesses.

The perfume starts off quite promising. The opening is crisp, zesty, and I look forward to a possible chypre development; the citrusy-bitter orange peel with a skillfully dark-sweet contrast piques my curiosity and puts me in a favorable mood for this creation.

And then it happens very quickly. Suddenly, another note slithers in and ruins everything. Plastic. Very synthetic, unfortunately. I think this was supposed to be an apple note. But alas, from now on it smells like an air freshener from the drugstore, scent direction "Apple - Orange." Fruity and artificial.

As with some other Brecourts, all the ingredients here have been so minimized and homogenized that only a single scent note has come out of it, and that is once again very boring. There is no multidimensionality, no depth, no development. It’s a bit like mixing all the colors of the watercolor set endlessly until a dull gray comes out at the end. This is especially true for the base, which is simply floral-fruity-sweet, but unfortunately also with the plastic note.

No.

review_title: What does it remind me of....
review_content: I can't help it, but this scent reminds me of one that I know. I just can't name it. It is a fragrance that I must have worn or at least tried many years ago. But I can't recall. All in all, very pleasant and mass-appealing. The opening is fresh and floral, but within a few minutes, it becomes fruity sweet. This fruity-floral-sweet note runs like a red thread through the...

According to Brecourt's fragrance description, a woman who is freshly in love should smell like this. Well, I have been in love several times in my life, or at least I thought I was, but I have never smelled like this, and I would never want to smell like this. It is a small, sweet fruit cocktail. The scent reminds me at most of teenagers who are frantically popping a Juicy...

Unpopular Scents No. 4
Sometimes perfume is a beautiful parable of life. How often have I rated something not so bad as bad, just because it fell short of my expectations? At the current time, L'Amoureuse has a fragrance rating of 4.7 on Parfumo. I can understand that, but I wonder what is being rated here: If L'Amoureuse were a drugstore scent, it would surely have a...

Somehow, the scents from Brecourt that I have tested so far seem like fragrance twins of scents that once existed, or still exist? Has the concept of a US brand been adopted and instead of kitschy colorful glass bottles, opted for plain black? Be that as it may, this love affair has existed in a similar form before. Here too, a fragrance from the good old days of powerful...

As I read through the fragrance notes, I doubt my perception. I take the small tester out again, read, and realize it is indeed "L'Amoureuse" that I have used. But where is the fruit? Where is the orange blossom? The reviews from my predecessors also confuse me. Can my nose be so differently calibrated? ------ Addendum from 28.01.2011 The fragrance was incorrectly bottled....

In my 3rd semester, I had a salmonella poisoning that presumably stemmed from fruit salad. Canned fruit!
This painful experience, which I successfully repressed for 20 years, is now very present again thanks to L'Amoureuse. Canned fruit!
I have rarely smelled anything that has evoked such horrible associations in me.
Disgusting.

This attar immediately opens with fruity notes, specifically first pear and shortly after Raspberry, which are then muted by citrus, giving a touch of sparkle, thus avoiding creating a fruit salad effect.
In small steps the scent enters the heart and here it becomes an ode to the rose, first with green, dry nuances, then emerges a then lemony not too disturbing and a little powdery, leading all the way to the dry down where the woody notes, which play a role on the side, emerge

The way this rose develop is similar to Fueguia's "Aguila de Ambar", however deprived of the sweet amber part that not everyone might like.

Still, this is a good blend that can have everyday use.

review_title: the royal temple of the orient
review_content:
and once again we (the perfumer of these amazing scents and I) spent our lunch break together in our favorite cigar lounge, enjoying a great Cuban cigar during a relaxed discussion. We gladly used the time for our shared passion for "amazing scents." Here, I had the luck to get my hands on a fantastic fragrance from "Nebiru." It was String Theory EXTRAIT as a perfume spray. For me, this was a special honor, as it is sold out and I was able to learn the story behind it. So I was very curious about what awaited me.

I sprayed this scent directly onto my skin. With such natural fragrances, this is truly the best thing you can do. What can I say, "bäääähhhhmmm, what is this!?" Just wow. I absolutely did not expect that. Until now, I was not familiar with the individual fragrance notes. So it was time to let the scent unfold and let my thoughts wander.

On the first sniff, I get something incredibly fruity, dense, and absolutely natural. Sweet, yes, but really very natural and not too sweet. Until now, I only knew overly sweet or rather artificial "oriental" scents. This one has truly shown me a new kind of sweetness. Fantastic. The scent is so rounded and dense that it creates such a harmonious composition. I am always very cautious with rose and iris, as they often become too much, too old, too kitschy, or something else for me. But here, simply wonderfully intertwined and in no way too much or intense. The roses and the blue lotus are wonderful and provide a light floral touch without being really floral. The ouds are beautifully combined and woven together. There is absolutely no sign of barnyard oud. Just a wonderful woodiness that you can enjoy. Hyrax, musk, civet, all animalic notes. But even here, so finely and beautifully intertwined that this animalic aspect rather rounds it off and embraces you, connecting with you to form a veil.

What lingers in my nose the whole time is an animal, somehow something dark and leathery. Not the usual animalic scent, no, an animal, but without being really recognizably animalic. It is wonderful and quite extraordinary. Here too, I learned how this "animalic" aspect comes about.

I must say that the perfume spray is brighter, more open, and radiates more. The animalic aspect comes through more as well. Whether attar or spray is ultimately a matter of taste. I find both wonderful. Currently, I own the "String Theory (Attar) | Nebiru Parfvms." The longevity is again from another planet. The quality is, of course, outstanding here as well.

Many thanks to Frederic for the experience.

review_title: An Urban Fragrance for the Modern Gentleman
review_content:
Brooklyn by the Brooklyn Soap Company has captivated me from the very beginning. It is a modern, uncomplicated Eau de Parfum that conveys urban chic while also providing a pleasant lightness.

The Fragrance:
Immediately after application, a fresh and citrusy top note unfolds, radiating clarity and vitality. However, the perfume does not stop at freshness: over time, aromatic herbs and a gently spicy note blend in, giving the fragrance more depth and character. Particularly pleasant is that Brooklyn never feels too heavy or intrusive. It remains elegant and wearable, ideal for everyday use or special occasions.

Performance:
The longevity pleasantly surprised me. Despite its light freshness, the fragrance lasts solidly for several hours on the skin and unfolds beautifully. The sillage is subtle, never coming across as unpleasant - just right for those who prefer not to be too intense.

Conclusion:
Brooklyn is an ideal companion for men who value a well-groomed, modern appearance. The fragrance feels high-quality without being overwhelming, and it is definitely versatile. Those in search of an urban, timeless, and understated scent will find it here.

Overall, a clear recommendation for anyone looking for a stylish addition to their fragrance collection.

review_title: Wear me at work where I am going to wear off!
review_content:
The title is very fitting in my opinion.
This fragrance is a great everyday companion for work (but certainly also for the gym or leisure in general).

This is subjectively due to the fact that the scent is very quiet and probably won't even be noticed. Only in close proximity. That means the fragrance is very close to the skin and quite subtle after 1-2 hours. The nice thing for me is that I still perceive it again and again. But what exactly do I perceive?

For me, the scent starts off spicy-citrusy and quickly transitions into a creamy citrus fragrance. If you spray too much at once, it comes off a bit soapy. Probably due to lavender notes.

The mentioned creaminess combined with the freshness of lemon really smells very pleasant and comforting. The scent is very linear and does not develop further. The reason for my purchase was that I really liked the beard oil with the same scent direction. However, the beard oil is, in my opinion, a bit more citrusy and less 'creamy-soapy'.

Conclusion: If you are looking for a fresh-creamy-lemony clean man scent, you will find it here. Due to the very weak longevity and sillage, just take the bottle with you and reapply as often as you like. Otherwise, the title is the program. For the price, I think it's a nice pleasure.

review_title: A fragrance with more than one surprise:
review_content:
Thanks to a nice comment from a perfumer, I found the motivation and am now writing my first fragrance review.

Brooklyn is undoubtedly a fragrance that is highly fascinating and uniquely combines freshness and citrus notes with green tones and spiciness in equal measure. What makes it unique is a certain lightness that is noticeable in every fragrance note, without losing depth. This scent caught my attention more than once during our first encounter, and I wondered how it manages to evoke such fascination.
Here is my attempt at an explanation:
"From nothing to something", American Dream, New York City, Gin and Tonics. These associations are triggered by the fragrance, and I recognize them.

As soon as I spray the fragrance, I immediately notice the cypress and juniper, which remind me of a Gin Tonic. But just a few seconds later, the lime becomes increasingly prominent, adding a citrus-fresh note that creates a clear contrast to the green-bitter base note. This shift between the different notes constitutes the first surprise.

The second surprise occurs in the drydown: The Gin Tonic transforms into a Gin Fizz, with the juniper and lime remaining while mint joins in. The mint is distinctly noticeable and stays present for quite a while before it is gradually replaced by a modern interpretation of a fougère. This interpretation is extremely well done and fascinating in its development.

Finally, the fragrance reaches its surprising conclusion, characterized by incense and cedar. This gives the fragrance an unexpected but elegant note.

Unfortunately, the fragrance dissipates a bit too quickly, although with a longevity of about 6 hours, it is still reasonable considering the freshness and the price. However, I expected a bit more due to the green notes. The sillage is good and perceptible for a long time, but not extraordinary.
I find the bottle simple, but fitting.
In summary, Brooklyn, you are not only a great neighborhood but also a great fragrance. For me, it is the perfect choice for a spring feel-good scent that is suitable for all occasions.

review_title: An "incredible" vintage chypre of the highest class!
review_content:
Discovered on the "discard list" (thanks Markus!), ordered blindly for a swap and hit the mark - or rather, the green one. A fragrance that, by reading its page, excites my expectations even more. Now it will be described in detail and enjoyment, just as I perceive it.
At the beginning, very "potent" citrus fruits await in natural aromas for the further ingredients, which can already be sensed before they are truly smelled. Then, shortly after, the greenest galbanum emerges, accompanied by a primal birch-tar leather note, inky, rough, and soft at the same time. The lemony and orangey scents follow closely behind. Then it becomes woody. Sandalwood - like in the past - probably still real! delights all the senses. Spiked with mosses and a delicate vanilla glaze. Earthy notes also leave nothing to be desired. There’s herbaceous-grassy-rooty vetiver paired with a good portion of patchouli. The citrus fruits are still present! And the sandalwood-moss accords reach their peak. Galbanum greets green and bright all around. Fortunately, the birch-tar leather does not want to give way! A true vintage world unfolds before my nose. More modern niche fragrances in this direction cannot do it better! Also in terms of longevity, Sterling plays in the top league, the sillage, powerful, yet never exaggerated, has everything that the green chypre heart desires!
Truly a dream fragrance! Dream?? It stands before me and I revel in its odor! :-))

I used to enjoy wearing John Sterling back in the late 90s, as I am really into leathery scents. It's just a shame that this fragrance is currently so hard to find, either through online shops in the USA or on eBay; unfortunately, it is no longer available in regular perfumeries here. It is truly a wonderful scent that can preferably be worn in summer or autumn. The top note is clearly dominated by the delicious fresh clementine, which skillfully transitions into the leathery heart, while patchouli and musk form the base, perfectly balanced. A refined fragrance. Always modern and just right as a daily scent for the office.

Because that's where I got my OF from, and at a quite reasonable price. "John Sterling"? Neither Fragrantica nor Basenotes provide any information about the manufacturer or what the name might refer to. Wikipedia knows of a Scottish author by that name as well as, among others, a fairly well-known football commentator.

Is this the only fragrance from this "brand"? If it is even a brand at all. On the bay, you can find it at what I consider reasonable prices as "Forester John Sterling." All quite confusing, almost mysterious...

About the scent: Clearly 1984, it could easily be older due to its character. The association made by the esteemed colleague Fiddleworth with classic English colognes does not resonate with me. Was the name perhaps the father of the thought? Damn, where does this scent come from?

For me, it is clearly a representative of the classic spicy men's fragrances, as we know and appreciate them from the 60s and 70s. Right after a very brief citrus appearance in the top note, it introduces leather accords that shape this fragrance throughout its entire development. Among other things, I also smell an accord that reminds me of my signature scent, the divine "Mark Cross." If a fragrance can achieve that, it immediately earns a place in my heart.

So why only 80%? Well, this beautiful scent is ultimately too subtle for me; for its class, it could use a bit more punch and longevity, and if a decent dose of oakmoss had been added in the base, it could have been a done deal for me. As it stands, it leaves an extremely positive impression. Old-schoolers should definitely give it a try.

John Sterling comes in noble attire.
Just as befits a gentleman on his travels.

A simple blue bottle adorned with a silver-framed leather crest, packaged in a midnight blue box with silver lettering ... and for those who prefer something particularly elegant, the bottle has also been wrapped in a brown synthetic leather case.
This way, it is excellent for transport and quickly accessible while traveling.

A fresh, slightly sharp citrus note opens this fragrance, immediately accompanied by a gradually intensifying leather accord that soon makes its presence felt quite dominantly.
This accord, which inevitably reminds me of large, handcrafted travel bags made from the finest leather, is flanked by a multi-layered, profound wood note that quickly takes on a green hue.

A light, somewhat soapy undertone adds the image of a barbershop, pleasantly understated and rounded off by a faint, sweet, very discreet hint of vanilla.
The sillage is good; it lasts on my skin for at least 8 hours.
No, John Sterling is not a great fragrance.
While it has a distinct recognition effect, in my opinion, it cannot measure up to the traditional English scents it is clearly inspired by.
It is a pleasant, albeit somewhat curious blend of Trumper's "Eau de Quinine" and Taylor's "Sandalwood Cologne," whose nobility it unfortunately never reaches.

I would still like to recommend it to all those who are enthusiastic about barbershop fragrances, were it not for the strange pricing - I still remember well that the prices now quoted in euros were not even asked for in Deutsche Marks several years ago.

Clean & comforting. Vegetal yet fruity. This a lovely easy reach perfume that’s inoffensive, (slightly) soapy and quietly inviting. This could easily be a fresh bedtime scent or a work-friendly skin scent.

As a skincare girly, I immediately get the centella asiatica note: it’s gentle, green and fresh. The peach note is subtle. The green plums here are tart in a subdued way. It’s less sweet & fruity than I expected. I think this could pair well several hyacinth-forward soapy skin scents. For instance, I think this would be truly a delight layered with Posies’ “Heartless.”

Ginger Ale, many love it, but many do not, yet it is one of the most consumed non-alcoholic and slightly bitter soft drinks. It has a distinctive and refreshing scent that has been very well captured here.

The fragrance:
Wow, what a rendition. You immediately smell the typical and citrusy Ginger Ale scent, as if you had poured yourself a glass of this herbal lemonade.
But now comes the truly special something about this fragrance. You actually feel as if you could taste or inhale the sparkling bubbles of the carbonation in the drink. It almost makes your mouth water, so much so that you would like to drink the scent, which you probably shouldn’t do… even if it says Cologne on the label.

The longevity is terrible. At first, you enjoy the pleasant scent, and in the next moment, you wonder if you had merely imagined it. It lasts barely 30 minutes before it completely disappears.
The sillage is weak; it could be compared to 4711 Eau de Cologne fragrances. It is not meant to project the scent into the surroundings, but rather to refresh oneself temporarily.

The bottle is weak, as always. But it is sufficient, as always.
The label is weak, as before. It has a lot of stuff written on it, as usual.

This fragrance has been very authentically realized, and I also found it great that it could even convey that sparkling sensation.

Aside from that, it is one of the rarer Demeter fragrances that I actually find wearable, as it has a certain similarity to Eau de Cologne and similar citrusy refreshing scents. However, you can only enjoy it very briefly, as it unfortunately (oh no, I say unfortunately for a Demeter fragrance!) vanishes in the next moment. But I think it is a good alternative to 4711 if you want a quick freshness kick, although 4711 probably lasts more than twice as long.

So, feel free to test it. If you ever see it or get your hands on it…
